So, "Starwalker" is definitely nice, it seems more interesting than "Luna Rossa", although it tries to please quite a few tastes, which clearly results in a lack of individuality and edges.

review_title: Mountain Stream in the Coniferous Forest
review_content:
OOOCH, some might think, Another forest again. Yes, that's right. But this time it's a different forest. In the mountains. And with a rushing stream.
A pleasant coolness envelops me, the crystal-clear water bubbles and hops over sticks and stones, gurgling and murmuring silvery to itself.
A hint of the south lingers in the air. Bergamot, ice-cold, citrus, and a grassy note.
I am still in a meadow landscape, the forest lies ahead of me.
I dive into the shady green world, surrounded by tall fir trees. Like small speckles, sunlight penetrates the treetops and dapples the path before me. Spicy air surrounds me, it smells almost "metallic" and cool. (Could it be due to the ginger included?) and very woody-needled. Once I stop to quench my thirst at the stream. The water is cold, and I have to drink slowly. It refreshes immensely and gives me new strength to continue hiking. The stream accompanies me for a long time through the forest. Until evening falls, and the stars twinkle.
Why "Starwalker" is no longer produced is a mystery to me.
It has a rather long-lasting, pleasant scent for me, and I use it when my nose needs a break from complex perfumes.

High above, far beyond the clouds and beyond the imagination of people, the Little Prince lives on his small planet. There is no one there to disturb him, no one who wants anything from him. All he desires and what enriches his life is her, the little beautiful rose, which he guards like a treasure.

Lost in thought, he lies on his back, looking towards the sky and gazing at the starry sky. He counts them as he dreams away and wonders how long they have been there and who placed them there. They illuminate his face like lights and cast shadows on his planet. He feels so free up here, away from all the tragedy and heaviness of life. Down on Earth, it is hectic and restless, but he is unaware of it.

The next day, riding on a shooting star, he flies through the familiar universe to discover unknown corners
But he realizes that he prefers to be at home, dreaming, caressing, and cherishing his rose, the light life indeed, the life as it should be, he chooses
Yes, he is a true connoisseur, a star walker and daydreamer, that blond-haired prince, one who does not have to grow up at all costs. And it is this way of life that I think of when I hear "Starwalker." A fragrance - similar to "Dreamer" by Versace - that awakens eternal dreamy youth. A scent that transports you to fantasy worlds and makes you forget all heaviness. Yes, it exudes such lightness that it carries you and reminds you of the little prince gliding on a shooting star. It doesn’t take much, just a bit of bergamot, cedar, and bamboo, and we have a light fresh-woody mixture of infinite delicacy and purity. Completely straightforward and a gentle, albeit pleasantly potent, companion through the heaviness of time.

So, for those who like to dream and, it must be admitted, still want to smell damn good and pleasantly masculine, this is the right choice. You get a lot for a small price and are well-equipped for spring and autumn.

Be like the little prince, remain a child at heart, enjoy your current mini-planets, look to the sky, dream, and take care of your roses.

May the stars be favorable to you like to the little prince and invite you to the imaginary star run. I've been caught, I need this.

See you soon,
Bene and the little prince**

review_title: This is what mainstream cologne smells like
review_content: I used to work with a young man who wore Legend. He was a financial planner who drove a mid-sized sedan, wore polo shirts on his day off, played tennis and golf and had client lunches with retired rich people. If you know that guy, you know what Legend smells like. Unoriginal, mainstream, devoid of unique personality, but "likable".

review_title: The Pen Maker is Behind a Solid Office Scent.
review_content:
One day, my best friend mentioned she loved a fragrance from Ulta and thought it would be an excellent addition to the collection of affordable fragrances.

When she told me the fragrance was Montblanc Legend, I decided to purchase it and give my thoughts.

----

Montblanc Legend starts with a citrusy aroma with bergamot and lemon, with a hint of freshness that comes from lavender. After a moment, the heart of the fragrance reveals itself with light florals. The florals complement the opening that extends the freshness, but keep the fragrance light.

The woods, tonka bean, and (possibly) oakmoss give Legend a firm base that adds a warm and confident feel, without being overly sweet.

Notably, it does smell similar to Abercromie and Fitch's Fierce, which was prevalent in American malls in the 2000s. This can be nostalgic, or off-putting.

----

In terms of performance, Legend is solid as an eau de toilette.

As I say in other reviews with similar projection and sillage, Legend will not announce your presence as you enter a room. However, the fragrance may get a person to turn their head as you walk by them, or they walk by you.

The longevity of this fragrance is anywhere from six to eight hours on skin. It should last for an entire workday or a night out—but likely not both without a respray.

----

Legend is an uncomplicated fragrance that is easy to wear in any social situation, whether it is at the gym, out on a date, or as a daily fragrance.

It is also easy to wear in all seasons, but Legend works the best in the comfortable temperatures of spring and autumn, and to a lesser extent, summer. It is weakest in the winter but has enough strength to push through the cold air.

For a fragrance that costs less than $40.00 for a 100 ml bottle, Legend provides amazing versatility.

That said, Legend shines the most as a fragrance in the office, as the notes combine for a fresh professional smell that is not offensive.

----

Legend is not a fragrance for someone looking for artistry or complexity. In addition, the fragrance may not mesh well with teens, or anyone that dislikes Fierce from the 2000s.

However, for someone looking for an affordable daily fragrance that works in multiple situations, Legend is a viable option.
Fruity and aquatic , fresh and clean although a little old and common .The sillage is good in the summer. i had 2 bottle of it and three different woman asked me about my perfume . women like it :)

I must say that I bought Legend by Montblanc because of the price, it was quite affordable (coffret with shower gel about 45€ for the 50ml bottle), I was tempted to buy it after trying it in 1 min or so. I have the highest respect for the Montblanc brand, and I was a happy owner of a Legend Night bottle. This one has nothing to do with the Night version.
The opening is very energetic, you receive a lot of fresh citrus and a bit of lavender (which I love) like a punch in the face. Vibrant head notes.
According to me, the problem with this scent is the heart, I think the floral notes are a mess, they' re confused, you don't get them clearly, the don't complete each other very well (rose and jasmine as described cause I don't get them), there is a woody note but I don't get the white cedar.
The base remains fresh, maybe the evernyl that I don't know that much. is a bit green, maybe too green, I was expecting much more warmth. The longevity is about 5-6 hours. Not that bad. Everyday scent, not too expensive. Not a first option in that "genre", try it out before buying. Good average fragrance. Nothing else. Not a "Legend" at all.

review_title: An awesome opening, and an overall nice scent.
review_content:
I did like this one. It reminded me of how much I like fruit done right in a fragrance. It reminds me a little of Aventus by Creed but only in the initial opening. I don't find this fragrance controversial or offensive at all. In fact I think that anyone and everyone would like this.

I like the apple and pineapple aspects, and the lavender mid and the woody base. Yes it's been done before in other male-marketed fragrances, but it's still a really nice fragrance. I would personally wear it. It's great, it works for almost any occasion, and is inoffensive and interesting enough for people to notice and be intrigued. This has been my first time trying a fragrance from Mont Blanc and personally I think it's a good one.

review_title: A fruity fougere and a memory of past's manly men's after shave colognes!
review_content: Legend is a straight, soft and easy going fragrance. A fruity fragrance with nuances of lavender and floral notes at the base. The fruity patch reminds me Aventus a bit. But not that translucent, Legend is dust-covered a little. You may not get enough compliment, buy you never gain any negative neither. It's a safe fragrance you can wear everywhere. But don't try to expose...

I have to admit that I like this brand but I don't like to judge a book by its cover. Unfortunately here I can't see any legend or a hero. Legendary are the ink pens of this brand,but this send...I had higher expectations from him.It's a common fresh-citrus blend,rather synthetic and linear without own character or some clear notes.There are many intresting notes but the blend is not very well balanced and induce confusion in my nose.Performance is also average.To be fair,I will add that I had tested him many years ago and I admit that I liked him more.But now?May be a reformulation?
As I also tested twice a few days ago the Legend Intense,my opinion is that there is a big similarity between these scents but Legend Intense is more enjoyable,better balanced with nice drydown and better performance.So try before you order.

Yeah I feel like this is a very generic drug store scent, because it is.

It's also very sweet and can get cloying. Sometimes I get a Jean Paul Gaultier Le Male Elixir vibe because of that sweet mintiness. I very much prefer the latter though.

Other than that, this scent lacks character and uniqueness. It smells like a combination of many other popular designer male colognes.

I can strongly advise you to get other offerings like Allure Homme Sport because this is just too mainstream.

I received this cologne as a gift. At first, while I was unwrapping the present, I saw the Montblanc Logo and I was like “Please, be Explorer for God’s Sake”. But it wasn’t.
As for the fragrance, It’s average for me. Average doesn’t translate into bad by any means.
I gave it a few tries and got a compliment like “you smell so fresh today”. But I am not the guy that wears anything for compliments, I would rather wear something that will get me no compliments but give me a good feeling while wearing it. (Something to give me confidence or to put me insantly in a good mood).
It’s not an expensive cologne.
I see it as a grown & mature man’ s fragrance.
30+ And up. It smells very fresh and manly just like and old aftershave would smell.
It can be a great fragrance for the right person. I mean you can’t go wrong with it as a gift for your father or your uncle.
Performance? 4-6 hours for me on the skin with moderate projection in the first hour and much more on the clothes. I mean you can leave your coat in the hanger when you arrive at the office and after the work day when you’ll put your coat on again you can still feel some of the frag going on but way more lightly. Conclusion : Average but still good for the right person.

Overall rating : 6.5 /10

This fragrance is a mystery for me.
When I was younger, I had this same exact perfume, and it smelled okay, kind of deodorant-ish, but it was usable, and it lasted for a reasonable amount of time on my skin.
I recently found a closed bottle of Montblanc Legend at my dad's house, stored perfectly, and it has little to no smell and the longevity is null. To test if it wasn't just out of date, I went to a perfume shop, to test it out. The results were the same. Little to no smell and bad longevity.
Safe to say, once, or even if this bottle ends, I will not buy Montblanc Legend again.
I'd much more recommend Montblanc Legend Blue to whoever wants to buy this, because it has a very similar smell, while projecting it more.

It has a similar profile to Vision by Ajmal. It’s fresh citrus with tops of bergamot and a hint of lavender. The heart cannot be defined as the tops take complete control but it’s supposed to be composed of jasmine. The base is make up of Tonia bean and sandalwood - which I really like. All in all it’s a fresh masculine scent that can be worn at work and in the evening.

review_title: 'I hope you're well insured, baby - with the dent you just made in my pants!'
review_content:
I recently heard a young gentleman (heavily tattooed, lots of gel, rhinestones on a shirt that was a bit too tight) say to a young lady (not quite as heavily tattooed, gel nails, rhinestones on a pair of jeans that were clearly too tight) while riding the subway. Two stops later, he had her number (on the other hand, probably: who doesn’t?), and they got off together - the friend she was actually with, annoyed, two steps behind. And I felt like someone who had just watched meerkats mating at the zoo - or something else with a fully archaic fascination, where you can’t look away or look anywhere else.

I then imagined how that young gentleman got ready at home half an hour earlier (after first going to Media Markt and then 'working out' and afterwards having a 'hardcore battle' with a buddy in front of the Xbox or a similar device). First, a delicious protein shake, then a shower, then sixteen sprays of Legend on his tattooed chest and into the tight rhinestone shirt. Suck in the belly, phone, cigarettes, wallet - another four sprays of Legend (you can hardly smell anything anymore) - daring killer wink, gun gestures with both hands towards the reflection - yeah, tonight’s going to be something!

He is a loud fragrance, Montblanc's Legend, confidently strutting with its exuberant-juvenile sexiness. A fun scent meant to impress others and signal vitality - and availability. It does this with the full force of citrus and oak moss (or something very similar) and a lowered metallic component in its top note, which has to achieve everything that Legend is supposed to achieve on its own, as the heart and base notes noticeably drop in performance. In its character shamelessly reminiscent of Abercrombie & Fitch's Fierce, it is transparent and little surprising - but it apparently works...

Conclusion: I would have liked to believe that after the insurance dent line, nothing more could come. But: 'Nice legs - when did they open?'

review_title: It's gonna be legen... wait for it...
review_content:
I must admit Montblanc Legend is - the longer I engage with it - more interesting than I initially thought. Montblanc Legend is a "Fierce" scent, a copy of Abercrombie's "Fierce".
Many years ago, a Dior representative stood in the Kurfürstenparfümerie, it must have been around 2011 or 2012, a time when I still had a great love for Creed's "Green Irish Tweed" and "Cool Water" (and the love for Cool Water is back). He said that "Fierce" by Abercrombie was now the "new generation" of these fragrances, a statement I only understand today as I smell Montblanc's Legend.
First: I have actually never smelled "Fierce" by Abercrombie, but I am sure I know what to expect; there are many fragrances that can be compared to it:
Montblanc Legend, Le Beau Male by Jean Paul Gaultier, Dior Homme Eau for Men, even the Axe Apollo body spray and shower gel, all these scents have a certain opening that I would describe as a "deodorant spray" accord.
If you take a closer sniff of Legend a few minutes later, you can smell an element that somehow reminds you of black ink, quite exactly like the black ink you can buy from Montblanc for their fountain pens. And if you take another closer sniff, you can smell "Cool Water quotes". However, Montblanc Legend does not turn out to be as fresh and aquatic as Cool Water, but rather a bit sweeter. If you leave Montblanc Legend on your skin longer or let it sit on a paper strip overnight, you can also smell Ambroxan here (for reference, think of "Molecule 02" by Escentric Molecules). Ambroxan at a very pleasant level, which was later turned up much louder in Dior's "Sauvage".

Legend is therefore indeed an interesting scent for me, as you can somewhat trace the development of the "Fougere" genre over the last 30 years:
In the beginning, there was Cool Water / Green Irish Tweed, then came Fierce / Montblanc Legend, followed by scents like Bleu de Chanel and Sauvage by Dior. And Aventus by Creed moves somewhere in between, between a very classic base like that found in Cool Water, but moving away from the aquatic to the smoky-leathery.
All these fragrances are very successful in their own right, and for each of these scents, there are several accounts that they are very well received by women.

I must conclude by saying that Montblanc Legend is nothing special to me in terms of perfume as art, but the craftsmanship, the composition behind this scent is indeed very solid, and the quality you get for the twenty bucks you have to shell out online is truly excellent.
What I have also dared to do with this scent is: layering with Dior Homme. When you layer Dior Homme and Montblanc Legend, you end up quite close to Dior Homme Eau for Men, but somehow better.

...dary.

After the statement and comment reply, I must still break a lance for the legend. Because although the fragrance establishment accuses it of having a shower gel synthetic quality and it fails to shine in any evaluation category, I find it truly successful as a representative of its fragrance direction.
After experiencing the Fierce DNA for the first time in 2002 at a Kohl's supermarket in Denver - back then as parfum-averse as a cold sock - I have been searching for a summer scent that plays this tune for quite a while. Initially, because I wasn't willing to spend so much money on a fragrance in the USA, and back in the old world, because it was hardly available here.
A decade later, I stumbled upon it at Müller: a black, heavy bottle with a small but well-dispersing sprayer and a plastic cap with a satisfying click. Still no ambitions in the hobby that would catch up with me nearly a decade later, just tried it out, but immediately recognized: this other, NOT shower gel-like fruitiness (my shower gel was called Cliff), this NOT aquatic warmth, this, at least initially NOT sweet seductiveness (I'm open to suitable, existing synonyms), that was Fierce! How cheeky! Clearly the same scent! NOT! Because what Legend lacked was the performance, the endurance, the projection, the presence. Regardless, I bought it anyway, and I was happy, as I finally had my perfume. And believe me, among non-perfume junkies, it is well received and has enormous recognition value.
As I said, a few years later PARFUMO came along, and alongside many new experiences, an original bottle of Fierce arrived at my home. Directly from relatives in the USA, as one fears counterfeits. But what was that? Top note: Check. But Legend still holds its own here. Fierce: Fruitier, broader, even a bit orangey (?). Legend: The slim pineapple suits it well, makes it cooler, declutters the DNA, and gives it more freshness, although Legend appears more restrained but also more mature than Fierce. Heart note: Check. Legend and Fierce are equal here in my opinion. In the base, Legend becomes warmer and more conciliatory with the tonka, but remains fresh and summer-appropriate due to its metallic, almost pencil-like foundation, whereas Fierce doesn't develop much but simply fades away. BUT. In the reformulation (black cap), Fierce is nowhere near as long-lasting as it used to be. It doesn't even play in the same league anymore, perhaps because the dosage of oak moss has fallen victim to newer regulations?
Be that as it may, Legend is just as enduring, but at the same time lighter and more multifaceted, although it does indeed come off as a bit more synthetic.
So I sold Fierce again, and now I've sprayed down Legend to 10ml.
But the fragrance journey is not over yet. The DNA fascinates me so much, and apart from Aventus (and Fierce 2002), no summer scent has really blown me away so far.
Thus, the search for Legend (Fierce?) alternatives began: Platinum Egoiste? Too much suit, too little summer-appropriate. Tous Man Intense? Affordable and longer-lasting, but even heavier than Egoiste (and even more orangey than Fierce). Just Cavalli Him? I like it, nice de-fruity top note (paprika), but it doesn't last. Legend Intense? See Tous Man. 701 from the notorious German fragrance copier? Like all the fragrances offered there, only 128 mBit (you know what I mean).
Aside from Legend, only Police with To be - the Illusionist has provided me with a worthy alternative so far. However, that one is too close to the reformulated Fierce, and thus I can give it an unrestricted purchase recommendation for its target audience.
That leaves me with the Aviator from Paris Bleu, but I don't have high hopes (and at the moment, it seems that, although inexpensive, it's not so easy to obtain).
Therefore: Legend does what it does definitely right. It enriches the Fierce DNA in a more mature direction, making it office-appropriate and not easily replaceable for me as an over-40 year-round fragrance.
So the search goes on, as so often...

review_title: Not a legend but a solid everyday scent
review_content:
Montblanc's Legend has been in my collection for 1-2 years. It started with Individuel and several fragrances from this brand followed, with a few still on my wishlist. The price-performance ratio of this brand is simply more than fair. Especially since these affordable fragrances all come with good performance. This one too.

The Montblanc Legend Intense performs significantly better than this one. I haven't tested the Intense version yet, but if it's a similar scent with better performance, the high ratings are justified. Since it really is just a nice alternative for everyday wear, I don't necessarily need to test it.
Legend is clearly a Fierce double. Right after spraying, the Fierce DNA hits you. For me, however, it's not a direct copy, but it definitely has its own character.
Fierce has also been in my collection for many years. I bought it blind for a lot of money back then. After all the praise for this scent, I was slightly disappointed. Especially for the high price. Even though Fierce is very crowd-pleasing, it's not particularly special to me. This Legend is also not the super scent that I'm mega excited about, but it serves its purpose: an affordable everyday fragrance that could also appeal to many women thanks to the Fierce DNA. There are still some differences from Fierce. While Fierce is a smooth scent without many edges, I find this one to be much more robust and masculine. The herb-fruity pineapple comes through very well here. A bit of tonka bean also adds a slight sweetness, although this scent is rather herb-fresh. The synthetics that some have negatively commented on are, in my opinion, quite limited. Definitely not significantly more than with Fierce.
For me, it's a great year-round scent with decent performance at a fair price. It lasts for several hours with decent sillage. Top.
It beats the outrageously overpriced Fierce with its poor price-performance ratio and inadequate performance. However, it might be better to test the Intense version, which is really well-received here.

It’s like a dream.
There’s this scent on me.
A mild, serious, yet elegant fragrance.
I’m sitting in an office. An extremely upscale office. Men in suits with Boss ties and women in suits with Hermès silk scarves flank a huge black conference table.
Leather briefcases with a glacier logo on the clasp sit next to the chairs. A clattering and tapping sound emerges as agendas and conference folders are pulled out. All with glacier logos on the closure clips.
The boss pulls out his ballpoint pen. Black with silver fittings. And a white glacier logo on the cap. Meanwhile, the refills of Starwalkers glide over the augmented papers.
Am I trapped in a Montblanc ecosystem?, is my thought.
My last thought, until a shrill ringing at the door jolts me out of my daydream.
Here I am now. At work. But not in a consulting firm, let alone at a teak wood table.
And as I get up to open the door for the next appointment, rubbing the sleep from my eyes, I catch a whiff of a fragrance on my wrist.
Montblanc Legend. So that’s where all these associations in my daydream come from.

Montblanc Legend is a fragrance that perfectly fits into the Montblanc ecosystem character-wise. A business scent par excellence. For anyone already familiar with the Montblanc brand, it’s a must-buy. Regardless of whether you encounter Boss ties or Hermès silk scarves in the halls of your company.

Fierce by Abercrombie & Fitch is a scent that I actually find quite okay. It sneaks into my nose whenever I walk past their flagship store in Düsseldorf and the perfume cloud blown out from it wafts towards me. At least I can appreciate it, and if I were a few decent years younger, it might find its way into my collection.

However, I see very little resemblance to Legend by Montblanc. On the contrary: while Fierce can still show a certain finesse, Legend is rather boring for me, including disappointingly harsh synthetic notes in the truest sense of the word.

The pineapple is a shy joke without a punchline, and the rest is more readable from the pyramid than something you can seriously filter out olfactorily. The only thing that seems natural here is the reflex to immediately think of shower gel. This doesn’t necessarily have to be a flaw, but here it comes off as neither high-quality nor creative, but rather something that has been sniffed a thousand times.

At least the puristic bottle with its elegantly adorned cap stands out positively here. While it’s not legendary yet, it’s a successful approach that couldn’t be continued in terms of content.

The scent is very similar to the Hollister fragrance from those stores, so it should be familiar to most people. I can rate the longevity and sillage as really good. After 3 sprays on the skin, the scent still fills the room for a solid 6 hours.
All in all, a good recommendation.

I find Legend to be a very, very pleasant all-round fragrance, suitable for casual outfits and any occasion. I won't go into the individual nuances, the scent progression, or longevity, as all of that has already been extensively covered in other statements about this fragrance creation.
Personally, there are certainly many other, more appealing scents for me,
but, ........ there must be something very special in the ingredient composition
of Legend that seems to resonate more with others than with me.
The fact is, with no other fragrance have I received compliments from the (female) environment as frequently and positively as with the scent experience of Legend. I find that unfortunate, as I usually wear fragrances for myself and not for others.

If I am suggesting this fragrance, then it is only right to test and evaluate it:

Montblanc's new men's fragrance "Legend" seems to be so new and rare that even the company's own website does not list it!

In general, the search for scents from the venerable, 1906-established manufactory based in Hamburg is somewhat difficult - on one hand, many fragrance shops only have a handful of Montblanc perfumes on their shelves or have banished them entirely from their assortment.

The turquoise giant probably wanted to fill this gap and has seemingly reintroduced the majority of the fragrance line (again) into its program, adorned with the title "New" - yet "Starwalker" is 6 years old and "Présence Homme" is even 10 years old! The last men's fragrance "Homme Exceptionnel," which has not crossed my path until now, was launched in 2008.

I was able to sniff the "New" for the first time in Venice, after I had not been able to find it in Germany until then. Even the Montblanc store in Salzburg did not carry it, nor its siblings at all.

The bottle presents itself, contrary to all glass clarity, mysterious and dark - yet noble and timelessly elegant!
The in-house design team designed and developed the fragrance container, which, with its deep black glass, resembles an elegant fountain pen with a glossy finish.

With the embossed, relief-like, iconic trademark, the star, the bottle emphasizes its family affiliation and is a tribute to the legendary masterpiece "149."
Rarely has a bottle been designed so personally and brand-specifically.
This can also be seen as a noble flask.

As grand as the bottle is, the initial perception of the fragrance is rather strange, which falls into the "Fougére" group:

It starts with a rather synthetic, citrus-like opening note for me.
I cannot recognize lavender here, and pineapple is only to be guessed.

This rather harsh entry feels fresh and green - I associate this scent with a fresh shave and a refreshing aftershave.

For me, the further development of the fragrance is very linear and does not make any big leaps.
Typical wood accents join in and form a solid conclusion.
Everything feels very calm and well-coordinated.

Longevity is average at 5 hours, mediocre.

For me, "Legend" does not represent a fragrance revolution, but offers an interesting, yet not necessarily essential alternative in the current mainstream fragrance cosmos.

For the black-and-white campaign shot by Peter Lindbergh, the Brit Simon Clark was chosen. He embodies the perfect male type and showcases the elegance that Legend is supposed to exude with his turtleneck sweater and strong hair blowing in the wind…

review_title: For me rather fresh, spicy, and herbal
review_content:
I first owned Montblanc Legend Spirit and think it's great (a mix of Invictus Aqua). Now I also have Montblanc Legend here. Many say it is a fragrance twin of Abercrombie & Fitch's Fierce. I can't judge that, as I unfortunately have never owned or smelled it. However, I can attest that Montblanc Legend has a distinct similarity to Emporio Armani's He/Pour Lui. By the way, I also really like that one.

Legend starts off fresh, slightly citrusy, and somehow herbal due to the lavender. Then woods come in, but it remains fresh and herbal. The rose and tonka bean, in my opinion, are hardly noticeable, if at all. Not even at the end. For me, Legend is an all-rounder, versatile in use. One smells clean, masculine, well-groomed, almost freshly shaved. It has that slight shaving foam and aftershave vibe, but not Eau Sauvage like in your face.

The longevity is a good 4 to 5 hours, the sillage is not overly strong, but one will be noticed in the first 2 to 3 hours. For me, Legend is finally a more potent alternative to my beloved Emporio Armani He/Pour Lui, whose longevity and sillage are a complete disaster. Fruity, as mentioned above, it is not for me, but rather fine, spicy, fresh, and herbal. Wearable in any season, for any occasion.

After Dylan Blue, I must advocate for another popular fragrance that receives quite a bit of hate from niche wearers who find it reminiscent of fecal oud, yet is perceived as very pleasant by 98% of the population.

The DNA is the same as Fierce or Percival, making it a younger version of Chanel's Platinum Égoïste and, in my opinion, a timeless classic.

When there was an Abercrombie & Fitch in every major shopping mall, where this fragrance was sprayed, it was probably smelled a bit too often.

Nowadays, it represents for me the archetype of a young, masculine cologne or barbershop/fougère scent.

It intrigues women in their 20s and evokes nostalgia in women in their 30s. Either way, compliments are guaranteed.

...I would like to break here. I agree with my predecessors: MBL smells quite similar to Fierce by A&F. I like MBL! From my perspective, even though it belongs to the - let's say - "Fierce" category, it still has its own scent. It is darker and lasts at least an hour longer on my skin than its older brother in the fragrance Fierce. For the sake of honesty, I should also...

Montblanc, or Montblanc International GmbH, is one of the leading manufacturers of high-quality writing instruments, watches, jewelry, and leather goods. Well... and now also in the field of fragrances. Montblanc has a name, and the price-performance ratio is more than good. The scent is really well received by women and is, for me, a must-have among fragrances, due to the price and the good image. This fragrance can be worn anytime, whether at the office, on a first date, or for a night out at the club.

...yes, that’s what I first thought of with this scent :-)
I mainly smell plum and pineapple mixed with a hint of
Diors Fahrenheit. Sounds strange, but that’s how it is for me.
I find the scent better day by day. One should take some time
for Legend, as it is different from fragrances one usually knows..
But no other fragrance boosts confidence like Legend. I have no
idea why that is, especially since in my opinion there are far "better" scents.
But that’s just how it is for me. With Legend, I feel good :-))

I can’t say anything about the comparison with Fierce, as I don’t know it and
would never have thought of bringing such a juvenile (sorry)
bottle into my home :-D

Bottle: Really great! Heavy glass + metal cap
Longevity: 8h +
Sillage: Not room-filling, but okay...

Let's get ready to rumble...

Rarely have I smelled such a blatant knockoff - it smells exactly like the almost 10-year older, infamous Fierce by A&F.

The bottle is dull, the idea of copying a good fragrance is too, the sillage and longevity are quite strong, just like Fierce.
The scent is still top-notch, very fresh, fruity & quite synthetic, but this is nothing more than a cheaper alternative.

It's a pity, Mont Blanc can definitely do better, as their masterpiece Individuel proves. There, they were famously inspired by Creed's Original Santal, whether intentionally or not is actually irrelevant, they copied...
Perfumers & luxury brands: don't copy, forge new paths!

review_title: I don't know what to make of this "Legend"
review_content:
Well, I don't know the much-praised "Fierce," and I intend to keep it that way if "Legend" is supposed to be its scent twin. Alleged womanizer or not: I own three wonderful Montblanc fragrances with "Individuel," "Starwalker," and "Présence," all of which have their own character, ranging from fruity to fresh to sweet... Unfortunately, "Legend" makes an exception for me and is - as so often - proof that the cliché "If you know one, you know them all" rarely applies in the world of fragrances.

I find "Legend" quite intrusive, without being able to particularly distinguish any scent note. For me, a synthetic, glaringly fresh fruit overshadows everything else. It may be a pineapple extract, but it could also be anything else. Underneath, subtly greenish and sweet notes shake hands. This endeavor may be well-intentioned, as it somehow seems like a bridge between old and young, classic and trendy, work and leisure... Only, in my eyes, it unfortunately hasn't succeeded.

I simply can't connect anything with "Legend," neither the day at the office nor the cozy corner of the sofa, neither a wild night out nor activities in nature, neither a rainy city day nor the sunny sandy beach on vacation. Nothing really fits this olfactory overall picture for me. Therefore, "Legend" simply represents nothing for me, but costs me nerves with every spray. You can't "make something smell nice" that you don't like. Hence, "Legend" unfortunately remains a directionless and far too shrill scent mush for me.

review_title: Unnecessary Fresh Fragrance with Annoying Synthetic Note
review_content:
Once again, a fresh scent from the annoying "Hugo" category.

The opening is reminiscent of a pineapple cocktail, not really something you can call natural. The pineapple comes across as quite sharp, making it penetrating. Litsea cubeba, an Asian, lemongrass-like essential oil, doesn't improve the situation, rather it adds to the sharpness.

The overall arrangement is annoyingly fresh, synthetic, and overloaded, comparable to "Hugo." Lavender struggles against this lab-like note but barely makes an impact.

Even the mossy heart and base phases are overshadowed by the surprisingly long-lasting annoying tones from the opening. Even after more than an hour, the unpleasantly sharp and piercing artificial pineapple-lemongrass mixture prevails. Friendly is different.

Only the tonka bean takes a bit of the edge off with softer, creamier nuances.

Far from a great success and truly one of the weakest men's fragrances that Montblanc has released so far. Legends look different.

review_title: You can copy it - gladly with a masterpiece
review_content: What drives a luxury brand, which is practically the epitome of beautiful writing instruments, to market such a fragrance under its name? Sorry, but this is legendary boredom: A sweet-citrusy note, incredibly unoriginal, quite artificial, cheap in its impression, and ultimately completely insignificant. I have pens from Montblanc, and with them, every application, every curve in the shape, every detail feels carefully and consistently thought out. Why would such a company then release a fragrance that seems so passionlessly cobbled together? In such cases, the marketing department should actually be up in arms - to prevent the scent of this loveless execution from potentially sticking to the brand name and thus to the other products. Unfortunately, this is not the only example of luxury manufacturers who are completely off the mark olfactorily outside their actual terrain... Jaguar and Porsche Design are also quite good in this race.

The sleek black bottle smiled at me from a familiar retailer. I sprayed it on my arm and immediately found myself enveloped in a fresh, pleasant shower gel note. Simple, nothing special, yet fresh and masculine. Then I saw the price and just like that, I bought it. I only wear it during sports activities or when I feel like having an uncomplicated fresh male sport scent again. I can perceive the fragrance for over 6 hours. For the price, I keep letting it join my perfume collection.

review_title: A Gentleman Who Would Like to Be a Legend
review_content: I bought Mont Blanc Legend because I already own one MB and they often have good fragrances on offer. Unfortunately, I have never found a scent like that again... It's been years... Well, maybe I'll find it again... BUT I'm digressing ;-) The Legend is, for me, a classic gentleman's fragrance. It is masculine, slightly bitter, and in my opinion, it suits an "older" gentleman...

The scent has been with me for a long time. Whether as Abercrombie Fierce or later from Montblanc.
(For simplicity, I consider both fragrances the same here; the nuances don't matter)

After I smelled Legend for the first time at a friend's place, I had to buy it that very day. So much nostalgia for little money. Since then, it has been sitting in the drawer. It feels too young, too "masculine," too Abercrombie, too loaded with memories. Too many associations with awkward teenage years are tied to it. I'm sure many others feel the same way. I don't want to trigger those associations. It would almost be embarrassing for me. Still, I always enjoy smelling it on others. Even if I involuntarily make a bit of fun of it.

A&F Fierce was my only perfume for a long time after its release as a teenager. Compliments poured in, but I remember always feeling a bit out of place with the scent. Even back then, it felt too 'dominantly masculine' for school life. Over 10 years later, with sensory training, more social intelligence, and insight into the world of fragrances, I can confirm that feeling.

But Legend/Fierce is actually a very nice scent. Also for adults. Wearable year-round, more suited for fancier days and outfits, with the leather jacket. Women* love it.

I just can't get my 15-year-old self out of my head.

Before I get to my comment, I must say that I am completely new to the perfume junkies and what does one look for at 18 years old? Of course! A ladykiller scent that you don’t smell on every street corner like our well-known 1 Million or Le Male.

After weeks of research for a seductive fragrance that would linger in the minds of women, I concluded to buy A&F's Fierce. Since this scent is unfortunately not available in any Douglas, I continued my search and lo and behold - I found its twin.

According to the comments, my expectations were set very high since Fierce is such a popular fragrance and this one is said to have a very strong resemblance.

So I made my way to the nearest Douglas. I tried to evaluate the scent as objectively as possible and didn’t think about the bottle or the copy of Fierce; I just wanted to know how it smells. I gave Legend 30 minutes to develop and took my first sniff of my strip. Well, what can I say? To be honest, I am disappointed. It’s not a bad scent, but also not one that really blows you away, and with 70% I think I’m still being quite generous. You can smell a woody note that doesn’t make the fragrance feel very feminine. Then there’s a bit of citrus and a hint of a spice stand - that’s it.
Nothing bad, but nothing special. I finally got confirmation from 4 colleagues, including 2 girls who felt the same way I did.

I can only hope that the highly praised Fierce actually has some scent, otherwise I’ll stick with my Sculpture, which has been loyal to me for months and has never let me down in any situation.

...because to be honest, I didn't expect much. Of course, this is not a fragrance of the century or a true replacement for my still greatly missed Eau pour homme by Armani in its original form. But... for me, it is the more mature version of Fierce. I can't really describe why, but I find it even less synthetic than the scent from A&F. Actually, I tend to prefer...

I often remember my first encounter with Fierce COLOGNE during a visit to the store in Paris. Back then, I was still a bit too young for fragrances, but the scent always lingered in my mind, although I never bought it. A few years later, I was frustrated to find during a visit to a perfume shop that the scent simply no longer had its old power and...

Montblanc Legend is referred to as a fragrance twin of Fierce by A&F and PdM Percival. Unfortunately, I never had Fierce. However, I can draw a comparison to Percival by PdM. I have Percival in my collection and really like the scent. When I learned that Legend is supposed to be a fragrance twin, the prospect of a budget-friendly everyday alternative drove me to bid on a...

review_title: My Favorite Scent - for about 5 years.
review_content:
For me, nothing really comes close to this authentic freshness with depth.

Montblanc strikes the right balance here between "clean" aka laundry/fabric softener and citrusy freshness with masculine sandalwood as the foundation.

In the first few years, I was simply blown away; I always felt completely empowered and confident, yet at the same time unique and special. I get almost sentimental when I think of all the travels and experiences where this scent accompanied me.

At some point, you just want something new, but I have absolutely nothing to criticize about this fragrance. The longevity is very good, and even on long nights, my shirt still smelled "legendary" when going to bed. A little bit more complexity might have brought me to 7 years of favorite scent, but otherwise, everything is perfect.
The bottle is also of high quality; I really like the design of a flask, silver and black fit the "legend theme," and it has fallen a few times, with only a small dent appearing after years. The spray also works great.

So all in all, one of my best recommendations. If you want something fresh but not standard - go for it!

I really like the scent. That's why I also see a lot of similarity to Percival - just in a designer style and not as intense.

You can find differences in my review of Percival.

Regarding "Legend": fresh, green, spicy, masculine.
Contrary to what some say here, this scent is absolutely not for teenagers. It's a very masculine fragrance. It has to suit a mature man.

For me, it's an allrounder. It works anytime. Also perfectly fine for everyday use.
Longevity is good. On some days, I can still smell it after 10 hours. But that's not always the case.

Despite everything - great spicy fresh scent. Not a fragrance bomb, but it doesn't always have to be that way.

This is a hot mess! The notes don't indicate the depths of harshness, synthetic over-the-top bitter sweetness and redundancy in this fragrance. "Hello" Axe body spray called and they want their formula back!". My husband got bored in ULTA Beauty while I was enjoying shopping for body scrubs, lotions and potions. Like a skunk spray...I didn't notice the smell until I got back in the car. I had been sampling Fahrenheit and reminiscing on the rich petroleum nutmeg, lavender leather and decadent carnation honeysuckle and Tonka notes and then I smelled what he was wearing. Windows down all the way home in spite of it being 20 degrees Fahrenheit. It was like a slap in the face. Although this fragrance has massive sillage and machismo, it is just a big pineapple express with an unruly funky sticky Tonka syrup note. Loud and linear and just unrefined migraine-inducing chemicals. I would typically expect more from the Montblanc name, but I guess times are hard.

Fruity, synthetic pineapple, artificially zesty lemon, spicy herbal lavender. Throughout the entire scent development, there is a pencil-like, metallic Iso-E-Super note that reminds one of Chanel's Platinum Égoïste. Oakmoss is, of course, also essential. In the heart, the sweet, sticky tea-like fierce note and in the drydown, woody + creamy tonka bean. Voilà! Here comes the bitter-fresh Fierce Pepsi.

I like this synthetic, metallic-seeming, sexy, smooth Confidence Booster, and based on the female reactions, the DNA is still very well received, making it one of the most attractive fragrances in its price range!

Now, let's address the major negative point: the sillage. After 30 minutes, it drops steeply, with a maximum of 45 minutes of effectiveness, which is unfortunately a complete failure. Either you have to constantly reapply it or you just spray it consistently on your clothes. The longevity on the skin, however, can be extended by the number of sprays. In direct comparison to the fruity woodruff Abercrombie Softie, the Legend, fitting its main target group, comes off as the more masculine bad boy.

review_title: Good for me, Great for them!
review_content: When I first sprayed I'm like "ok, it's Allright". It's not like wow, amazing. It smells good though. It's got fruity apple with a woody base. The ladies though, I can tell they like it and i got a compliment first time wearing it. Plus I can tell when women and people get into my space to get a better whiff. This is a great and cool add on to my collection.

As a connoisseur of this line, I can start by saying that between the EDT and the EDP, the latter is clearly ahead. Even compared to the Emblem, another one I've had, the Legend EDP turns out to stand out.

Pleasant and fresh smell, right on top. The bergamot stands out in an initial phase, but minutes later comes the scent of very smooth leather, with a light but elegant touch of cedar. It doesn't smell like animal leather, far from it, it's almost aromatic. Even the notes of wood are very delicate.

During one day (around 12:00, assuming I applied it the first time before leaving for work at 8:00 am), I had to reapply once more during the afternoon (around 3:00 pm) because at lunch time neither I nor anyone else felt the fragrance (it was close to the skin). But that doesn't surprise me, even though it's an EDP (still way better than EDT).

The projection is reasonable, but if we consider the fact that it is an EDP it leaves something to be desired (in the first hour it's good, but then it's just close to the skin).

review_title: Easy reach, great fragrance for men
review_content: Legend is a really nice, generic masculine fragrance that pretty much any guy would like and most people would like smelling on a man. Easy go-to grab for any time of the year, day or night, and for any occasion. Legend doesn't make a statement but that's what makes it so versatile. True EDP performance that doesn't disappoint. Very reasonably priced. Tested from a sample and have a full bottle on order for myself.

review_title: Fierce Abercrombie & Fitch DNA with slightly better performance
review_content:
If you are a fan of the legendary Fierce Abercrombie & Fitch fragrance, this version of Legend Eau de Parfum Montblanc is the closest to it, with somewhat better performance.
Same DNA but the fierce scent is better in terms of purity.
A masculine fragrance that is attractive to women and suitable for moderate and spring weather.
The fragrance bottle is elegant as usual in the Legend series.

review_title: Just got it on clearance/ Better than the OG
review_content:
This stuff is a deeper version of the OG. I like the OG as it smells similar to Curve for Men but performs better. It's loud for about 3 hours, then calms down a little. But it lasts a whole day. I smelled it in the morning before taking a shower.
It's still fresh and woody, while it goes deeper into the woody and aromatic side, but still airy with that violet leaf note. Less bright than the original.
Honestly though, this is an excellent buy for the $36 I spent for it.

I don't think blind buying anything is a good idea and always recommend sampling. But if you absolutely have to blind buy because of an urgent gift or whatever, this would be a good call due to its reasonable price, mass appeal, and versatility This is primarily a wood-scented fragrance, but with moss and some ozonic violet leaf notes on top so it has a fresh/clean aspect to...

Performance: On skin that isn't making contact with clothes or surfaces, you can still get recognizable whiffs after 7-8 hours, but you have to get right up close. Generally, I get 6 hours out of this, with the first hour having a medium to slightly more than medium projection, and then it's a closer bubble for another 2 hours, and then a skin scent for the remaining 3 hours. Surprisingly, not much longer performance on clothes.

Scent: Overall, this smells like shaving cream with a bit more astringency from the oakmoss and leather notes. In the opening it really smells like shaving cream. That specific combo of fresh and ozonic, but with a just a bit of bite hearkens back to barber shop smells, but updated for the 2020s. I don't really get a magnolia note. There might be floral notes, but I have a hard time singling them out. The woody note is also hard to identify because different wood notes smell so different. I'm not sure what "generic woods" smells like. Most of what I get is the combo of violet leaf and oakmoss. Many contemporary fragrances don't usually have such a recognizable oakmoss note because of IFRA, but it's definitely recognizable here. As for the leather note, again, hard for me to single out, but I think it becomes much more noticeable after a few hours of drydown. Sometimes oakmoss and leather notes can have similar effects, so hard to tell if this is just the character of the oakmoss changing and the leather isn't overly noticeable, or if the leather is noticeable. The opening is brighter than the drydown, but by and large the drydown smells quite similar to the opening. It opens as a brighter, clean shaving cream, and dries down as a less bright after shave balm-type scent.

Bottle: It's a good bottle. The top black piece is plastic, which is a bit disappointing given the nice heavy metal-over-plastic cap. I kind of don't like that I can't see how much liquid is left, but I respect the blackout aesthetic. Sprayer is very respectable, and the bottle is easy to hold.

review_title: Sometimes it just has to be simple...
review_content: In this review, I want to keep it shorter than usual. Why? Because simple things shouldn't be artificially dissected, chewed over, and interpreted in various ways like we did in German class. "Montblanc Legend EDP" is a so-called "shower gel scent." "Shower gel scent" - just reading that makes me cringe. Honestly, I'm fed up with it. What gets dismissed as "boring...

review_title: Out of the Shower? We Love It!
review_content:
This Legend EAU DE PARFUM . What a powerhouse.

It's so good that it's almost ridiculous.
It's so good that it's simply my wife's favorite fragrance.
It's so good, so simple, so clean - so linear. Delicious, fresh, spicy, masculine.
I use this stuff in every situation - and for various occasions.
When meeting friends. In the office.

And just now, I'm putting on a sweater that hung in my office wardrobe for about two weeks. And the scent is still in there. And so perceptible. This has happened to me once before with the perfume. And I wondered why I hadn't already typed out a review like this to give voice to my enthusiasm, making your mouths water so much that you can't help but create a demand in your mind that screams for the scent! I want percentages! :D

And I'm always - always fresh with it. No matter where.
We often go camping with the rooftop tent, and those of us who know camping sites and bad weather know how good it feels when you come out of the shower in the morning, which is simply a blessing compared to the rough weather and the adversities that you encounter outside much more than in a warm hotel room.

And then you put on the scent and are instantly wrapped in a feel-good cloak of lasting freshness like shower gel and ready for anything! It sounds cheesy, but that's exactly how ridiculously simple the story is. No poetic influence. I love this perfume and will stock up on it royally in the hope that it will never be discontinued.

He actually appealed to me during testing after I had been walking around the perfume store for some time and had tested a few.

Fresh, powdery, and simply clean and straightforward. You can't say much more about it... actually.
Well, I got it because I wanted a clean and freshly showered scent. But the title is there for a reason. To me, it smells like a man who has just showered and put on his suit.
Unfortunately, maybe it's due to my skin type, it doesn't project as I had hoped. I need 8-10 sprays for it to be noticeable, and unfortunately, it fades quickly.

The bottle is very simple and comes from the Legend line, except that it is lined in black on the inside and has a very masculine and chic appearance due to the overall black design.
But unfortunately, it will remain the first bottle of the Legend EDP in my collection.

I originally got this fragrance because it is considered a budget-friendly alternative to Parfums de Marley - Percival. And yeah. That's somewhat true. That I wouldn't shell out hundreds of euros for the former is obvious to me. After all, it's "just" a fresh, shower gel-like everyday scent, heavily inspired by the legendary A&F Fierce. So really nothing that reinvents the wheel. Still, it just smells good. So if you're looking for an alternative, you quickly find Montblanc. It smells very similar, although a bit spicier and unfortunately also a bit more synthetic.
Longevity and sillage are also not comparable in any way.
Nevertheless, considering the price difference - which is really enormous - one has to ask:
Is it worth it? In my eyes, clearly no. Montblanc Legend serves its purpose as a Fierce substitute almost better, even if it can't reach the quality of the luxury knight.

Montblanc, if you read this .. you must get your thoughts together, the market is flooded enough with uninspired creations like The Phantom - Paco Rabanne, K from D&G or Y from YSL. We know you have the money and the talent to come with awesome products like The Individuel, Signature or Explorer!

Why bring this brand to insignificance with perfumes nobody want and making them more expensive with each launch?

Like many of you, I like when a perfume house offers value for money and for many years I was under the impression that Montblanc, licensed by Inter Parfums (Sisley, Ferragamo, Van Cleef & My Origines, etc) should have mindful investments.

Since the Explorer for Men and Signature for Ladies, Montblanc only launched flops:
- Explorer Ultra Blue (6.5),
- Legend Red (6.5) and
- Signature Absolute (7.2) which my wife likes but flies away in 2 hours.

When I saw the bottle design and the IFF Perfumer Bruno Jovanovic (Rose Incense, Bad Boy Le Parfum and Fierce from A&F) behind this creation, I had high hopes and was so curious to try it.

It starts with a strong stale smell of clary sage (similar cold mettalic one like in the H24) and nothing much else, the violet petrol like smell is very weak and some synthetic cedarwood is also barely there. And it develops into a dry sweaty gym bag after a few minutes, I had to use vegetable oil and soap and scrub this from my skin like my life depended on it.

There is absolutely nothing to like about this scent and it seems like it was launched without a clear mission in mind and why was also Natalie Lorson (Bentley Intense for Men, Lalique Encre Noir Extreme and Gentleman Givenchy Réserve Privée) needed for this?

We, Parfumos and perfume lovers, should VOTE with our money and not encourage anymore the perfume houses to launch soulless creations like these and still buy them anyway.

The opening of Explorer Platinum gave me a creamy vibe with a subtle sweet coconut scent. At that point, would have classified it as unisex. As it settled and the wood scent became more prominent, changed my mind - it is definitely a masculine fragrance. Around the 30 minute mark, it really became nice with a wood note making it sharper, less creamy. Longevity is very good with decent projection - around arms length and gradually diminishing to around the 4-5 hour mark when it's down to a skin scent.

I can see it as an easy reach for everyday for a guy wanting a straightforward, pleasant scent, not trying to make a statement. Could work anytime of the year, day or night, most all situations.

I was eager to test it after the first promising opinions right after the premiere, which led to growing expectations that in such a weak year as 2023, some nice, masculine premiere would finally be released. And what happened? Well, that's a bummer because Explorer Platinum is unfortunately a very average, generic scent, there is absolutely nothing interesting about it. Secondary, repeating patterns that have been used dozens of times in recent years.
The scent is simple, fresh, cedar, a bit metallic, slightly herbal, smelling like a lot of other blue perfumes with a hint of fougere. There is a note here that is already well known from Sauvage and similar products, but in any case it is an average, common scent.
The parameters are good, although the projection is low, the bottle is impressive, but what's the point if there's just something inside. Versatility may be a plus, but Explorer Platinum is so colorless that it's only suitable for a quick trip to the store or to the gym.

review_title: Montblanc Explorer Platinum - An Intriguing Scent
review_content:
The first time I tried it was on a tester strip in a mall. I was immediately surprised by the scent and although I did not try it on skin at that time I knew it was something that I was eventually going to get.

In terms of scent, Explorer Platinum is masculine, lightly sweet, herbal-camphorous and woody. It does share something in common with the Original Explorer and that is the Akigaliwood/Suede component. Therefore, the far dry down can be felt as synthetic due to these notes, as it was also the case with the original one. You will go nose blind on this, but not as much as with the original; I also perceive it as having more depth than the first one and not being as minimalist.
It is a creamy or buttery scent but I personally don't get any coconut, which is a good thing because I am not really a fain of it in perfumes. This is not a safe blind buy as I can see how some people might perceive the greenness which is present here as dill or even parsley! I was lucky to see their commercial months before I purchased it and because of that this one inspires to me winter, forests and snow.

In terms of performance, I got 7-8 hours on my skin but if you spray on clothes is will surely last even more. During the first hour it will be quite loud, like most of them are and then it will settle down to 1 feet for most of its life duration.

I find it very relaxing and enjoyable, definitely an office scent but can also be worn casually, of course. The scent goes into a direction of sophistication and elegance to some degree and, although you don't need to suit up for it, you can't use it with any kind of random outfit.

This is not unisex, this is for men and I think it's a solid release, to which I am going to rate as an 8/10.

You are walking through a forest by a stream on a cool spring morning. It rained last night. The plants are big and growing rapidly. You dip your bare feet in the stream. It's cold, but it's refreshing. Suddenly the wind picks up and it feels as though the forest speaks to you. You can feel every leaf, and the power each one carries.

Everything is green in this forest. The floor is lush with grass. The wood has a green hue. The light passes through the thick canopy.

You are nature.

This fragrance is an absolute surprise!

It has nothing in common with the usual Explorer.

In terms of longevity, Explorer Platinum is relatively linear, which is wonderful, as the scent remains almost the same throughout its lifespan.

After application, one can immediately perceive a kind of coniferous freshness, rounded off by a light sweetness in the background from a green violet scent. Shortly thereafter, the top freshness dissipates, and from this point on, the fragrance remains green-warm, dry-woody.

Explorer Platinum is so skillfully composed that the green, leafy sweetness of the violet leaves gives the fragrance a depth, while simultaneously carrying the darker note of sage in the background.
The cedarwood subtly adds a lightly dry, minimal smoky note to the whole composition.

When the fragrance has faded in the evening, a pleasantly sweet sage scent remains on the skin.

Dear community!
Since the fragrance was announced, I have been searching almost daily for a way to get my hands on it. Finally, a few days ago, I found it, and today I finally received it. The black predecessor, Montblanc Explorer, is a very successful fragrance for me, which is why I have very high expectations for the new one. I generally really like the packaging and the design of the bottle from Montblanc. Everything feels very high-quality. But now to the most important part. Removing the heavy cap, I pump it 3 times, and the first fine spray mist settles on my skin. The scent first reminds me of Gentleman Givenchy Eau de Toilette Intense, just not quite as sweet and powdery. Then, for me, the basil comes to the forefront. However, the top note disappears quite quickly, and the fragrance becomes sweet. For me personally, only the woody/sweet and very subtly citrus component remains. Montblanc still needs to work hard on the longevity and sillage. After a few minutes, the scent is only very close to the skin for me. It is possible that it will develop a bit more in warm temperatures.

All in all, I find the fragrance successful.
Best regards from Austria

review_title: A Walk in the Licorice Forest with a Coconut Water Stream Flowing Through It
review_content:
What? Violet leaf, clary sage, cedarwood... This can't be.

When I first smelled the fragrance, I thought more of a Pina Colada or Coconut Kiss that I spilled on my clothes. A little later, something strange happened, as the scent developed into a light, fresh licorice forest fragrance with a coconut water stream flowing through it, and after 2 days, it is still on the polo shirt.

Don't hold me to it, but after 2 days in the drydown, I perceive a mix of Creed's Silver Mountain Water and Virgin Island Water.

Definitely a bold scent that lasts extremely long for a fresh fragrance.

review_title: With the Dog in the Underbrush!
review_content:
Montblanc is probably only considered in passing by many. I felt the same way. Then I came across Explorer Platinum, and although it wasn't love at first sight, I learned to appreciate the quality during the second test.

I spend a lot of time with my dog, and sometimes we end up in the underbrush. Suddenly it struck me… this is the scent of this MontBlanc creation. Very harmonious, green freshness with a hint of sweetness and the somewhat harsher note of cedarwood. This is forest and nature in its perfection. A little fun fact on the side: My dog noticeably comes to sniff around when I wear it.

Unfortunately, the longevity and sillage are weak points of the fragrance. After 4-5 hours, it is only very subtle on the skin. On clothing, it lasts a good hour longer. However, the price is absolutely top-notch, and for those who don’t want to spend too much money on perfume but still want to wear a nice, somewhat unusual scent, Platinum is perfectly equipped.

Conclusion:
Top price/performance ratio and a lovely everyday fragrance for spring and autumn. I just had to have it - says my dog!

There aren't many fragrances that I smell that are relatively outstanding. To get straight to the point, Explorer Platinum is exactly one of those. When thinking of independent scents, one might quickly think of Aventus or BR540. However, in terms of uniqueness and class, Explorer Platinum holds its own against the big names.

Of course, you have to like the DNA, but the fragrance impresses with a wonderful freshness and a woodiness that I have never encountered in this form before. The scent development is relatively linear, and what you smell after 30 minutes is still what you smell after 6 hours. No surprises along the way, but sometimes that's not necessary.

I associate this scent with class and style. I don't envision a teenager in baggy jeans and a baseball cap, but rather someone over 30, whether in a business suit or in a white shirt, jeans, and sneakers. In my eyes, it is a mature fragrance that has class through understatement and is one of the most unique scents I know.

For me, it's one of my top 5 fragrances ever.

This perfume could be a variant of Bentley's Momentum Unbreakable that is warmer and woodier with a coconut-like note and less of the artificial mandarin inferno.
I associate 2 hours of concentrated orange juice with a lot of wood in "warm" tones, cypress, and sage.
I find the top notes - calculated for frequent use - more pleasant than in Momentum Unbreakable, which starts as an extreme synthetic-focused orange bomb, later shifting towards dill like in Zara's Tiveden, which does not happen at all with Explorer Platinum. That one smells herbal and natural from the very beginning and is consistently milder or more balanced. You "explore" more "plants" here. From orange to wine berry to sage to cedar wood to "warm" coconut elements. By the way, I don't detect violet leaf like in Fahrenheit and Simply here.
Fragrance description as a scene: Bentley parked;-), backpack on, let's go. Clean air while walking in the forest on a nice day. Moment, ;-)Break! Hiking pause in a sunny warm forest clearing. Sitting on the sun-kissed sturdy grass, a little picnic. Peeling a mandarin, drinking grape juice - oh, I still have that little coconut cream orange shot in my backpack -, seeing birds and squirrels, smelling wildflowers and tree resin, onward we go. As the sun blinds me, I briefly dream of vacation by coconut palms with the scent of the sun-warmed pine bark. How important it is to have some silence and breathe fresh air from time to time.

Thank you for your attention. Since you’re already here, you might as well stay a bit longer and read to the end. And don’t worry, this is not an ordinary comment. But let’s be honest, without the headline, you wouldn’t have read the comment about this “normal” fragrance. See.

Aren't we all searching for that one extraordinary scent? Don’t we all want to smell like no one else? Something that makes us unmistakable. And why does it smell like Imagination, Naxos, or Ombre Nomade on every corner? Why do we let way too many influencers talk us into something? What’s unique about that? Especially when you can buy a similarly scented fragrance in one of the many dupe shops for little money, which you wouldn’t want to afford in the original. Therefore, many people today smell the same, even though they believe they are wearing something extraordinary. Whoever has found the irony in this game can keep it.

Montblanc is not exactly known for producing creative fragrances. Most of the time, they create scents that are inspired by successful and trendy fragrances. Just to get a piece of the big perfume pie. This one is probably an oversight. Because it is extraordinary. Violet, clary sage, and cedar. That’s all that should be in it. It is said to remind one of Santal 33 EAU DE PARFUM. That wouldn’t be my first choice to rake in money through sales. And to get straight to the point, this one does go a bit in the direction of Santal 33 EAU DE PARFUM. It’s not a true fragrance twin. It’s softer, not so straight-in-your-face, not so leathery.

The Montblanc is aftershave-fresh (I just love it), green, woody paired with just the right dose of sweetness. Minimal, but just like you need sweetness in a beer or a really good wine to keep the overall experience from being too dry.
Violet (I just love it) gives the scent this cool, sharp freshness. The clary sage takes on the green and the minimal mineral sweetness, and the cedar wood - what a surprise - brings the woodiness. It simply smells different, extraordinary and yes, extremely masculine. It’s somehow a modern old-school scent.

The longevity and sillage are top-notch for me. A workday without reapplying is no problem. The bottle is, as always, a matter of taste.

What can I say in conclusion: It flies completely under the radar and, in my opinion, unjustly so. Testing is a must if you want to discover something extraordinary.

And to all those who think only niche counts: It’s not bad to wear Montblanc.

Legend Night's bottle has an intense cognac color with contrasting black details inspired by a fine liqueur. And there is an ambery-type scent in Legend Night. It has a morsel of everything you would expect from a woody, aromatic, and spicy cologne for men. It has a smooth and powdery texture, even though it has a fresh/spicy opening with cardamom, mint, and cedar. Night is the fourth chapter of the Legend saga, after the original Legend EAU DE TOILETTE, the Legend Intense, and the Legend Spirit.

On my skin, it opens up with a big blast of candied green apple spiced with a puff of green cardamom and a dab of mint. I can pick up the caramel nuance and lavender from the very beginning. The minty feeling adds deepness but lasts only a moment; it almost immediately disappears. The opening is bright, reminiscent of the natural radiance of man's aura. The start will remind you of something familiar if you are anything like me. Having mint, sage, and cardamom together adds a lot of spice to what would otherwise be another vanilla and apple scent.

The scent turns powdery as the minty edge tones down because the violet creeps in. The violescent lavender is more prominent now, and the apple moves to the back. It shares the herbal facet of the middle stage with the vetiver. The middle notes immediately counterbalance this first impression of refreshing coolness with their warm nobility. This is the point at which the floral notes really come into their own. The precious scents of dry cedarwood blend well with the floral lavender tones and slightly powdered violet.

When the scent approaches the dry-down, I get vanillic sweetness with a touch of warm woods, while fruity apple and spicy cardamom still linger in the back. I pick up a lot of sweetness, but sweet without crossing into gourmand territory. The vanilla note is an exciting take on today's trendy, charming vanilla-centered men's scents on the designer market: it has a dark vibe. Honeyed would be the closest term. Sweet, vanilla, tastes of honey and caramelized sugar, with a bit of apple, sage, citrus, and vetiver. I can smell vetiver and patchouli near my skin, accompanied by subtle notes of dark vanilla and velvety musk.

It is a scent with a masculine slant, but not in an alpha-male way and free from aggression. It best suits the fall and cold winter seasons, definitely an evening and night out type of cologne, but I can wear it even during the day. While the performance will not last an entire workday, it is acceptable for most evenings out and most date nights, quite a good cuddle scent. Although advertised as a night cologne, the fragrance is, to me, very smooth. I think you can get away with using this as an office fragrance. The scent is delightful, sweet, and woody at the same time. Yes, I actually like it a lot.

I base the review on a bottle I have owned since June 2019.

-Elysium

I got this bottle of Montblanc Legend Night because my father stopped wearing it and instead opted for Christian Dior, Versace, Man In Black and YSL's La Nuit De L'Homme L'Intense. (Amazing leather / iris frag btw, way better than Valentino Uomo or Intense)

And a few days after getting it, i break it down here.

Citrus / Spicy opening with bergamot, cardamom and slight aromatic mint / sage nuances
Ambery, powdery heart (Has some kind of iris / orris nuance way heavier and more pronounced than in "iris" bombs like that La Nuit De L'Homme Intense or Gentleman EDP by Givenchy) with touches of apple
Vanilla / woody base

It's an interesting fragrance. Not particularly unique by any means but it does have a particular dna that you do not find in other fragrances. Yet being close to Versace Eros (It doesn't smell much synthetic to me but anyway) it's like a grown up, refined and more elegant version of it. If Eros is the minty, citrusy vanilla kid oversprayed in the club, Legend Night is the same kid several years later (8 - 10?) wearing a tailored suit and an open shirt while drinking some fine cognac or whisky, neat. It's the best way i have found to describe it.

Bottom line: Great fragrance for the price. Montblanc always giving a great bang for buck ratio. And worth pointing out that the performance to me is ok. Not bad by any means, nor a beast mode, projects quite silently but it's great for a date. Also if you're more subdued and instead of going out to blast a club with 20 sprays of a loud scent, you go to cafés on cloudy days to meet reader girls and say you're a writer and a photographer, it's a better scent for that as well. (Maybe not as good as JPG Le Male Essence de Parfum or Givenchy Gentleman EDT, both classic and vintage) Not a heavy projector in my experience, but i guess that with it oversprayed, you can go clubbing or to a party without any trouble. Spray on clothing for extended longevity and you're good to go. Great budget winter and night scent

I bought this the other day after hearing about it.
It opens up fresh with the mint and bergamot to my nose. Then I get the Apple and vanilla combo
And the dry down is beautiful.
As per other people’s concerns even though it’s a edp the performance can be a bit to be desired.
Although it does stick around and you do get nice reminders that it is still there I do wish that it projected a bit more as the scent is awesome and I have received some good compliments since my purchase.
All in all an under the radar scent if it lasted longer projection and sillage wise it could have been an absolute winner
Would recommend it if you are happy with 1-2 hours push for sillage and about 5-6 hours as a skin scent

I tested this out on a paper strip at my local Hudson's Bay. The first thing I noticed was a wonderful mint note layered over the darker ones. It was quite delightful. After a while I noticed there was a real gourmand quality to this scent. After a few hours I experienced one of the most satisfying dry downs ever. Beautiful wood spicy scent. Real masculine. This scent is definitely for nights out and preferably in colder weather. If you want an alternative to the Dior L'Hommes of the world, this is it.

review_title: Unassuming Whispered Fruit-Spice-Wood All-Rounder with Certain Solidity
review_content:
With Montblanc, I usually see things in black when it comes to fragrances. Their wonderfully old-fashioned designed ballpoint pens glide effortlessly across the paper, smoother than any other, but with the perfumes, it has mostly been a clash of cloying synthetics or overly sweet concoctions so far.

"Legend Night" seems to actually be above average. Here is something quite wearable for the autumn in the mainstream.

Right off the bat - the scent is relatively simple. However - and this does set it apart from the other unpleasant offerings of the brand - it largely avoids laboratory-like notes or headache-inducing sweetness. It comes across rather modest and balanced.

At first, there’s a dab of apple, gently embraced by sage and cardamom with a mild spiciness. In the sillage, it is rather body lotion-like creamy, and after an hour, a very delicately drawn mix of cotton candy and a hint of wood unfolds, perhaps the aforementioned Akigalawood, which is said to be patchouli-like in construction.

What might be most surprising is indeed the unassuming nature of "Legend Night," which I consider a small step forward, as I don’t have to be annoyed by synthetic notes for the 333rd time.

review_title: Who ... wants must wear Legend Night!
review_content: A scent as if being poured again on the bear skin in front of the fireplace. Seductive, understated, assertive, with a slight caramel note enriched by a splash of ten-year-old Talisker. Next to a neck that smells like Legend Night, there are most likely two shoulders to lean on. And the lady of the heart must lean, because otherwise this perfume is hardly noticeable after just...

Scent Impression:
"Legend Night" by Montblanc is a spicy-sweet fragrance, perfect for the darker time of the year.

The emphasis here is more on spicy than sweet, although fans of sweet scents will also find something to enjoy. Nevertheless, the strengths definitely lie in the pleasant spiciness of sage, cardamom, and balsamic woods, rather than in the sweetness of apple and vanilla.

I find the comparison to Herod by Parfums de Marly to be quite fitting, as it also gives me that cozy feeling of security. However, I perceive "Legend Night" as significantly more versatile, as it is not only perfect for a cozy fireplace in winter or a family Christmas party, but just as suitable as an evening fragrance in autumn.

Longevity:
The longevity on the skin is average, while on clothing it is above average.

Target Audience:
This fragrance might be a bit too sweet for older men, but that is a matter of personal taste.

Occasion:
This cuddly, warm, cozy scent can be worn for all evening occasions during the dark season.

Conclusion:
A spicy autumn-winter fragrance that can be perfectly applied at sunset and truly enjoyed by the fireplace or campfire. The bottle colorfully expresses exactly what one can look forward to: a cuddly, warm, cozy scent with a light sweetness.
