"Legend Night" is another (and at least visually the most appealing) offshoot of Montblanc's most successful fragrance line - and it moves even further away from the Fierce-like DNA of its original perfume. Which is not a bad thing. Here we have a subtle candy scent that doesn’t hurt anyone, fitting well into the autumn on still quite fresh young men's skin. From the office to the club. An unabashed crowd-pleaser fragrance. Not one that stands out. But certainly well made, and it doesn’t always have to be the big hit.

"Legend Night" ranks in the second league somewhere behind "Eros" and "One Million" clones, representing the Sugarboy style cleanly, commendably understated, and somewhat pale. Definitely synthetic - but never piercing. Definitely very sweet - but for noses (like mine) that can still handle it, anything but disturbing. A minimally tipsy (indefinable) fruit. Dusty vanilla. Adapts very much to the wearer, has little character of its own or special strengths. Smoky or distinctive should not be expected here. Simple, wearable, an affordable cuddle blanket between sexy and interchangeable. There is definitely worse in the mainstream. However, it will likely remain forever a maximum of a hidden gem, as it does not linger in my memory or on my collar, neither positively nor negatively.

Bottle: a highlight, great color gradient!
Sillage: more discreet than many other such "sugar product uniform slush" (harshly put)
Longevity: 6 hours, no top rating here either

Conclusion: sweet and solid mass-market goods that are not unpleasant at all. For young boys, it’s certainly a nice entry-level and signature scent. For advanced users, it’s a passing item.

At first, one can perceive an intense and powerful ethereal sweet herbal note that exudes a certain prominence, thanks to the 'sage'.

At the same time, the sage merges with a delicate citrus nuance that gives the fragrance a note reminiscent of red apple, although it is not a red apple at all, but likely comes from the interplay with 'bergamot'; as well as Madagascar vanilla and patchouli in the right mix creating full milk chocolate, or it could also be the base DNA of the fragrance, so I am absolutely not sure whether the red apple in the fragrance pyramid was simply not published by the manufacturer; everything is possible.

And it reminds me that I gifted my 16-year-old little brother (he's not so little anymore, he has more bicep than I have thigh :-) ) a Montblanc fountain pen, and he also likes slightly sweet fragrances, not too extreme, so I sent him a Montblanc Legends Night bottle, and it really worked out that he received this bottle exactly on his 18th birthday.

- I love it when my plan works out! :-)

A little later, the fragrance becomes deeply floral and also spicy, accompanied by a fine Mediterranean, almost sweetly tinged smooth note, and I also suspected the use of 'violet' and 'lavender' along with a hint of 'neroli'.

In the last 3 hours, a 'vanilla' sweet creamy, delicately woody touched 'cedarwood' remains, and the question of whether it is now also free from that abominable creature that dares to call itself human has finally been answered with "Yes"!

I could not perceive 'vetiver' and 'patchouli', but I can very well imagine that these components were used for completion.

Overall, the fragrance lasts 7 hours on my skin.

The sillage is designed from the beginning for a very noticeable half-arm's length for 3 hours, before it gradually reduces until the fragrance fades away.

"Honk1510, thank you for the decant!"

Montblanc is not exactly known for creating and launching highly attractive fragrances.

Their releases often align with already well-known, extremely successful scent compositions.
Generally, they are so-called crowd pleasers!
Perhaps to grab as large a piece as possible of the sweet-tasting cake.

At first, a slightly spicy, herbal note emerges briefly, stemming from the sage.
Then, the lavender and violet quickly come to the forefront.
They form a slightly creamy, almost balsamic enveloping with the vanilla, patchouli, and cedarwood.

Models for this fragrance composition can be found in D&G The One or also at Valentino.
Qualitatively, they are probably executed a bit better there, but also cost 1-2 euros more.

Bottle: quite sturdy - with a metallic cap

Longevity: also relatively stable in this price segment (mid-range designer) - 6h+

Sillage: quite close to the body quickly - maximum 3h then close to the body - if desired, reapplication

Conclusion: spicy/sweet fragrance - particularly well-suited for cool/wet & dark autumn evenings - more suitable for a younger audience - but this ultimately remains a matter of taste.

review_title: The Warm Blanket No One Talks About
review_content:
I would like to write about my favorite evening scent.
I am 34, have a wife and kids, and I don't really go out partying anymore :D
I still like to take the time to shower in the evening and then crash on the sofa after a tiring day.
This is usually the time when I apply this fragrance - not because it refreshes me or makes me extroverted, but because it confirms my mood that I want a quiet evening lying on the sofa with my wife, watching TV or talking about life and everything.
The scent never takes control over me or leaves me frowning; instead, it gives me a cozy feeling that nothing bad will happen today. It fits me, especially in such life situations.

You can tell that the production doesn't quite match the quality of other perfumes, but it doesn't clash and lasts pleasantly long.
I have sprayed it several times before sleeping, which is rather unusual for me.

It's a shame that some people here criticize it; I think for the price, it is unbeatable in what it does!

All the best
Your Andreas :)

This fragrance is a pleasantly slightly sweet, woody, and fresh winter scent. Unfortunately, the longevity is very low, and it is only worth wearing if you spray it generously and want it to last for 1-2 hours, because it hardly lasts longer. It's a pity, a typical problem with Mont Blanc.

Legend Night is one of the few fragrances that I have repurchased multiple times in my life, and it is also one of those scents that do not reveal their full potential at first sniff. Unfortunately, fir balsam and rosemary, which together with sage create an extremely calming effect for me, were forgotten in the fragrance pyramid, so I often use it as a sleep fragrance.

Fragrance notes: Bergamot is only very faintly noticeable at the beginning, while violet, vetiver, and patchouli, thankfully, I do not perceive at all. Vanilla and cedarwood are subtly felt in the background from the heart note. As I mentioned, the dominant notes for me are primarily sage, rosemary, fir balsam, and also lavender, which only makes a very subtle appearance.

Fragrance classification & intensity: This is a slightly distinctive, fresh, spicy, and woody scent that I still consider to be the best fragrance from Montblanc, even ahead of Legend Spirit.

Comparison: Those who enjoy very vanilla and slightly distinctive yet pleasant scents, such as One Million Privé by Paco Rabanne, will also feel comfortable with this fragrance.

Some fragrances have been in my collection for years and tend to be a bit forgotten. This Legend Night is really quite solid and deserves a review in my opinion. Of course, it is not one that is very innovative, yet it does its job well in this price range. The Legend line is more in the shower gel direction, leaning towards a noticeably fresher vibe. This Night flanker was...

review_title: Montblanc Legend Night - The best Montblanc for me
review_content:
Montblanc Legend Night is for me the most relaxed scent in the range and exactly what I need when I want to unwind at home and still smell good. The fragrance starts off soft and pleasant with a warm blend and a hint of lavender. Cozy, but not too heavy.

What makes Legend Night special is this comforting warmth, which is perfect for quiet evenings. It doesn't impose itself, always remaining subtle and pleasant. That's exactly why I love wearing it when I relax at home and still want to smell good even though I'm not going out. I always enjoy smelling it!!

The longevity is okay, but nothing extraordinary. For longer days or nights, I would reapply, but for my own four walls, it's completely sufficient. Legend Night is not a party scent, but a true comfort companion.

Legend Night is the perfect fragrance for relaxed evenings. Warm, subtle, and just right when you want to unwind - for me, the best Montblanc!

A fragrance that accompanies me from time to time between October and March. When everything is a bit quieter and one wants to navigate through everyday life in a more contemplative way. I really like this sweet - somewhat lavender-like - woodiness. It exudes a warm heaviness that I would describe as very pleasant and calm. Exactly how I want to experience our dark, cold...

review_title: I’d never thought I’d be into a knockoff,
review_content:
But this one knocked me off of my feet when I got the whiff... if you can’t tell it’s totally trying to be Aventus you’re kidding yourself, but if you aren’t tempted to shell out the cash, you aren’t human. I like the real version, but I couldn’t bring myself to spend the $$ on something so many people already have... cut that price down THIS much though? Hell yes I’m in...

Again, you can tell it wants to be creed, and as the notes pass it becomes MORE obvious, but I don’t care... I’m loving it, and I didn’t even spend HALF the cost.

Projection? Check. It’s a good 3-4ft reach for a good 2-3 hours. Sillage? Check; they will know YOU were there. Longevity? Checkmate! Easy 6-8+ hours on a 3-4 good sprays.

I’m STOKED Mont Blanc brought this beast out... it’s worth every penny

Well I blingbought this one - just because the 30mil bottle looks soo damn good. As a first impression the fragrance is ookay-ish, but nothing special. It smells a little bit similar to the Dior Sauvage but its much more fruity, much less sharp - lets call it Ambroxan triangle: The [sharp Sauvage], the [creamy LunaRossaCarbon] and the [fruity Explorer].

So as a first impression lets call it nothing special, its a versatile ambroxan-based fragrance.
What about the longetivity? Its pretty bad, lets face it: 30 min normal and 2 hour time as a skin scent, and its gone, so its longetivity is really poor, but the 30mil fits well in the pocket, so I think Montblanc is prepared the bottle format for re-spraying.

Allright, and why am I writing a review if the smell is "nothing special" and the longetivity is pretty bad? Because of two reasons: the reactions and how the scent changes with temperature.

The most of the fragrances smells suffocating in hot weather or disappears in cold weather - there is only 1-2 parfumes are useable in hot and cold weather - but Montblanc Explorer is one of them, because its smell changes with the temperature.

But the biggest reason to talk about this fragrance is the reactions: well I used some mainstream hits before: Dior Sauvage, Prada LR Carbon, Bleu De Chanel, Bvlgari Aqva Marine, Jimmy Choo Man Ice, Tom Ford Noir, D&G The One, Zadig&Voltaire This is Him!, D&G Light Blue, YSL Y, YSL La Nuit, YSL L'Homme, and so on, but I have never, NEVER received so many positive feedbacks on a single fragrance like this, and especially from women.

review_title: Ah so good for the price...
review_content: Yup no matter what the Creed snobs say, this is Aventus-esque and just as good. I mean look at the perfumers for a start. I can't believe how good for the summer this is and soooooo cheap. I get a full days performance, unlike the Creed masterpiece that varies with every batch made and I have had a few bottles. There's not much more to say than just buy a bottle it will not disappoint.

I came across him not to long ago when I was looking for a new scent when I was about to run out of my beloved Bleu de Chanel Parfum. It opens with a sharp bergamot which for some could be a bit synthetic but in my most humble opinion it's prob the best part of this fragrance. The mid is also very lovely, as it settles it turns into a woody/ aromatic scent which is also very clean. About and hour into the drydown it transitions into and ambroxan bomb which I can no longer detect any nuances whatsoever, just a screeching ambroxan base that still projects and linger very well. After that point it really is nothing special. As for compliments this will get you noticed and garner compliments and to be fair my better half absolutely loves this. Value for money is very good, you can gets this for 40% at times on online discounters having said that it would be a hard pass for me at retail.The bottle presentation is very elegant in my opinion with the classic Montblanc minimalism. All and all a pretty decent scent if looking for an all year-round scent and you don't want to break the bank.

review_title: Guilty pleasure for an admitted snob
review_content:
This fragrance makes me realize I need to step off my high horse of $300 fragrances every so often. To put it simply this is just a really great fragrance. Sweet and citrusy with a really potent woody/leather backbone. Smooth and easy-going, not a typical "cologne guy" scent like most designer releases.

This is not an Aventus clone, but it does fit the category and is clearly an inspired scent with its bergamot and heavy ambroxan. Aventus is fruity and musky, whereas this is dry and woody.

As pointed out by other reviews here, Explorer isn't exactly a performer... The scent is pleasant enough, but I am probably a bit of a snob since Explorer gave me a headache after not too long of wearing. One of the issues is since longevity is so bad, two sprays are far from enough so you'll spray at least five times. Sadly it makes it just smell more, not longer. The...

review_title: Montblanc Explorer: Hail to the King
review_content:
It is official. After nine years, we finally have a designer fragrance based on the most popular fragrance(s) in the world. This Montblanc Explorer review is my fragrant journey during the last five months.

Here are my 5 quick takes:

- An all-year-around fragrance
- Fruity Aromatic composition
- The natural interpretation of the most popular niche fragrance
- Versatile fragrance suitable for anyone
- High-Quality presentation

I found it quite pleasing and was my most used fragrance during the summer.

The oblivious influence is straight-up visible, but it differs enough with its natural smelling notes.

If you are interested in my perfume work, you can find me on the web and social media's under the Scent Grail name. Cheers.

A fragrance on the path of Creed Aventus, but without the pure, smoky scent of pineapple which found in Aventus. It’s not completely similar but rather follows its path, the pineapple has been replaced with citrus and Italian bergamot.
Rather, the fragrance comes closer to Club de Nuit Intense Man Armaf, L'Aventure Al Haramain, and Supremacy Silver Afnan, all of which followed the path of Aventus, but didn’t reach its purity and quality.
Perhaps Explorer Montblanc is better than its predecessors, as the similarity here in the stages of the fragrance, except for the opening, is very similar to Aventus, at a rate that may reach 40%.

Definitely suitable for summer, as it is a lively fragrance that stimulates activity, and suitable for men over thirty years of age, can be worn on any clothing, whatever it is, and at all the summer times, It is an easy and unpretentious fragrance.

The performance of the fragrance is somewhat average:
- Longevity: around 4 hours and often less
- Sillage: around 2 hours at best

The fragrance bottle is ordinary, not special, and gives the luxury impression of somewhat.

review_title: Nice Scent and an Easy Reach
review_content:
Tested from a sample. Opening has strong citrus scent which mingles with a herbal accord. More herbal I'd say than spicy. As it settled the citrus went to the background and a smooth vetiver-leather scent became obvious. As it further evolved, about 20 minutes, a wood scent started to dominate which was backed by a softer musky scent. The wood scent eventually became less smooth and more sharp - maybe sharp/sour is a better way to describe it. Longevity was very good with decent projection - around arms length and gradually diminishing to around the 6 to 7 hour mark when it's down to a skin scent.

Overall, a great masculine fragrance which gave me a similar impression as Montblanc Explorer Platinum even though they smell different - an easy reach for everyday for a guy wanting a straightforward, pleasant scent, not trying to make a statement. Could work anytime of the year, day or night, most all situations. A definite keeper with a very reasonable price.

I do not know Aventus, so can't say how Explorer compares to it.

Absolute banger. I've slept on Montblanc thinking they were kind of an off brand, but everything I've smelled from them is worth every penny. I own genuine Aventus from 2015, and I will say on opening these are almost indistinguishable. Explorer quickly shows a different character on the dry down, however, with more pepper and patchouli and a distinct woods base. It's hard to...

review_title: My dad is not a lawyer
review_content: Montblanc are madlads. Not because they "copied" Creed but because they did it better. Aventus is a beta fragrance and Explorer is a chad. I like that it smells better, costs less and has a better bottle. No need to waste money on Creed, I'll get this instead then use my savings to spoil my girlfriend. You know, because I actually have a personality. How are those triple digit collections going team?

review_title: “Montblanc Explorer” the clone, the myth, the legend?
review_content: Call montblanc explorer whatever you want but this is my two cents. I received a sample of the juice luckily before it’s release and used it for some time now. I’ve tried heavy sprays, light sprays and everything in between and this fragrance performs nicely, right where I want it to be and of course that’s on my personal skin. My first impression of this slightly smoky wave of aventus made me think of a man like Beowulf, someone back in the older days that is a warrior but some part of it is very modern too like I hate to say it on here,.. Sauvage. I’m not sure if I’d say this a mix between creed aventus and sauvage because it’s not, but the very peppery feel I get from this is mixed also with the ambroxan to create this sausage-esque comparison that many would say is main stream to some extent because of dior’s Sauvage. This pepper and ambroxan when sprayed lightly on my clothing changed into a smell that sort of resembled a candle and is something that I’m not rather a fan of, but when left on skin with a few sprays (meaning 3) as we all should wear this mixture creates a lovely aroma that slightly resembles pineapples in the top note. Having all that said I must say a solid release this fragrance is a solid release from this house and although people give this frangrance backlash for smelling like a bottom pick aventus (considering all the other great clones out), this is a addition to Macy’s and more maintstream retailers for their own feel for aventus and have something new-smelling unalike from all the scents at stores like Macy’s. Let’s be honest, Montblanc is showing that this Creed Aventus the community speaks of is merely an overpriced exclusive, that all the ingredients within Creed can be replicated with rarely even using any of the same notes! I respect this aventus clone the most for that fact and I encourage perfumers from all over the world to create. I respect Creed Aventus more nonetheless because of its completeness, quality, and heritage but Montblanc merely opened the door for a glimpse at this masterpiece of a niche fragrance.

Explorer is the most mainstream and mass pleasing interpretation of Aventus. No smokiness, hardly any woodiness but instead a good dose of Ambroxan. However, the sweetness in there is strange to my nose. Imagine an original coca-cola in comparison to a sugar free no name cola product. These super cheap diet soda stuff sometimes has this scratchy almost bitter and artificial taste. That is how I experience Montblanc Explorer. Its maybe muscs that provide this strange sensation. In the air it definitely smells better than of clothes or skin which makes me believe that some of the heavier base notes are the problem to my nose
In my opinion its successs comes from the fact that this is the only designer Aventus available in stores to smell...

review_title: Trendy (Jordi Fernandez, Antoine Maisondieu & Olivier Pescheux, 2019)
review_content:
Explorer is like a best-of compilation of trends in perfumery nowadays. It takes already known and beautiful Aventus DNA and pairs it with the molecule of the moment – Ambroxan that gives that shower gel, musky and clean vibe. Explorer opens up with sweet bergamot and this fleeting leathery notes, to my nose very similar to Zara Vibrant Leather. Like Jerome Epinette was a part of the team. While Vibrant Leather continues to follow Aventus’ footsteps, Explorer deviates a little bit and successfully introduces a note of clary sage which I really like. From now on Ambroxan takes the main play, accompanied by a light touch of pepper and some discreet synthetic woody and green patchouli aspects.
I have to admit, Explorer smells good. The scent profile is pleasing and versatile. Every occasion is a good occasion for Explorer. It is not good as Creed Aventus. I personally even prefer Zara Vibrant Leather, but somehow in my opinion is upgrade from Dior Sauvage and Dior Homme 2020. There is nothing to dislike in Explorer, except for the complete lack of originality. Does somebody with a bog collection needs it? No, but Explorer is an ideal fragrance for people who only needs one fragrance and wanted to smell good, trendy and fun. Nothing more, but nothing less. And the bottle looks great.

Rating: 6/10

I've had the chance to try Aventus lately and went downstairs, grabbed the 30ml bottle I gifted my father and brother, so they'd have something versatile to wear whenever they go out.

Are they similar? Yes. They are both woody citrussy but I don't like the smell of Sage. If it wasn't there, Im not sure how the woodiness would be complete. Still, I think it's way better than Aventus.
I think this bad boy is an amazing gift for your boyfriend,father or even grandfather. Such versatile Perfume that you could never go wrong with it. Absolutely inoffensive and really chill. Thanks to my classmate in Uni who made me get this.
I find it really classy and nonchalant and for the price, it's definitely way better than Aventus. At least there are no batch issues.

review_title: A cheap parody of a modern classic
review_content:
Montblanc Explorer EDP opens with a pungent, synthetic, chemical pop that smells like a tire garage mixed with salty sweat.

To me, it’s unpleasant all the way through and headache-inducing from start to finish. It lingers for ages, which is great if you enjoy the smell, but for me, it felt like being followed around by the Michelin Man after a long run in the hot sun.

I kind of understand the comparisons to Aventus, but they’re completely different beasts with only vaguely similar DNA. Explorer lacks the crisp, fruity elegance of Aventus and smells like a cheap parody of a modern classic.

2/10

Explorer is a highly versatile, crowd-pleasing scent that punches well above its price tag.

From the first spray, you’re greeted with a fresh burst of bergamot and a hint of spicy pink pepper, which gradually gives way to a rich heart of vetiver and leather. The dry-down leans into ambroxan and patchouli, delivering a modern, slightly woody base that lasts all day on my skin.

Yes, the DNA is inspired by Creed Aventus. But Explorer holds its own. It’s smoother, less fruity, and more grounded, which I prefer for daily wear. This is a fragrance I reach for year-round, whether I’m heading to the office or out for dinner or even to the gym.

If you’re looking for something safe yet refined, familiar yet still well-crafted, Explorer delivers. It’s not niche, but it doesn’t need to be. Just solid, reliable rough masculine elegance in a bottle.

review_title: Harsh opening, better dry down and weak performance.
review_content: I tried this fragrances multiple times in the store. I always got a strong synthetic cleaner vibe from it and it deterred me from buying it. But always after it dried down it smelled much better, so I finally bought it. Unfortunately it doesn't seem to last long on my skin. But as an office fragrance (which I was aiming for) this will do.

Finally, Mont Blanc took the long waited but oh so sweet revenge on Creed, for what the latter did with Individuel.

For a fraction of the price, Mont Blanc made the Aventus DNA very accesible to a lot of people. A great addition to the fragrance market. Love it.

Save your money and just pick up a bottle of CDNI EDP or Limited Edition. The scent off this is nice, but the longevity is pretty trash for an EDP, and it seems that Montblanc are upping their prices now too. The longevity is far too weak on most of their perfumes to even consider raising their prices lol

review_title: A good fragrance, just not for me
review_content: I bought this on a whim after seeing how well-liked and cheap it was. I was wowed by how powerful the opening was. I love a good citrus opening. It dried down into a strong wood and leather, with the citrus lingering in the background. Nevertheless, I was disappointed to say that this wasn't for me. It's smells too old, generic, and masculine-leaning to my nose.

Explorer always stood out as a great choice for spring, especially for me. It's strong, and its zesty lime is just perfectly balanced with the Haitian vetiver, creating a great, almost ethereal breath of freshness with a feeling of ritualistic warmth haunting it. It's a great pick that definitely needs to be tried, especially due to its bold exoticism.

On the first sniff it gives off the aventus vibe but the dry down is completely different. I absolutely have no complaints with this scent as long as I am not comparing it with Aventus and you shouldn't too because the price tag says it all...Maybe you can go ahead and compare it with Armaf CDN but then the quality of ingredients come into play, the ONE downside is there...

review_title: The Do It All Safe Bet
review_content:
Montblanc Explorer is one of the most versatile fragrances that sits on my shelf. When I don’t feel like putting much effort into matching my fragrance with my mood or my outfit, Explorer always works. It is no secret that Explorer is heavily influenced by Creed Aventus, so it doesn’t win any awards for being at all original. But out of the many fragrances I own, this is the one that makes my wife weak in the knees when I wear it. It is quite a simple formula. Zesty citrus off of the top that comes off as pineapple with a dash of lemon. When it dries down, it goes into woods, oakmoss, and good old ambroxan.

Explorer is not a heavy projector, nor does it project for very long. It becomes a skin scent at around the 2 to 3 hour mark. It does tend to stick to clothes more than my skin.

The bottle design is fine. It’s easy to hold. I do wish the atomizer sprayed more and the black “leather” wrap on it becomes a little annoying when you are trying to see how much juice is left in the bottle.

At about $40 for a full sized bottle on discounter websites, this is wonderful value. If you want something that can get you close to the Aventus DNA without the $300 price tag, this is your best bet. Many people will recommend Club de Nuit Intense Man for the better performance, but with Explorer you avoid that super irritating lemon house cleaner opening of CDNIM.

I'll be honest it doesnt smell too wow but its gets more compliments then I expect. Its clean and classy, nothing crazy. Its woody too. That's what you need in a everyday fresh fragrance. Fresh and wood = compliments. Plus look how cheap it is compared to others. It's worth it and lives up to the game

A very easy wearing fragrance. The citrus off the top is almost bitter, which gives way to to a creamy synthetic leathery base. There's a bit of smokiness in this too as it dries down. Performance is ok though falls short of a full work day wearing.
I really don't get the comparison to Aventus other than the fact it's a citrus over woods composition. I'd say this is more akin to a muted and less fruity Cedrat Boise.
Not my favourite, but evidently a lot of others favourite as this is one of my most complimented fragrances in my collection.

After some research, I settled on Explorer as an alternative to Aventus. I love Aventus, but don't want to blow through my bottle too quickly due to the price, so I bought Explorer as a substitute for a typical day.

When I first tried it, and especially when I first tried it on, I was very surprised at just how similar it is to Aventus. The one thing I noticed is that it lacked the pineapple sweetness that is so prominent in my Aventus. Comparing them side by side, it is also a little more harsh, and leans a little more into the masculine side. However, I asked to people (women) to blind smell them both and tell me which they prefer, one preferred Aventus, and the other preferred Explorer because it was a little more poignant.

I got a 200ml bottle for about $115 at a retailer. To me, the scent and the bottle quality at that cost is a great deal. My only complaint is that it doesn't seem to last as long on my skin as Aventus. Overall great value, and if you like Aventus, a great alternative.

I absolutely adore the smell of this cologne. It's fresh, and woody, with a slight smell of leather. This is a fragrance you could easily wear in nearly every occasion. The price is also amazing. After all these amazing things this seems like an obvious purchase right? Not so fast. Sadly this suffers greatly in its longevity and projection. If you're okay with your cologne becoming a skin scent within an hour, and then completely leaving your body in 4-5 hours, then this is a great purchase. However, if you're looking for an amazing everyday fragrance that performs well, this isn't for you. Overall I would still recommend this cologne for those who love the smell, but I believe there are other better options with a similar price tag.

Scent 8.5/10

Longevity 5/10

Sillage 6/10

Value 7/10

I don't own Aventus so can't comment on the similarity. The smell is good, but very weak. It projects for only about 30 mins or so. Longevity is ok, 3-4 hours as a skin scent. Overall, not happy at all.

My first and last blind buy....

Opens with citrus and herbal spices. Leather sort of hints around by the heart combined with a clean vetiver note . Dries down to a peppery musk.

I mean, it's that simple. It will be my only blind buy, not because it's bad, because it's not. But I don't want to gamble of average scents like this.

Obvious comparisons are to Aventus and having smelled both, I get the comparisons, but isn't a 1:1 match. A pretty well constructed scent for the price.

Looking for a Creed Aventus Clone? This isn't it. Don't get me wrong, it's a really great scent, it's just not creed.

If I were to describe this, I'd say put 50% creed aventus in a bottle and 50% dior sauvage in the same bottle and you'd get Mont Blanc Explorer. It's a nice fresh every day kind of scent. Unoffensive, versatile, easy grab.

I like it, it's worth a sniff, maybe you'll like too.

review_title: Great frag, but performance severely lacking …
review_content: Aventus DNA, but not an Aventus copy or clone — it’s in its own distinct lane. All-year round citrus freshie that’s inoffensive and very office-friendly. Lacks performance, even for a freshie, my only criticism of this fragrance; on my skin lasts just over an hour before settling into a skin-scent for another hour before I’d need to reapply. I imagine it would last a little longer on clothes. I’d probably gift this but won’t be re-adding it to the rotation as the performance leaves a lot to be desired.

review_title: Slightly above average scent, slightly below average performance
review_content:
Fruity/citrus but not overly bright, sweet or fizzy. More succulent and bold. It's pretty nice. I haven't smelled aventus but I can definitely sense a pineapple in here. It's kind of an earthy, bold, fruity fragrance. It's my introduction to this type of DNA and it's definitely its own type.

I've worn this in a few different settings. I don't love it as a daily driver especially when I'm working. But I do love it when I'm out of the house. With friends, or general outdoor recreation. It's a happy scent. You can layer it with something like anOther 13 if you want to make it a bit bolder.

Does not last long...like at all, which is also why I like to layer with anOther, since that one lasts a while and keeps some of the Explorer with it. But it's okay, for the settings I prefer Explorer in, I don't want it to be overwhelming. Just some nice whiffs.

Fairly safe blind buy, but may or may not blow you away. To me, it was a blind buy, and it's overall pretty average, but definitely on the nicer and higher end side of average.

Montblanc Exporer was my second ever purchase. At first I get a pretty sharp peppery opening, but this calms down quickly and transitions into the bergamot and ambroxan, which I feel are the most prominent notes for me. Super easy to wear, might be a bit weak on the sillage for some, but if you like a more understated scent, this is perfect.

The quality for the price is really good too, you can get a 200ml bottle for 60 euros on discount

awesome scent, i can really pickup the pink pepper in the beginning as well as that citrus smell. I find most of my male friends love this on me(no homo) but me and my brothers girlfriends both told us we smell like grass!! so id say overall 70% of people should enjoy the smell of this, but it may be hit or miss when talking about just women. The bottle is super cool too, one of my favorite bottles in my collection. i was able to snag 200ml for 60$ on jomashop

The opening act of Explorer is where the overlap with Aventus is going to be the most noticeable. Do the two smell alike? Yes, but let’s get the differences out of the way, and focus on Explorer in this post.

That pineapple note from Aventus is absent. Along with, the birch wood. Explorer isn’t nearly as sharp, deep, or smoky as the Creed fragrance. Also, no vanilla undertones. But, as a woody citrus cologne? Quite similar in terms of aroma.

Explorer starts off with its bergamot citrus note and it’s fresh spices. I mainly get the sage, but there is also a prominent pink pepper.

Underneath this, sits leather, ambroxan, wood, and vetiver. It comes across as bright and fresh with the a level of smoothness.

To me, the leather and cacao notes in the base, also give Explorer a resemblance to Dolce & Gabbana Pour Homme. The D&G has tonka bean and tobacco, instead, but shares the citrus, sage, and it also has a pepper note.

It’s not too complex. The final dry down has less of the citrus and pepper and more woods and a somewhat chocolatey finish from the cacao note. Definitely doesn’t have the same depth or development as Aventus.

The opening notes in Explorer made me sigh in disappointment. As I continue learning and understanding my note preferences better, this one just wouldn’t make the list right off the bat.

It opens with a strong burst of vetiver, along with some other deep, unrecognisable notes that evolve into that classic masculine scent I dread the most. I'm still on the fence with vetiver. For now, I can tolerate Haitian vetiver, but not its woodier, deeper counterpart, Java vetiver. Fortunately, the vetiver in Explorer is Haitian, and it does become more subtle and toned down over time.

The bergamot disappears almost instantly. I couldn’t help but chuckle; it vanished like a breeze. Ambroxan steps in, replacing vetiver as the lead solo until the very end. It’s quite linear from start to finish, and I can definitely catch a bit of that Sauvage vibe.

My nose is still pretty green, and right now I’m leaning more towards freshies, so it makes sense why this one isn’t really hitting for me.

I expected bolder notes or riskier transitions, especially for something marketed as an ‘Explorer’ but it turned out to be a safe, mass-appealing ‘City Dweller’ that wouldn’t even dare venture down an alleyway, let alone the countryside.

Mont Blanc Explorer ist ein Parfum, für jeden Tag und jede Jahreszeit. Für wenig Geld bekommt man hier einen Frischen Duft.
Er ist sehr künstlich, was manche stört. Außerdem hält er nicht all zu lange, nach 4-5h ist er nahezu weg, also am besten in ein Travelzerstäuber umfüllen und dann wieder auftragen.

Für den Preis bekommt man ein gutes Produkt welches aber nicht mit Aventus Creed zu vergleichen ist, da manche diesen als Klon oder Dupe bezeichnen.

review_title: Interpretation of Aventus, yet it stands on its own
review_content:
Explorer can be characterized as an interpretation of Aventus, yet it stands as an independent fragrance distinguished by its light and aromatic qualities, enhanced by the notes of bergamot, vetiver, and patchouli. It is an ideal fragrance for both everyday wear and formal occasions, exuding a smooth and masculine scent. While not overpowering, its presence is subtle and noticeable throughout the day. Wearing this fragrance is not intended to impress others; rather, it is a personal choice for enhancing one’s aroma. Unlike fragrances sought after for compliments, Explorer simply captures attention in a positive way.

Explorer is particularly suitable for office wear or travel due to its moderate intensity. Its projection is not overly strong, lasting approximately two hours at arm length, and its longevity is approximately five to six hours, with a lingering skin scent of Ambroxan thereafter.

I have never smelled the real Creed Aventus so I cannot compare the two but while I enjoy this scent, it does not blow me away. It is very fresh in the opening and then it becomes this masculine scent. While the price is certainly a standout and the bottle is quite nice for me this is just not signature worthy. Longevity is very good I can still pick it up after 10 hours.

this is okay it smells similar to aventus and it’s inexpensive but it hardly lasts it’s worth the extra money to just get aventus if you like the dna, but if you’d rather get this i wouldn’t recommend it for anything other than going to the gym or running quick errands. i need more characters but there’s nothing else to say ignore this

After good word of mouth and reading reviews and similarities with creed etc I thought to try out this perfume. With a fair price I thought why not?
Tbh it's a nice smelling fragrance but it does not last long. You can get a bit of headache with this too. I will keep this review short and give this a ratinf of 3.5 /5. Club de nuit is far better

I must confess! I belong to the AA's! The Anonymous Aventus Abstainers. My nose is untouched by the Creed primus, and so I dare to draw an unbiased conclusion based on my personal taste. The fragrance is predominantly torn apart as a dupe and, in my opinion, has a worse reputation that does not do it justice at all. The first time I sprayed it on a strip in the duty-free...

Mont Blanc Explorer is the first fragrance for which a statement simply isn't enough.

I had already tried a sample of Aventus and was torn. This interesting scent kept coming to my nose, but then there was also that smoky note that reminded me of damp ashtrays. Unfortunately, I realized that as a former smoker, I just don't like smoky fragrances at all. The same goes for By the Fireplace or Noir Ambre.
Aventus therefore "failed" for me. The same was true for me with twin fragrances or dupes.

But now finally to the Explorer. The similarity to Aventus is clearly present, but it is not a complete copy. Especially the Ambroxan sweetness at the end is noticeably different.
I am particularly pleased because the smokiness in the Explorer has been dialed back to a minimum, so it doesn't bother my sensitive non-smoker nose. What remains is that interesting note that I always found so great in Aventus.

As well-known as the DNA is here, I have never smelled it on anyone in my surroundings. Therefore, I am genuinely excited about the release.

With four sprays, I get a good sillage of three to four hours. I also noticed that the fragrance smells even better in the cloud than directly on the skin.

After that, the scent noticeably fades and lasts on me for 6 to 8 hours, depending on the temperature. It could be better, but it's not bad either.

In my opinion, the fragrance can be worn by any man from about 25 years old (I find it too mature for younger ones). It can be worn on any occasion except for sports.

I really like the bottle, and the sprayer is also fine. There's nothing to complain about.

For me, Explorer will be my leather jacket fragrance for spring and summer this year.

Conclusion :
I recommend Explorer to anyone who likes the Aventus DNA but, like me, doesn't want the smokiness and instead can handle a bit of mainstream sweetness.

It was a torture, it was tedious, it was exhausting. Out there, it seems there are actually more perfume enthusiasts than one can imagine. The new scent from Mont Blanc simply did not want to be tested by me. No matter where I was - Karstadt, Douglas, Galeria Kaufhof - everywhere the testers were empty. The hype surrounding the fragrance as the ultimate Aventus clone seems to be real.

Well, I actually found a store where there were still minimal remnants of the scent in the bottle. After the third attempt, one is allowed to be lucky. The procedure of first using a test strip and then weighing whether to bless one's wrist with the scent was skipped. Instead, it went straight to the wrist.
I was truly amazed at how well the top note is done here. It really smells almost 1:1 like Aventus. I am not the biggest fan of it - I already mentioned this in another comment. It is indeed a good scent that always works, but it hasn't blown me away. For me, it is a little bit sour and could be a bit softer. Over time, it does become a bit softer and slightly smoky, which is also pleasing, but I still maintain that this is not a scent for which I would lay down several hundred euros. The Explorer is a significantly cheaper alternative here, but it doesn't quite reach Creed's bestseller. Why is that?

I already wrote that the top note, to my nose, is almost exactly what I also perceive in Aventus - namely a very fruity, yet slightly sour, piercing affair, where one hopes that something changes a little bit. While Aventus became a bit softer, but still not as much as I wish, the Explorer remains very linear. The bergamot is omnipresent, but it does experience a little bit of contrast as vetiver comes in slightly and adds some freshness. The next and also last big step is the Ambroxan, where I was afraid that it would be used as excessively as in Dior Sauvage EdP. Fortunately, that was not the case, but still, something else could have been used instead of Ambroxan to imitate the slight smokiness of Aventus. Unfortunately, the Ambroxan brings a certain, albeit not overwhelming, synthetic quality that is not particularly bothersome but is still noticeable, which results in the Explorer not reaching Creed's level. Aventus is simply more rounded, more sovereign, and above all - and this is the crucial point - a bit softer in the scent development - not by much, but still perceptibly so. Thus, Mont Blanc's new creation always has a slight scratchy undertone that diminishes the overall impression a bit. One must still acknowledge the really good price-performance ratio. Because considering the price, this Mont Blanc is not that much worse. Despite my criticism, it is better than many other mainstream options (like Sauvage, for example). The longevity is also very good, considering that fruity scents always have a bit more to struggle with. There is also nothing to complain about in terms of projection, as it projects absolutely sufficiently.
Conclusion: It doesn't quite reach Creed's cash cow, as it shines through increased sovereignty and roundness. If I had to choose between the two scents, I wouldn't choose either, as my taste is not 100 percent met here. However, if I were forced to choose one of the two scents and had to spend my own money on it, I would definitely go for the Explorer, as the differences in everyday life, while focusing on other essential things alongside the scent, are only marginal.

review_title: No fragrance to write fairy tales about...
review_content:
but a solid everyday scent that swims along with the current of the times.
In fact, I am someone who enjoys writing stories about fragrances and letting them take me on a journey, but with this one, it just doesn’t work. The scent progression is about as linear as a broomstick, and reading the notes feels like just having taken half a box of Hoggar™ Night.

“Laaaangweilig!” many are now shouting, and they are right, because they are perfume lovers with an "eLeGaNt TaSte" who probably douse themselves in Andy Tauer every day. They say Explorer is copied, “How can anyone like this? Yuck! Ugh! Never! 1 star!”

In reality, however, it looks different. Most people are not elite noses and simply do not care about the rarity or uniqueness of a fragrance; they just want to smell good for half a day, and for that, Explorer is perfect.

Fruity-fresh with a bit of smoke and vetiver for character, great longevity and sillage, and all for little money:
Your friends like it
Your parents like it
Your bank account likes it
and especially Chantal from the secretariat likes it ;)
only you don’t like it because your ego won’t allow you to appreciate something from the mainstream. Sad, really.

review_title: Pleasant Fresh Cheapie in Aventus Style
review_content: Something new from me. Like most fragrances that resemble Aventus, scents quickly come into the spotlight. This one too. I briefly tested it a few months ago, and now I have a small 30ml bottle in my collection. This small bottle is very affordable online, and even the larger bottles are not too expensive. Montblanc is a brand I find quite likable with a great range. Anyone...

Not quite. Let's put it into perspective. It's the nephew.
After my rather attention-grabbing comment on Aventus, here’s one about a supposed clone. Of course, I had to get a sample (thanks Kitho!) - the Explorer is currently all the rage.
This time, I took an analytical approach. Sprayed it on. Hmm, I smell nothing - so I had to resort to a paper towel. Sprayed the paper. Uh yeah, it’s masculine. I get a fresh pineapple note and a lot of spicy/peppery elements. Good. Set the sample aside and did some sports first. I should mention that I sprayed three fragrances on different cloths and they all lay in my kitchen. While I was working out, I kept getting a little breeze, and it smelled strongly of Explorer. The other two fragrances didn’t register at all (they were Atkinsons samples). I was already aware of a certain polarizing effect. It’s room-dominant and has a decent sillage. Good - showered and then thought I’d just give it a try. Sprayed on - 4 full sprays and off to the dentist. In the car, I could constantly smell myself. It wasn’t unpleasant. I had a mental battle with the pineapple (I still don’t like it) in combination with the masculine undertone that comes strongly from the Ambroxan (vetiver, pepper, patchouli, and Akigalawood). Unfortunately, I don’t notice any leather.
Well, off to the dentist. The dental assistant was taken by my perfume. I’ve never experienced that before, but it was an interesting experience....
Back home. Scent assessment: still smells the same as at the beginning ;).
Update: 9 hours later and I can still smell myself. The longevity is thus already at an extreme level.
However, when I got home, I couldn’t resist applying Aventus on my right arm and Explorer on my left for a direct comparison:
Aventus: not sweet, rather fresh, help, the pineapple is there and there’s musk. I still don’t like it :(. Too old, too heavy...
Explorer: sweeter than Aventus, fresh pineapple, the vetiver plays a stronger role here and the Ambroxan does its best. It’s brighter and sweeter but already quite similar to Aventus in the top notes.
In the drydown, it becomes clearer. Explorer remains sweeter, fresher, and for me has no noticeable smoky/leather note. There’s more synthetic quality here than with Aventus. When I look at the price-performance ratio, I don’t have much more to say. Explorer will soon join my collection as a full bottle.
Test it yourself - if you don’t like Aventus, you might find something to enjoy here.
P.S.: Note to myself - I’m slowly warming up to “pineapples” - um, the plural of pineapple, I guess... maybe also to “pineapple nuts” ;).

It's simply this DNA. I know it. Even if I may have never owned it myself, I've often smelled it and I like it. I want it! Mont Blanc Explorer has it! At least a sample of it. And that is my problem! Imagine it's a hot summer day and you're sitting in a restaurant in front of a really great pizza, of course with garlic. Then comes the thirst, the craving, and the desire for...

review_title: Inspired? Leaning? Imitated? - As long as it smells good!
review_content:
Unfortunately, I can't say anything about the similarity to Creed Aventus, as I haven't had the opportunity to test it yet. A comparison with Sauvage? - Well. I have to admit that I've received reactions about how good I smell like Dior Sauvage while wearing Explorer more than once. For an untrained nose, which is unfortunately (because I also think Sauvage is great) flooded by the world of young men wearing Sauvage, this is not objectionable. There is a certain similarity.
The opening of Explorer is slightly fruity and pleasant, which does fade a bit over time, but makes the further development of the scent - which heads towards Sauvage - a bit more playful and lighter. This is also the reason why I believe Explorer can definitely be worn during the day and on warmer days without leaving a "heavy" scent.
Visually, the bottle of Montblanc Explorer is definitely an eye-catcher! Sturdy, simple, and the artificial leather? really adds to it, especially suitable if you like to wear black.
Longevity and sillage could be better, but the scent experience for me is definitely a 10/10!

Final thought: Is it really that important whether a fragrance might be inspired by another or "imitated"? Perhaps for the perfumer, I won't dispute that. For me as a user? Definitely not! Because in the end, we all want to wear perfumes that we like!

review_title: Mass or Class, Mainstream or Niche?
review_content:
One thing you have to give to the Montblanc people: when they do something, they do it properly. And I mean really properly, typically German, I am inclined to say, and certainly with a penchant for perfection.

This starts with the writing instruments, which are not only visually impressive but also top-notch in their craftsmanship. When I first came into contact with the brand's watches, I was more than skeptical. However, I was quickly proven wrong after I had the chance to watch a watchmaker from the Swiss canton of Jura work while inserting the spring. Manufacture instead of Eta movement, great craftsmanship like that of the fountain pen nibs, so here too, no skimping but going all out. And then the first fragrances. At first, I was still on the track of "a strong brand that now wants to squeeze the last cent out of the consumer." But: I found the "Legend" convincing (and thus it found a place in my home), so I was quite curious about the "Explorer."

The Explorer starts a bit impetuously; the bergamot quickly gives way to a fine blend of leather and vetiver. And then Ambroxan spreads out, and quite a lot of it. You can like it or not; I do, and in combination with patchouli, I find the dry down simply well done.

Many say that it is all synthetic and therefore of inferior quality. Of course, Ambroxan is fully synthetic nowadays (and can, depending on which synthetic pathway was chosen, be of quite appealing quality). Ultimately, perfumes are products of experts in the laboratories of Givaudan, Firmenich, IFF..... anyone who has ever watched a chemist at work at these producers starts to wonder what we are spraying on ourselves daily and what kind of food we are putting into our bodies.

But, to return to the Explorer, these are not the cheap, inferior outputs from some reactors that equip so many shower gels with some scent, but here, brand-typical, they have approached it with a certain minimum requirement for quality. This is also reflected, for example, in the above-average longevity on my skin and a sillage that can let your surroundings know, hello, I have a new fragrance. The look and feel of the bottle are simple, elegant, and 100% brand-authentic.

My conclusion: A successful further excursion by Montblanc into the world of perfumes. Price-wise and qualitatively, in my opinion, it is exactly in the middle between niche and mainstream. A fragrance for every day, for every watch and time of day, for every occasion. That's already quite a lot. And typically customer-friendly, as mentioned above (the Montblanc people do it properly), they have also thought of a travel spray (30ml), which has also made its way directly into my carry-on trolley.

Montblanc-typical, simply really good.

review_title: Aventus without smoke, but with Ambroxan... a bumpy experience.
review_content:
A little rant: I don't understand why Montblanc decided on such a marketing move. Everything was actually going great!? Legend Spirit and Individual are, if we set aside the bottles, quite good fragrances in the designer sector. So why does Montblanc feel the need to copy Creed Aventus? I just don't get it.

The scent itself is, as has been mentioned in several other comments, a kind of mix between Aventus and Sauvage... at least in the drydown. Because to be fair, I must admit that in the first 90 minutes, there is hardly any Aventus present, and the parallels only show up later. It's as if I have a fruitier version of Aventus in front of me, where ambergris has been swapped for Ambroxan and where the smoke is missing or the woods have been toned down. Explorer starts fresh-spicy with a hefty dose of Ambroxan, then after a while, it increasingly shifts towards Aventus. Except for the hefty dose of Ambroxan, which remains very prominent for a long time.

For me, a lot of things just don't fit together. Aventus is so much finer and more balanced, more transparent and complex, and so beautifully LIGHT simply. This one never comes close for me. It just feels synthetic and cheap, the Ambroxan doesn't fit and is too present. Explorer is only worth a blind buy if the fragrance eventually falls into the same price segment as Legend or Individual. I hope I can get rid of it again without losing too much value... :-D

My buddy recently said to me: "Smell me, what do you think?" And I replied: "Did you finally buy Aventus?!" And he said: "I'm not a loser like you to spend €180 on a fragrance!" Long story short. It turned out to be Explorer by Montblanc, as he revealed to me afterward. I was astonished because I really smelled Creed at that moment. I then tried it in-store yesterday. So I...

That's it.
Over.
Final.

What has been troubling me for a while is now a fact. Aventus is mainstream and on its way to meet a similar fate as so many before it.

For years, I was infatuated with JPG Le Male in the 90s. When the wear became apparent, I satisfied my urge for individuality for years with Allure Homme Sport. And I had grown fond of Dior Homme Intense; it was my signature.

Aventus was my entry into niche fragrances; it had everything I was looking for: strong performance, unique DNA, and a scent that always fits.

Since I received Montblanc Explorer as a gift, I know that it's over. Anyone can buy Aventus now. And they will. My search starts all over again...

Explorer is from the start Aventus, with a bit more citrus and synthetics.
But the longevity and a bit more leather make it almost more interesting than the original.
I will continue to test it because I still like the composition. Only the pride and the feeling will be different from now on.

Goodbye King, it was a great time with you...

Liberté:
The freedom to develop a fragrance that should smell as the marketing suggests. Whether it is to be a 1:1 copy of the original or a "inspired" scent. As far as I know, everything is allowed when it comes to the pure fragrance. But now let's get to THIS scent.
Explorer opens with a juicy bergamot, pepper, and a small amount of sage (at least to my nose). I would describe the top note as fruity - fresh, and for untrained noses in the local perfumery, this is certainly a convincing argument. The heart note in the form of leather and vetiver quickly comes to the forefront, and the Eau de Parfum immediately feels a bit more masculine. In the base note, Ambroxan and Akigalawood join in. From this point on, it is supposed to smell like the one it is "inspired" by. In conclusion, it only feels dry and woody. The longevity on my skin is about 5.5 hours and the sillage is 1.5 hours. For an Eau de Parfum, I find the longevity a bit disappointing.

Égalité:
I wouldn't claim that Explorer is a clone, as it lacks many fragrance notes like the prominent pineapple, apple, and blackcurrant. The birch, which gives Aventus its slightly smoky note, is also missing. Nevertheless, one must admit that the drydown surprisingly reminds untrained noses of Aventus.

Fraternité:
Solidarity in the sense that more and more people wish for an Aventus for the slimmer wallet. Those who like this type of fragrance DNA can go for Explorer, as it is mass-appealing, unobtrusive, and affordable. It brings compliments and is a good all-rounder.
In conclusion, it must be noted that it cannot compete with Aventus. BUT it doesn't have to as a budget-friendly alternative.

review_title: The king is dead, long live the king
review_content:
If a perfume were to hold the status of "god-king" within the community, it would probably be Aventus.
You can feel however you like about it, as opinions are known to differ. However, each of us can still acknowledge the titan status of this rather fickle beauty.

But when a perfume is so good that the myth surrounding it calls forth an armada of imitations, that is indeed concerning. Aventus remains the most copied fragrance in the world, and the original is increasingly falling into disrepute.

Naysayers would claim that Creed, in their hubris, is summoning the downfall of their house, and they wouldn't be entirely wrong.

This brings us to Explorer, as there has never been a designer clone of Aventus, marking a milestone in the history of men's fragrances.
Regarding the scent itself:

Explorer starts with a combination of bergamot, ambroxan, and akigalawood, and when you look at these and other notes, you don't necessarily come to the conclusion of what is actually being attempted here.

No pineapple, no apple, no blackcurrant, and no birch tar, and yet: after the first sniff, I could have immediately told you what this is supposed to be.

Explorer is more synthetic than Aventus, of lower quality, but no less pleasing. The top notes are undeniably pleasant for untrained noses and a stroke of genius considering that "normal" customers do not wait for the heart and base notes, provided a fragrance does not unfold non-linearly.

As it dries down, the bergamot takes a backseat, and what emerges is a typically synthetic men's wood scent, like those found in every drugstore. It lacks everything that makes other clones something special.

The longevity is decent at 6-7 hours. After one to one and a half hours of mediocre projection, it transitions to a skin-close level. For a fresh scent at this price, that's quite alright.

It definitely makes an impression right away, especially in the first hour, but the longer you wear it, the more banal it becomes. I actually have enough "crowd-pleaser" fragrances that this one didn't really need to be there.

Explorer marks a turning point for me: Aventus is no longer a niche fragrance.
Even if the copy is meager, it is still a copy and indicates how much we have reached the end of the line here.

Aventus had a good decade, but perhaps we can now lay it to rest, let it enter the annals, and wait for the next holy "grail fragrance."

The king is dead, long live the king!

So where should I begin.. this fragrance will always be something special for me, as it was the reason I discovered my passion for perfumes. I was still very new to the perfume world, didn't know its predecessor Aventus or any other niche fragrances, and at the time I bought Explorer, I had no idea that this would be the start of a passion. I had already tested other great...

review_title: Why do people buy CDNIM when this one is available?
review_content:
So right off the bat, anyone who likes Aventus and is looking for a fragrance that represents the same kind of perfume and is generally a bit more approachable should go for this scent. I would say MB Explorer is not an exact copy but rather a really good fragrance.

I had CDNIM myself and I somewhat fell for the hype; at first, I thought it was soooo great, but no, Club de Nuit is the product of a HYPE and influencer scene that sells people a strong feeling and not a good product. CDNIM is one thing, and that is LOUD, which the original simply is not. I have a 2019 batch of Aventus at home, and I must say that CDNIM does hit some notes and overall is similar to Aventus, more so than the Explorer. As a musician myself, I want to make a comparison that targets the same mistake many buyers make with fragrances:

!!!!!LOUD IS NOT BETTER, IT'S JUST LOUDER!!!!

Many people buy ultra, extremely super bass headphones and speakers and associate that with good sound; if something is loud or extreme, then it is automatically better. But that's just not the case. Anyone who has heard a really good sound system with a well-produced song will notice that the bass, mids, and highs are all there, and indeed all of them are balanced and not overly exaggerated but just well mixed. Everything is clear and easily audible, and above all, you can hear every accent and every note without it being overshadowed by unnecessary bass thumping. So much for that......

And that’s exactly the issue with Club de Nuit Intense Man; Aventus has lemon/bergamot? Okay, we’ll throw everything we have in there, and while it may smell like mosquito spray, the CUSTOMER WANTS MORE, MORE, MORE and not good. Fine smoky aroma from birch? Okay, we just give the customer the feeling they are in the middle of a forest fire. Longevity? Well, then we’ll just skimp on the quality of the oils, for MORE, MORE, MORE!!!!! And every time someone walks by me wearing the scent, it smells like Aventus mixed with mosquito spray and toilet cleaner. And that’s the problem: fragrances/dupes should be as similar as possible and much longer-lasting than the original, but whether it’s a good fragrance in itself is irrelevant. In other words, if CDNIM existed but Aventus did not, no one would buy CDNIM. Because it’s simply not well blended. But precisely because there is Aventus and the hype, customers buy it because it is so much LOUDER (POWERRRR!!!!!!) than the original and cheaper. But sorry, the scent is really only decent after 5 hours, so I think, okay, that’s how I would wear it, still not a super awesome fragrance, but okay. The same goes for all the Dior Sauvage clones that smell like toilet sprays, but at least you can smell the person from 15 meters away, and they all smell the same with that one synthetic note.

Now to Mont Blanc Explorer. No annoying opening, pleasant citrus note, oh wow, even a slight pineapple, slightly woody, slightly herbal, and above all, smooooth. All notes are balanced; none overpower the others. Fresh, not heavy, pleasant, and yet not boring...... Summer 2024 can come. And the best part, in contrast to CDNIM, you actually get compliments with this one because it’s simply a good fragrance, so Creed Aventus as a designer fragrance, and that’s totally okay because it’s rounded and good without being unnecessarily expensive. And the best part is yet to come: I wear it more often than the original now because it fits everywhere. Disco, bar, gym, university, work,.....

Sorry, but CDNIM is just hype. Aaron Terence Hughes (a real perfumer) also made a video about all the Aventus clones, and he said that MB Explorer is simply nicer and rounder.

Similarity to Aventus: 70-80%
Scent: 9/10
Price: 10/10
Purchase recommendation: 100%

I have become a relatively new resident and a true fan of this community, and have been fascinated by great fragrances my whole life.
Now I want to write down my impressions, but about the Explorer, as there are already so many reviews about Aventus. However, I want to compare both fragrances.
I received the Explorer as a sample card, and was already impressed after the first test how much it reminded me of Aventus. I sprayed the fragrance for work, relatively little, but I could perceive the scent well throughout the day.
That's why I wanted to compare both fragrances, Aventus and Explorer, directly via test strips. I came to the following impressions...

For me, the Explorer starts off very strongly alcoholic. It has an almost piercing note.
From the typical Aventus scent, I can't perceive much on the test strip yet. Rather, almost nothing.
When I then sprayed Aventus on a test strip, this phenomenally wonderful fruity pineapple vibe immediately came through...simply outstanding.
I couldn't detect that with the Explorer.
Also, the overall presence and radiance of Aventus is much stronger. This characteristic of Aventus remains in the foreground, especially in the initial phase.
As time goes on...as I said on test strips, the characteristic scent of the Explorer slowly develops more. However, I notice another thing very strongly. And I can always pinpoint this with Creed fragrances. It is this wonderful creaminess. I’ll just call it that, because Aventus feels so soft and smooth compared to the Explorer.
This means that the Explorer is and remains simply more angular.
Nevertheless, the Explorer catches up over time. The scent becomes more tangible and present, which leads to a relative alignment of both fragrances as time goes on. At least according to my perception.
I think that the Explorer, when considered as a whole, definitely smells great. I also like it in terms of longevity and sillage. Even at the end of the day, I can still perceive it well.

To answer my headline, what remains of the day is a scent that is quite similar to Aventus, which is probably hardly distinguishable from the great original in everyday use. When you also consider the price component, I find the Explorer worth considering.
Nevertheless, I miss the presence, the glow, and also the creaminess of the original...

review_title: Similar to the original yet unique
review_content:
So, let me try my hand at my first comment.

I already have three fragrances (Legend, Legend Spirit, and Individuel) from Montblanc in my collection, of which the last two were blind buys. However, I like all three.
A few weeks ago, I discovered an advertisement for the new Explorer. I looked it up online and checked out its fragrance notes. My curiosity was piqued, and I quickly ordered it.
When it arrived, I immediately liked the bottle. Certainly, there are more beautiful and higher-quality ones, but this one is really well done by the creators at Montblanc.
But let's get to the scent itself.
From the very beginning, it smells very much like Aventus, which intensifies after a while. Towards the end, however, it develops its own unique scent note that sets it apart from Aventus. This is very pleasant and likable, as it does not merely represent a dupe scent but also has something of its own. As a dupe, I find it very successful, if not one of the best, even though it lacks the smoky note, which is not necessarily required.
The longevity and sillage are very solid. On me, the scent lasted 7-8 hours.
Price-performance ratio is top-notch.
In my opinion, a great new fragrance from Montblanc.

Often mentioned and recommended from the social media stage, and always referred to as a "clone" of the big brother from Creed, I couldn't help but give it a try.

I was quite familiar with the big brother and could never fully understand the hype surrounding it. Sure, Aventus has its charms ... but perhaps this scent just isn't for me, which is why I could only muster a shrug: "Nice enough, but not for that price." Stone me for that.

After work, I like to stroll into the usual fragrance shops. And then there was the frequently mentioned Explorer on the shelf next to all the other designer fragrances at a price that, due to its mentions, should be worth a test on the skin. I sprayed it on, and the opening immediately reminded me of its mentioned predecessor, but with a more citrusy twist. However, during the drive home, I had that typical scent moment, having to bring my wrist to my nose again and again to "sniff" - that is the crucial indicator for me when it comes to a purchase - the "wanting to smell it again" feeling versus all rationalities.

The Explorer is certainly inspired, but in my feeling, it is not a clone, but an independent fragrance. It is more reserved, subtle, and gentle. What I appreciate much more about it are its individual notes in the mid and dry down. Stone me a second time, but I would prefer the Explorer over its predecessor - completely independent of longevity, price, or anything similar. I simply like it more because it could evoke more than just a shrug.

In search of an everyday fragrance, I decided on a blind buy of this scent, which I managed to snag at a low price in a 30 ml travel bottle. And yet, it was a mistake.

The scent smells far too unnaturally artificial to me.

I don’t even want to describe the notes further because I smell dominant Ambroxan in all phases. I would even go so far as to question the expertise of anyone who considers this fragrance successful.

To end on a positive note: The idea of the fragrance is good. The notes used are sensibly combined, paving the way for a successful scent. However, in my opinion, it fails in its execution.

review_title: Lonely Peak of the Aventus Clones
review_content:
For me, this is by far the most pleasant of all Aventus clones. I would even go so far as to say that I prefer it to Aventus itself.

Why the best clone?

No overpowering citrus, but a pleasant, well-tolerated bergamot - which at no point is as piercing as the lemon in Armaf's Club de Nuit Intense, which never lets up throughout. In contrast, Montblanc Explorer: After the top note, the citrus subsides, which would also become too much for me in the long run, and a pleasant fresh-smoky note develops, which occasionally reminds me of the scent concept behind Dior Sauvage.

So: Less "Club de Nuit" shouting, better to reach for this far more tolerable fragrance.

review_title: Creed Aventus, Dior Sauvage or Zara Vibrant Leather?
review_content:
Just a day ago, I secured a sample of Creed Aventus. Yesterday, I was in Düsseldorf and had the chance to pick up Montblanc Explorer at a bargain price to compare it with my other clones.

The surprise is that it smells like a copy of a copy. To my nose, it smells like Zara's Vibrant Leather! If you want to be precise (Sauvage + Vibrant Leather + a bit of smoke)

For those looking for an Aventus copy, I clearly recommend Club de Nuit or Rasasi pour Lui Zebra. This scent, while similar to Aventus, is more of a knockoff of a knockoff, which, by the way, still smells pretty good.

review_title: A copy is never as good as the original
review_content:
I bought the fragrance a year ago in the hope of finding a cheaper alternative to Creed Aventus.
The opening is very reminiscent of Aventus and quickly convinced me. A third of the price and no difference to be recognized?! Well... too early to celebrate: Because in the drydown, Explorer gains (or rather loses) its individuality and develops a strange, cheap-chemical bite.
The more often I wore the fragrance, the more this "chemical bomb" bothered me. Even as a standalone scent, I wouldn't be able to recommend this Montblanc.

Bottle/ Packaging:
Wow, what a great presentation. Montblanc really doesn't have to hide here. A very high-quality looking bottle rounded off by a heavy, anthracite-colored cap. The spray button works excellently and sprays what I consider to be just the right amount of the content.

The fragrance:
The opening is very fruity and, a rascal who thinks ill, just like Creed Aventus. That's how you catch buyers... unfortunately, like me too.
However, the drydown is very chemical in nature and at least has its own scent character. However, it doesn't come across as particularly high-quality. The longevity is decent for a fresh scent, though not outstanding. The price/performance ratio is still good.

Conclusion:
For "just going shopping" or as a cheap all-rounder, Explorer by Montblanc is not a bad choice.
However, no miracles are to be expected, and it is definitely not an alternative to Aventus.
Especially the bottle is excellently designed and makes a statement. In the end, however, the content is decisive, and here it fails due to the unfortunately very piercing chemical bomb at the end of the opening.

Yes, amateurs love this scent!! While fragrance enthusiasts are indecisive and argue about the chemistry of the scent, some regular person out there is falling in love with it. Montblanc Explorer is my best-selling fragrance, but why is that?

The Explorer simply smells masculine and fresh to me, yet still diverse. It has a really good sillage and longevity that is definitely above average. Additionally, it comes in a nice, high-quality bottle, and last but not least, the truly unbeatable price; you can get this for about 30 euros for 60ml, which is really impressive for a perfume with this performance from a designer house that usually offers writing materials, backpacks, etc. for several thousand euros.

I was able to test the new fragrance from Montblanc - Explorer - on Saturday; the name promised a lot, the packaging and the bottle are appealing, and the sweet smile of the turquoise Mademoiselle, who praised the scent in the highest terms, promised something as well - so I applied the fragrance to my wrist and off we go; I reached for a tissue, just like with Dior's Sauvage, an ambroxan overdose that unfortunately overshadows and kills the entire fragrance, leaving a sharp sensation in the nose; otherwise, Explorer starts off citrusy and slightly spicy and later becomes a 1:1 copy of the highly praised Aventus by Creed, although not as rounded, but that is probably due to the ambroxan - I am happy for young people who do not want to spend so much money on a fragrance in the price range of Aventus, they have here a perfect fragrance twin that caters to the mainstream and has the potential to be a real hit; unfortunately for me personally, it's the wrong direction, as I am not such a big fan of Aventus either.

The Montblanc Explorer starts off fresh upon application and quickly develops into a woody Ambroxan bomb. And bomb is really the keyword here, as the sillage is brutal. I was asked outdoors from about 1 meter away, 4 hours (!) after applying (two sprays on the neck, one behind each ear, and one in each elbow), what that wonderfully fragrant scent was and if I had showered in...

I actually just wanted to write a statement, but then I ran out of characters and wanted to get a few more things off my chest.

Explorer is, for me, a slightly herbaceous spring or summer fragrance that has an above-average longevity for a fresh scent. The fragrance itself is rather simple, but just right for my workday. From the notes, I mainly smell bergamot at first, and later Akigalawood and Ambroxan. I don't smell the sage or the cocoa at all.

Unfortunately, I had to realize in the last few days, when it finally got a bit warmer, that the Ambroxan became very overpowering and the other notes were hardly noticeable. Now I will probably only wear Explorer on cloudy days and likely relegate it to the bench in the summer.

Everyone knows it - almost everyone appreciates it: Explorer by Montblanc is an excellent copy of Aventus. Above all, it is affordable and of consistent quality.

Recently, I had L´Aventur by Al Haramain, which I found relatively decent. However, Explorer seems to me to be significantly more refined, rounder, and a bit richer.

It starts with the lemon, which here refreshes with a slightly spritzier note, then merges into a pleasant symbiosis of synthetic background noise including Ambroxan with the other fragrance notes that are hardly distinguishable and should probably not be taken 1:1 according to the pyramid.
In between, spicy and especially fruity-fresh nuances sparkle.
Sage and vetiver components are possible, but hardly anyone would sniff them out without assistance. The same goes for patchouli, but leather and cocoa are present only in homeopathic doses. It doesn't matter, because everyone is reminded of Aventus, even if neither pineapple nor blackcurrant are mentioned.

Thus, Explorer forms a crisp summer refresher with absolute justification. One could argue whether well-copied is better than poorly composed oneself. I like it - not only because it elicits positive reactions, but because it is a pleasant companion for hot days and tropical nights. Explorer is not a classic feel-good fragrance in that sense, yet the Inner Compass appreciates it.

After recommendations from various YouTubers and good reviews, I went on an "exploration."
I got a sample and off I went.
With the first spray on my arm, my nose sensed a sense of well-being. It smelled fresh and a bit like pineapple, I liked what I smelled. After a 30-minute walk, I wanted to smell my arm again, but I couldn't smell anything anymore. At first, I thought I had forgotten where I had sprayed the stuff because I couldn't believe it. No matter how hard my nose tried, the scent was gone after 30 minutes. I tested the fragrance again at Müller, but once again, the scent was gone after 30 minutes. For others, it seems the scent lasts longer on the skin, but that's not the case for me. Unfortunately, it's a disappointment for me, even though I quite like the fragrance.

review_title: You smell good! Oh yes, you smell good... wow, you really smell good!
review_content:
Hello friends,

Yesterday, my wife gifted me this perfume for my birthday. I smelled it and was immediately fascinated because it reminded me a bit of Dior Sauvage. Since I have that at home too, I compared both and was surprisingly struck by how much I preferred the Explorer. My wife made a good choice :)
Well then: this morning at 10, I had to go to the doctor to pick up my sick note for work. As always, I had to put on a fragrance, so I decided on the Explorer. When I arrived there, I naturally had to go for the consultation and promptly received the first compliment from the doctor. Of course, I thanked her and continued on my way to work to submit the sick note.
