Now, about the scent itself, it starts off very citrusy and artificial, with the bergamot coming through nicely. The pepper makes its presence known, and you can tell that ambroxan is in there. I can't pick out much more. At the same time, it reminds me a bit of aftershave, in a positive way. Although I would describe the scent development as very linear, it becomes slightly softer and almost creamier over time. Nevertheless, you get exactly what you smell when you spray it on. There's not much scent evolution. I don't detect any leather or cocoa.

Conclusion: I would buy it again and again, great price-performance ratio, fits in almost any situation, and is also a good entry-level fragrance.

Regarding the Aventus topic: The explorer lacks the pineapple and is not smoky. Otherwise, there is a similarity. Still, it is a standalone fragrance.

review_title: He is it, but also not... maybe he is?
review_content:
Just to clarify, he is not really Creed Aventus.
You could probably tell some people who are not that knowledgeable about perfumes that it is Creed Aventus, but that’s about it.
My girlfriend personally loves this scent and I use it as a ''Straight Outta the Shower'' fragrance, as well as for non-special occasions, like the office.
Nothing special, but also not wrong.
I managed to snag 60ML for 21.00 euros, you can't complain about that.

Now to the scent composition:

It starts fresh with bergamot and pink pepper and then transitions into a robust blend of vetiver and leather.
The dry down is warm and pleasant thanks to ambroxan and a hint of cocoa... (cocoa if you really get into it ;-))

A modern man smells like this. MB Explorer is an absolutely brilliant fragrance; the beginning is very fruity with orange. You can imagine a glass of freshly squeezed orange juice, really phenomenal. After that, the scent develops into a woody note, but always remains fresh. I have had the fragrance for a while now and have experienced a lasting power of about 6-8 hours each time, and it logically lasts even longer on clothing. But for me, this longevity is ideal because you smell good during the day and in the late afternoon, no one at the gym is bothered by your scent. The fragrance is generally suitable year-round, but I see it as a scent for moderate temperatures in autumn/spring.

I discovered this scent at an airport and sprayed it on for testing, but the fresh synthetic opening didn't excite me much at first.

At that time, I was not familiar with Aventus or any other niche fragrances and didn't know that it was inspired by something.

Shortly after, on the plane, I realized I couldn't keep my nose away from my wrist; the scent developed very well and was then ordered immediately at a very reasonable price.
I had a similar enthusiasm back then with Sauvage EDT; apparently, I like Ambroxan.

Now that I know exactly what the scent is and have also tested others like Rumz and CDNI, I must say that Explorer is my favorite on most days.

It avoids the extremely smoky notes and is thus a good all-rounder that I can wear on warmer days.

For me, it’s basically an Aventus that is "even more mainstream" and perfectly suited for Western noses.

The longevity for me is a good 8 hours, during which it projects nicely.
I also like the bottle itself, and the sprayer is okay.

For the price, it's a no-brainer for anyone who enjoys this fragrance DNA! :)

For me, this is truly an all-around solid scent. It won't blow anyone away or particularly surprise them, nor does it need to. Especially not for the price.
It is often said that it has the Aventus DNA, and I must say, yes, there is definitely a resemblance. Since Aventus is personally too expensive for me, but I still wanted to know how similar the two are, I sprayed Aventus in a perfume shop and compared it at home.
In the opening, I think you can smell most of the differences. The Explorer lacks the distinctive pineapple, which I actually find very nice in Aventus and miss just a little bit. It is lightly peppery fresh, paired with bergamot. Overall, a very nice fresh start.
In the drydown, however, the differences become less apparent in my opinion. It is somewhat more synthetic, but completely acceptable for the price. My girlfriend thinks I smell like a needle forest. I don't find it that extremely woody or smelling of pine needles, but I understand the thought. The Explorer is definitely woody, no question, but there is also a bit of leather that rounds it off very nicely.
You can tell that the Explorer is inspired by Aventus, but it is not a 1:1 clone.
The sillage is unfortunately a bit disappointing, but that also makes it a good scent for the office or sports, especially since it is not an overpowering fragrance that should offend anyone. On the contrary. I have even received compliments for the Explorer!
In my opinion, a good, affordable alternative to Aventus. Those looking for a bit more performance might want to reach for the Arabic clones, like Club de Nuit Intense, although I must say I haven't been able to test it myself yet.

The Explorer is actually available in almost every perfume shop, so anyone who wants to test it should be able to do so everywhere. I think even a blind buy is justifiable here due to the price. However, one shouldn't expect too much. It's simply a well-rounded fragrance, unfortunately with weak performance ):

As already seen in the title above, Montblanc Explorer can be worn at any time.

I must honestly admit that the scent did not impress me much at first. But as it often happens, I have come to appreciate it. It is particularly pleasant when it lightly lingers in the air after the drydown. Explorer has something clean about it; at its heart, it is clearly masculine due to the combination of some woodiness and leather, quite citrusy in the top note.

Associations with pineapple are definitely present, even though it is not listed in the fragrance pyramid. Consequently, it also reminds me a bit of Aventus. I can definitely agree with my predecessors on the point that Explorer is not as smoky as Aventus. I think this makes Explorer even more suitable for any situation.

I find the bottle really beautiful. I have the 30ml version, and it is just a real pleasure to hold.

I got the fragrance for 24 euros including shipping. It was also a blind buy. I would buy it again.

The fragrance opens with fresh citrus notes that create a lively and energetic atmosphere. At the heart of the scent, there are spicy notes of bergamot and pepper that add depth and character to the fragrance.

The finale of the scent consists of deep and woody notes of vetiver, leather, and patchouli, giving it a masculine and seductive touch. Overall, I would describe the fragrance as woody-aromatic, and I think it is especially suitable for men looking for a scent that reflects their adventurous spirit and the essence of discovery.

I wore the fragrance at work, and many of my colleagues noticed it and were taken by it. I rated the performance as average, but still sufficient for everyday wear. Overall, I would say that Montblanc Explorer is a solid fragrance.

Every time I smell the bottle, it whispers softly in my ear: “Take me to the office!” I would never wear Explorer on a date. But I would wear it when sitting across from my boss and saying, “Trust me, I’ve got the project under control!” Explorer is, for me, the epitome of seriousness and grooming.

It has a certain spiciness and sharpness that creates a polite distance from the other person (hence also unsuitable for a date). At the same time, however, a subtle sweetness sneaks in, preventing one from appearing aloof and grumpy. It is a formal invitation that says, “Feel free to come by, but don’t feel at home. My house is my house.”

Therefore, Explorer might not only be unsuitable for a date but is generally more of a scent for formal occasions. Anyone wearing Explorer in their free time might give the impression of either having a stick up their a** or being forced to try to be perceived as particularly serious by others. (No offense to anyone who wears Explorer in their free time; you still smell good!)

In summary, Explorer is the perfect scent for things like: the office, the baptism of a nephew/niece, the wedding of a not-so-intimate acquaintance, a funeral, or the opera.

Addendum: A review is always subjective and based on the perception of the reviewer. Therefore, please do not take statements personally or generalize them to all people. Every statement should actually begin with “Within the horizon of my perception…” But then reviews would be unreadable.

review_title: The Rider in the Shadow of the White Mountain
review_content:
The fragrance brings a pleasant freshness that feels modern and versatile. At the same time, it is harmoniously balanced and feels rounder than the expensive model. It is a scent that can be worn almost anywhere.
Montblanc Explorer impresses mainly with its excellent price-performance ratio. For me, it is not just a cheaper alternative, but better than its more famous counterpart with the rider.
Overall, a clear recommendation for anyone looking for a high-quality, fresh, and masculine scent without having to dig deep into their pockets.

I personally perceive the scent for a maximum of 2 hours. In my opinion, it doesn't matter that the fragrance is sometimes available for just ~60 euros per 200!!! ml. Otherwise, it is a pleasant citrus scent, but you can't really find anything special about it. Just test it out in person. I must say that there are significantly better alternatives - like Turathi...

review_title: No alternative to Aventus …but I find this one better
review_content:
So it happened that I stayed over at a friend's place yesterday, woke up today, took a shower, and was just about to leave the house with him on our way to school. Just before I was about to put on my jacket, he spontaneously asked me if I wanted to spray on one of his perfumes for a moment. Of course, I couldn't pass that up. Instinctively, I reached for Explorer, but with low expectations, as the performance of most, including my friend, was rated as not very impressive. Following his instructions, I sprayed on three spritzes. The scent was very good at first, but also very subtle.
Half an hour later came the surprise; suddenly, an immense cloud of fragrance enveloped me, which didn't seem to fade away. My friend shared this surprise; the scent had never performed so well on him. Even now, 9 hours later, the scent is still wafting around; at least in terms of performance, it is ten times better than Aventus.

However, I think that the two fragrances can be compared in very few other areas; they differ too much. In the drydown, I smell a lot of pepper in Explorer, while Aventus, for me, tends to fade away with a creamy scent. The first 20 minutes are admittedly very similar, but after that, the two fragrances go in very different directions. Interestingly, I prefer the development of Explorer much more than that of Aventus.

P/L is excellent. Performance is at least 10 hours with a sillage of initially 2 meters and later (after my 9 hours so far) just under a meter.

I mainly wear Montblanc Explorer as an everyday scent when I don't feel like overthinking what would suit me best today. It smells fresh and clean, yet it is not characterless like some other aquatic fragrances. Overall, especially for the price, it's quite a no-brainer.

Montblanc Explorer... This fragrance was recommended to me a while ago, but I never really had any interest in it. One day, while helping a woman at a Douglas store to arrange a few bottles, she gave me 2 perfume testers as a thank you. Jpg le Male le Parfum and Montblanc Explorer. I then tested it a few times and realized that it simply fits into every conceivable life...

The Aven… I mean Explorer is a beautiful perfume that stands out with its fresh and spicy notes. The top note is dominated by notes that immediately unfold a refreshing and invigorating effect. A hint of pepper gives the fragrance a subtle sharpness and makes it the …
… yes, the Aventus!
There’s not much more to say about this awesome scent. The affordable Aventus par excellence. Light smoke paired with a citrusy freshness that makes everyone take a second look. Perfectly suited as a signature scent. Montblanc has done a great job here.

Now I feel compelled to write the first review, unfortunately not from a positive motivation. I got the Explorer last year based on so many recommendations and found it great as a daily scent or for the office. I was even complimented on it, which is rather rare for me. Since this year the bottle ran out and the price is still very attractive, I naturally ordered another bottle, this time even the 100ml (last time only the 60ml). Unpacked, sprayed on, 1 to 2 hours later...nothing. There was nothing left of the scent except for the biting/stinging smell that often remains with fresh cheap perfumes due to their longevity (I think that’s Ambroxan or something, feel free to correct me). That was not the case with my old bottle at all, I really can't stand that. What a disappointment, I have no idea if I just had bad luck with the purchase, but if the new batch performs like this in terms of scent quality and performance, the Explorer is unfortunately dead to me. It was really solid, a coherent overall package, but as it is now, I don’t think it can be recommended anymore.

review_title: A great companion for everyday life!
review_content:
The Explorer definitely belongs to the category of fragrances that can be worn effortlessly in any season and for any occasion! It's like a Swiss Army knife among perfumes.

It is a very fresh and very clean scent, quite pleasant, but nothing that really blows me away personally.

It's an average scent similar to Dior Sauvage, Versace Eros, or Acqua di Gio, fragrances that everyone seems to wear these days. It's not a bad scent, but nothing groundbreaking, and it's a fragrance that you can often smell outdoors in pedestrian zones or while waiting in line at the supermarket. It has definitely become very mainstream, to put it briefly.

I don't want to speak poorly of the scent because it is by no means bad.

It smells very citrusy, slightly fruity with a hint of wood and a touch of leather.

The scent is definitely a safe blind buy and an ideal entry into the world of perfumes.

In terms of price, the fragrance is an absolute steal; the 30ml starter size can sometimes be found for under €30, and the largest size of 100ml for under €60. For a designer brand, that's definitely a statement.

The scent is very similar to the very expensive Aventus, but here you get a fragrance that is strikingly similar to Aventus and costs only a fraction of that!

All in all, a successful flanker, but as mentioned, quite mainstream, and there are definitely better alternatives that stand out a bit more from the crowd.

By chance, I came across a bottle of Explorer. To start with the positives, the scent is worth noting given the moderate price.
It is a nice, not overly intrusive fragrance with pleasant fruity notes, a bit of citrus, and a hint of woodiness - a friendly men’s scent that doesn’t immediately veer into "smoky" or "leathery" territory.
The fragrance can be worn by young and old alike, and it is also suitable as a subtle companion for the office, not being disturbing or even intrusive.

A bit critical is the relatively short longevity of the scent. The composition at the beginning does come off as somewhat artificial-alcoholic, which is probably also due to the price. I don’t see this perfume as a real competitor to "Aventus." Aventus is clearly the more upscale fragrance for the businessman in a suit and tie (if one can describe it that way) with better essences that come together beautifully, are a bit "smokier," and last significantly longer.

Despite this, Explorer is a fragrance that can be used every day and for any occasion, even for the younger generation.
It is not too harsh-smoky in the dry down, but offers a nice blend of fruity yet typically masculine scent notes with Ambroxan. The perfume will definitely remain in my collection, as it is universally applicable, possibly also for layering with other perfumes that bring a bit more masculine touch and longevity.

Montblanc Explorer opens for me with a lightly peppery freshness, immediately accompanied by a fruity pineapple note. The scent feels modern, elegant, and pleasantly dynamic. Unfortunately, the Explorer smells too synthetic to me overall, and the longevity is too short at 4 hours. A Prada Luna Rosa Carbon is better suited for everyday wear and comes without the artificial pineapple scent.

Guys, the scent is great.

Many women have already commented on it. Ladies love it.

Longevity is so-so. Overspray is a must.

The opening was even better a few years ago - much fruitier.

Still a banger.

I don't compare it to Aventus. They obviously go in the same direction [fresh, woody, masculine], otherwise they smell completely different to me.

review_title: Good scent for a low price
review_content: Very masculine sexy scent with freshness of citrus and spices balanced with woods and tonka beans. Performances are average, not bad, not beast. You can find it 55€/100 ml on discounters websites so it's a very good price. Very versatile not too fresh, not too loud, you can wear it all year long (but better fall and spring I think) for any occasion. Nothing revolutionary but a good scent for a low price.

review_title: Why It’s Sometimes Better to Throw Your Identity Overboard
review_content:
Many designer interpretations of modern, maximally successful fragrances (Sauvage EAU DE TOILETTE, Aventus) copy, excuse me, orient themselves to their role models, but with a few minor adjustments, especially at the beginning. Sometimes this works better (Authentic Man, Explorer, Luna Rossa Carbon), sometimes less so (MCM Onyx). Sometimes it goes completely wrong. Sometimes it would have been better to just copy the foundation outright.

Legend Red starts fresh, clinically citrusy, sour, and slightly woody. This clinical synthetic quality bothers me immensely and has something of a cleaning product (but not of the pleasant kind). At this point, I am (still) very disappointed with the fragrance, which is referred to as a hidden gem by some YouTubers.
After about half an hour, the tide turns: The cedar now comes to the forefront, grapefruit and blood orange, which are so poorly executed here, recede much further into the background, and - Sauvage comes to the fore. Yes, that’s right, Legend Red incorporates a decent portion of the successful designer DNA from 2015 in the drydown (albeit without pepper). At this point, I begin to like the fragrance.
However, it is already too late for the overall rating; the creepy start cannot be redeemed by the progression.

In addition, the performance is mixed. While the fragrance lasts a solid 7 hours on my skin, the sillage leaves much to be desired right from the first spray, and on the other hand, it loses much of its already low projection power after just an hour and a half. The price is very reasonable, but this is also reflected in the performance.
The bottle, lastly, is the typical one from the Legend series in fiery red. I’m not particularly fond of the basic shape; it’s a bit spartan and looks somewhat dated in my opinion, but otherwise it’s okay. The bright color, in my opinion, rather enhances the impression of being old-fashioned.

A solid fragrance for everyday and sports, but not extraordinary, and one should first get used to the start.

Blood orange and grapefruit in the top note. Not boring but also not interesting, just pleasant enough not to be stared at by everyone in the room.
-not at all intrusive-
I wore the fragrance on a hot summer morning. After half an hour, the juniper berries came through. The woody notes in the base were hardly noticeable to me, and the scent remained rather fresh. Unfortunately, the overall impression of the fragrance was marred by a synthetic note that made it seem somewhat cheap. Even in a closed room, I could only perceive the scent on my skin after two hours (with 4 sprays).

Presence is a a well blended scent from the house of Montblanc. It is a very pleasing fragrance and holds some similarities to L'Homme by Yves Saint Laurent. I find it well balanced by Corinne Cachen. The scent opens with cinnamon, apple and some ginger. Once the scent settles down some of the other notes start to come through a little more. Presence is a very fresh and clean and is very versatile and it could be worn in any occasion and is ideal for the workplace.

The longevity is slightly above average on my skin, Projection is decent but subtle. I like the the bottle design but the only negative is the cap on the bottle appears to be a very loose when closed and comes off easily. This is only a minor issue.

Overall a solid 7.5/10

review_title: I like it, I don't love it.
review_content:
Alright, I just got this today. On first sniff I've smelled it before. It reminds me of my school bus driver from back in the day, Mid 90s. I like it. I don't love it. I did spray it on one arm about 5 hours ago and I still smell it, and get whiffs as I walk around the house. It is very much a sweet shaving cream type smell. Its not bad. I think longevity on my skin will be decent. I do not think I can pull this off in the heat though. Might be overpowering. To me, this is a fall and winter scent.
j

Montblanc Presence smells classy and refined.

Despite being subtle, it has a good staying power and okay projection.

I smell lots of cinnamon with spices and ginger, all over a vanilla base.

Updated January 2014

Montblanc is one of my favorite brands when it comes to price-performance ratio. At the top is the berry scent Individuel, which has a large fanbase. Additionally, there is the Fierce-like scent Legend or Legend Intense. Emblem, Starwalker, and this one are less known but still very good fragrances from this brand. They all have one thing in common: great performance, high-quality scent, and a low price. Where others charge a lot of money, you can get these fragrances for around 30 euros. Classy. The stationery from this brand is quite expensive and more for business people, while the fragrances, in my opinion, lean more towards the casual range.

I bought this fragrance this year. 75ml for around 30 euros. Well-spent money for fans of sweet and fruity scents. Even though it states that production has been discontinued, the fragrance is still readily available. And that's a good thing. An interesting scent that stands out from many. Really a nice blend of heavy-light. It starts with a powerful dose of cinnamon and ginger. Rather on the heavier side. But not too heavy, as bergamot, apple, and sage give it a nice freshness. However, those who do not like cinnamon or ginger should steer clear of this scent. Heliotrope is also present, and it's a note that I really like. Woods and a lovely sweetness from tonka complete the rest and round off the fragrance well. Very pleasant and delicious creation. It slightly reminds me of my first self-purchased fragrance Bruno Banani Man, which I loved and still like very much today. Not a twin, as Presence is truly unique with a high recognition value. A big plus point, as you don't often smell such fragrances and could receive some compliments if you care about that.
The performance is also very good, like all Montblancs. The sillage is really pleasant and just right. Especially in the first hours. Over time, it diminishes a bit, but still remains in a pleasant range. The longevity is also good with many hours.

Overall, Presence is a really beautiful fragrance with a lot of recognition value. Especially between 10 and 20 degrees, it is a truly lovely transitional scent that I really enjoy. This fragrance is really inexpensive and offers a lot for it. Highly recommended!

Montblanc Présence has been on my watch list for a while, and since the high summer seems to be coming to an end, I thought it was about time to start looking for a new autumn/winter fragrance.
So I went through my "fragrance to-do list" and ultimately found myself irresistibly drawn to Présence. Even though the scent is classified as a year-round fragrance, I associate cinnamon, cardamom, vanilla, and woody notes more with the colder season. Unfortunately, it seems that the production of the perfume has been discontinued, so it ended up being another blind buy. However, since I have generally liked every Montblanc fragrance so far and the notes used here match my taste quite closely, my fear wasn't too great.
A few days ago, the fragrance finally arrived, and I must say that I really cannot understand how one could discontinue the production of such an amazing scent.
The top note is characterized by a fruity-apple-cinnamon note and, due to the clearly present sweetness, somehow reminds me of the candied apples from the fair (in a positive way). In the middle, the vanilla becomes more pronounced, and after a while, the woody notes dominate, just as you would expect from the fragrance pyramid :)
Unfortunately, both sillage and longevity are a slight drawback for me. Présence tends to be perceived as very close to the skin quite quickly unless I apply it quite generously. The same goes for longevity. With "normal" use, I find myself somewhere between 4-5 hours. Especially with autumn/winter fragrances, one hopes for a bit more. At 25€/75ml, I can easily forgive that for the perfume. If in doubt, you can always just reapply after a while :D
All in all, I can truly recommend Présence to anyone looking for a somewhat more unusual (since lesser-known) fragrance away from the mainstream.

I haven't worn this fragrance in fact for much more than 15 years. For various reasons.... To be honest, I even gave away the fragrance (98 out of 100 ml) back then. I just couldn't wear it. Not anymore. It was the last fragrance my father gave me for Christmas before he passed away. My father put so much thought into what gift I would like. After all, he knew exactly...

Just because I was so enthusiastic about Mont Blanc's Individuel, it was time to test another creation from the luxury brand. And since the price was right and I had never seen it in stores for testing, I ordered it blind online in the 50 ml version. Unfortunately, it was not delivered in the nicer snow globe version, Mont Blanc seems to have changed that. But it still looks beautiful, and the bottle reminds me of the Individuel bottle, with the turquoise liquid shimmering nicely.

The scent is certainly unique in its composition, not everyday, and I have never smelled anything like it before. Fortunately, I tend more towards the above average note than to Joe's below comment. But I must say I like both fruity and very sweet as well as fresh perfumes. And Presence lies exactly in the triangle of these 3 characteristics. It is cinnamon and slightly spicy. It also has something refreshingly summery, almost aquatic. Cinnamon and water sounds like an acquired taste, but it is much more pleasant and could even appeal to the mainstream audience. However, Presence lacks the recognition it deserves due to its courage and uniqueness. The third strong component is the sweet and citrusy fruits that round off the scent. Namely apple and bergamot. Very delicious, likeable, and digestible. However, one must be into sweet scents, as both the fruit sugar content and the vanilla finish are sweet and youthful. At times I thought it could be good for the office, but it might be a bit too sweet after all. More of a casual scent!

The bottle is, as mentioned, typically stylish Mont Blanc, and anyone who even gets the snow globe should not hesitate long. Due to the sweetness, the sillage is strong, almost leaning towards a going-out scent and is similar to the popular Original Santal clone. The longevity is very good, typical for vanilla finishes, you get a long wear out of it!

Not at the level of Individuel, but very solid and versatile. And you stand out from the crowd!

review_title: Representing all (old) Montblancs: a true delight!
review_content:
I mentioned elsewhere that I only became aware of Montblanc as an EDT manufacturer through Parfumo. At Douglas or in duty-free shops, this brand has never been recommended to me. I don't even know if they were ever in stock. Unfortunately, with Legend and Emblem along with their flankers, there are only two fragrances left in the current offering. Presence is unfortunately no longer included, nor are Starwalker and Individuel! :-(

Presence can still be ordered for little money. I paid 35 euros for 75 ml. Like the other mentioned fragrances, this scent impresses me with a finely balanced fruitiness that I have only detected in a few perfumes so far. The sillage is by no means intrusive, but still noticeable for several hours at about half an arm's length, especially when sitting at the computer in the office and casually moving my nose towards the keyboard! ;-)

I want to write about Montblancs in general here - also because I am not a "perfume sommelier." Legend is certainly the most mass-compatible scent (a kind of fougère), Starwalker the freshest, Individuel the fruitiest, and Presence the sweetest. I find them all fascinating and very distinctive! Only Legend Spirit disappointed me, and Emblem seems to me, based on the reviews, to be too sweet-gourmand.

I am simply thrilled by the perfect balance of the (old) Montblanc fragrances (including Legend) and of course the excellent price-performance ratio. None of them comes across as overpowering or intrusive! The sweetness is not too cloying, the freshness not too fleeting, the fruitiness not too one-dimensional, and the fougère not too mainstream. Perhaps it was good that four different perfumers were involved here, each able to showcase their own signature, with the briefing perhaps stating: "Do something unique, but remain brand-compatible. We like it original, but not too extreme! We stand for high class, but not for decadence!" ;-)

In any case, I am delighted by the discovery of four wonderful fragrances that are absolutely suitable for everyday wear yet still have their own distinct character. And to return to Presence: Even when you read apple, cardamom, and cinnamon: Let yourself be surprised! It has little to do with the Christmas market... unless Christmas Eve is moved to summer and there's a roller coaster involved! ;-)

What am I reading here? Blindbuy Superstar, a true delight, an extraordinary fragrance that you don't come across every day.
Yes, folks, when I first get a whiff of such a scent, it truly is exceptional. But I want to write a bit about it. Ginger and bergamot are not the number 1 in the top notes; the ginger is more noticeable of the two, while the cinnamon - logically - is prominent and lingers down to the base, but fades towards the end. The apple, which firmly establishes itself in the middle, actually plays its role in the top notes. In the further drydown, as Presence approaches its end, which unfortunately comes a bit too soon, a slight restlessness emerges that tries to break the sweetness or take away its one-dimensionality. At this point, I find it hard to say whether it’s due to the sage or the bone-dry teak wood; I would tend to lean towards the teak wood.

For the price, it’s certainly something nice. But it’s not that extraordinary, as I have at least 2 fragrances in my repertoire that shoot in the same direction as Presence. The former would be RDLC from the British label Lee Cooper. Both fragrances are quite similar; however, the more successful variant is Presence, especially since RDLC has a musty, piercing note of dry willow and lime wood that perhaps a woodcarver might appreciate, but no true fragrance lover would seriously enjoy.
Another fragrance that goes in this direction was O Boticario Onix, which I loved very much. However, here the Brazilian has the upper hand, as this one is based on the crisp, tart green apple and is overall more multifaceted and spicier.
And even a classic and true nose-pleaser like Boss Soul is not entirely dissimilar to Presence, although it cannot be called a scent twin of Presence.

So, I’ve somewhat torpedoed the uniqueness of Presence, but that doesn’t mean that Presence is bad. I wouldn’t equate it with Spice Bomb, as happened in one of the comments; that’s a different ballpark.

Despite being "discontinued," Presence has a decisive advantage: unlike RDLC, Onix, and Soul, this one is easily obtainable and at moderate prices!

review_title: You have to try it once
review_content:
Right from the start, I stumbled upon MB Presence and then bought an almost full bottle at a great price here on Parfumo.

First, about the bottle: It is simple, elegant, and the color of the liquid looks really delicious. Like a green apple that you want to bite into, and I had exactly that sour feeling in my mouth when I saw it for the first time. Unfortunately, the cap is a bit wobbly, but that's not a big deal.

Upon the first spray, a sharp, peppery, synthetic apple note hit me. It reminds me of Proraso Aftershave from that big bottle.
This sharpness fades away quite quickly, and you feel the transition to sweet apple and mild cinnamon, which actually holds on until the end before it transitions into an Ambroxan blend. So, not really spectacular.

Overall, it's a nice freshie that you can actually wear for any occasion throughout the year. In winter after a shower, in summer as a daily fragrance, but like many in this price range, it doesn't last long, which is why I will probably use it up and not repurchase.
One shouldn't expect much development. But for €15 you can get the bottle new, and that's quite reasonable.

review_title: So present it is unfortunately not... But delicious all the same!
review_content:
I stumbled upon a nicely full Présence at a very good price during a group order at the Souk. The fragrance pyramid didn't blow me away, as the well-known combination of sweet, fruity, and spicy notes is anything but spectacular. But in the end, it was interesting enough to take the plunge, which was certainly also due to the good reviews here.

Upon the first spray, I was pleasantly surprised, as Présence starts off significantly spicier than expected. The fruity-fresh sweetness sneaks in later into the mix. The combination of apple, cinnamon, and ginger somewhat reminds me of licorice, but in a good way. Those who enjoy smoking shisha will know what I mean (classic double apple). As it develops, it is pleasantly complemented by a few woody notes, which, however, disappear so quickly that they are hardly worth mentioning. This brings us to the major problem of Présence:
The longevity is unfortunately terribly poor. I really can't understand how it currently has a rating of 7.2. Just when you think it’s really getting going in terms of fragrance development, it fades away again. The sillage is pleasantly strong at first, but diminishes significantly during its very short lifespan. It's a shame, really, because the scent itself is not bad. Unfortunately, this means you have to reapply regularly.

Overall, Présence is fine if you're looking for a fragrance that doesn't stand out too much in the sea of fruity-fresh perfumes, but still brings a certain uniqueness. Unfortunately, in my opinion, its performance is a major drawback. However, those who can financially afford to reach for the bottle regularly will certainly not be unhappy.

A fragrance that is actually pleasant in its basic DNA, but unfortunately rather reserved, starting with a sweet-spicy combination of apple, cinnamon, and ginger. The opening feels slightly minty and quickly drifts into a somewhat overly synthetic territory before the warm, spicy notes assert themselves more strongly. Particularly, the cinnamon gives the fragrance a cozy, slightly wintry nuance.

As it develops, the synthetic note continues to grow and remains in the foreground; however, the fragrance overall remains rather fleeting. After about one to two hours, it nearly completely dissipates, making it more of a short-lived companion. Those looking for a long-lasting scent will likely be disappointed here.

Despite the weaknesses in longevity, the fragrance composition itself is pleasant and quite wearable - especially for those who enjoy warm spicy notes but do not want to be accompanied by an overly intense scent. Perfect for relaxed occasions or when one just wants to briefly immerse themselves in a warm, spicy cloud of fragrance.

I was quite looking forward to it even before it was released. I tested it on my skin yesterday and also brought a scented paper. Now I have to say that it is a thorough mainstream aquatic perfume but not boring. Explorer Ultra Blue can still be included in the same category with Sauvage, Y, or so, but it is not a shower gel type, rather a perfume with marine mineral elements such as Bvlgari Aqva, D&G LB Swimming In Lipari, or Invictus Legend.

We already know that Montblanc is not a brand of originality or artistry in the perfume market. Their value is to finely predict consumer demand and join the trend at the right time. But they couldn't join the ambroxan festival of the 2010s. They must have been very concerned about how to inherit the trend as a latecomer in the market, and the result is this, Explorer Ultra Blue. They didn't make the scent more luxurious or special at all. Instead, they took note of the phenomenon in which other designer brands began to accept the salty mineral use. That salty mineral use is something that niche houses have tried first, something that has already been known to the point of safety, but has not become very popular yet.

Anyway, the early opening of Ultra Blue is a fruity cocktail-like scent, which is not very refreshing but also not sticky. This opening provides sweetness for teenage consumers but does not follow the pattern of mainstream men's perfumes. Anyway, the opening disappears quickly, soon after, a salty bergamot pops out. Pepper doesn't stand out very much, but adds a little bit of sharpness to this. And the ambroxan bomb, which is already supersaturated in the market, begins, and it followed the trend of men's perfumes in the 2010s, but emphasized the salty one. It is not necessary to mention the synthetic patchouli and leather that remain in the drydown. They are not materials for a good scent, they are just to increase the longevity, I think.

However, I think there's a reason why mineralic thing can't be completely mainstream, like ozonic thing. Ozonic perfumes make citrus brighter and more beautiful under certain conditions, but when it's not very hot, they also smell like cheap wipes. Likewise, Mineralic perfumes can give different experiences depending on the wearer, but sometimes it evokes horrible unpleasant memories for a person like me. I was born in a conscription country and had to be conscripted regardless of my will. Soldiers there disinfected always, whether was cleaning a camp or grooming equipment, with iodine solution. So the mineralic perfume is the smell of iodine solution used in the army for me. Whether it calls mineralic, marine or seaweed, whatever.

Nevertheless, Explorer Ultra Blue may be the first Mineralic perfume I'll buy. It scents more familiar and wearable than other perfumes with mineral notes to express the cold smell of the sea. it's more recent than Bvlgari Aqva. Nor is it overly sweet like Invictus Legend. It's definitely more masculine than D&G Light Blue Swimming In Lipari. It lasts longer than Valentino Born In Roma and has a little more clean feeling. But surely Ultra Blue won't be my most favorite perfume, and even if I buy it, it'll be time to sell at a discount store very cheaply. Sometimes others simply abbreviate these words as "Nothing Special", but I thought this perfume was pretty good than "Nothing Special". That's because It have made the kind of smell what I hate as acceptable as possible.

PS 1: Very little resemblance to Explorer original. The original wasn't even a literally original anyway, you know, so please stop your hasty expectations about Ultra Blue.

PS 2: If it's the same price range, of course ADG Profondo is much better. However, if the price of Explorer Ultra Blue goes down to 1/3 of Profondo, the evaluation will be different.

PS 3: I'm sorry for my childish English.

Liked Explorer and Platinum Explorer, so decided to try Ultra Blue. The best way I can describe it is a dialed down version of Explorer that is more fruity. It's as if the woody accord in Explorer were almost eliminated. The added fruity accord is generic, not specifically pineapple. I'd also say Ultra Blue is sorta like a watery and watered down Dylan Blue.

You can gather from the above that it's a generic blue fragrance, perfect for summer. Performance is at the lower end of moderate - got about 4 and a half hours of longevity at which point it was a barely detectable skin scent. If you don't have a blue summer fragrance, Ultra Blue could fill that hole, although I think there are others that are better. Of Explorer, Explorer Platinum and Ultra Blue, Ultra Blue is my least favorite.

review_title: I am confused by the influencer hate for Ultra Blue.
review_content: I don't get the all the negativity on this one from the toobers. Maybe my expectations for Ultra Blue were different than the rest of planet earth. Sure, the performance is moderate, but performance IS moderate on most fresh fragrances with similar profiles. Ultra Blue is exactly par for the course when it comes to avg. summer frag performance. As far as scent goes, I disagree that it smells like every other another generic blue like so many say. I think that assertion is mistaken. Look at the "smells similar" fragrances below. Mostly all blues yes, but the suggestions are all over the map exactly because it is hard to pin down another blue fragrance this smells like. Scent preference is highly subjective though, so to each his own. But to my nose, this is a great summer daily scent for men around 30+ with control over their libidos. Its not a chick magnet or attention seeker, but it was not designed to be. Its a nice guy fragrance. Maybe its a young married man with a steady job fragrance. We need frags like that too, not just screaming head turners. So, obviously I am a fan of Ultra Blue and think it deserves a shot. Don't pass on sampling it, especially if you live i a hot, long-summer climate like me. Consider what it is meant to be. Consider what it is not meant to be. You do have to spray a little heavier with this just like most other nice guy freshies.

Purchased from : eBay
Price paid : $12 / 0.48 fl oz
Format : spray
Method : Right wrist

Okay, so being a fan of both regular and platinum versions of Explorer, I figured hey, what could it hurt to blind buy a couple tall vials of their rarely-spoken-of cousin.

Man, this a crazy cousin.

The first blast is icy and clean but that subsides within a literal 5 seconds. What follows is a stark similarity to Nautica Voyage (which I hate) and what I'd describe as diapers or a nursery. There's some kind of non-descript mixed fruit aroma that reminds me of poopy diaper and gummy snacks. Some ripe and melting banana. The diaper changing room/nursery smell persists and the cologne does not morph or change.

For me this is one of the worst colognes I've ever smelled. I maybe did not expect to fall in love with it, but I did not expect this to go into the stinker hall of fame. Wife loves it. Go figure. I may try to send it back and order something else. At least it was cheap. I'd almost rather wear Nautica Voyage (puke).

Finally, the Corona numbers are going down again and today I am eagerly heading to the perfume shop I trust for the first time. I had already looked into the new releases that saw the light of day in 2021. I particularly focused on the "freshies," as I have always been a fan of blue, citrusy, and aquatic scents. Spicy, smoky, and heavily woody fragrances have never really appealed to me... God knows why :p
On my testing plan were 3 fragrances: Light Blue Forever (with the supposedly genius-smelling blood orange), MontBlanc Ultra Blue, and Cologne Bleu by YSL... I think you know what kind of scents I’m into ;)
When I arrived, the new Light Blue immediately caught my eye, as it was displayed in the shop window. My little heart skipped a beat and I went straight into the store.
I sprayed it on and smelled it. Eyebrows furrowed and sniffed again...
Well, what can I say? Indeed, a strong blood orange that I hadn’t detected in any other fragrance before. But as mega good as often described? I don’t know. For me, definitely not worth the money. I could have also cut open a grapefruit and spread it on my skin. In my opinion, it would have been the same scent... Well, there were still two left. So I grabbed Cologne Bleu and sprayed it on. A typical drugstore fresh opening and after a short time a clear similarity to the TuttiFrutti Invictus. Unfortunately, for me, another swing and a miss? So there was still one left: Ultra Blue by MontBlanc
I had heard increasingly negative things online and on YouTube, so I had no high expectations for the scent.
I sprayed it on and smelled:
The scent definitely starts off very citrusy and pleasant. If I had to describe the top note, I would say it’s a good mix of 2828 by Acqua Alpes and the green "Skin Food" cream by Weleda. Overall, the scent seems rather linear in my eyes, but maybe my nose just isn’t trained enough to pick out the individual components... The scent definitely doesn’t fill the room when you enter. Personally, I like that^^ It could also be due to my rather sparing amount of 2 sprays ;) Longevity for a freshie is above average. Certainly not a very unique scent, but a rating of 6.5 seems quite low in my opinion.

I found Montblanc Explorer to be a solid fragrance, even though it has similarities to Aventus. In 2021, it was finally time for another Mont Blanc Explorer. My expectations were for an evolution of the already known and solid Explorer DNA. However, Explorer Ultra Blue has managed to disappoint across the board. Of course, I was aware that it is not a €200 perfume. For me,...

The Explorer is likely to generate significant revenue for Montblanc or its licensee. Accordingly, it is not surprising (although somewhat questionable) that they are attaching flankers to this success. However, Ultra Blue has relatively little in common with the original Explorer, except that it could be categorized as a Freshy.

It starts off citrusy, herbal, and fresh with a noticeable synthetic undertone, like what feels like 1000 other fragrances in this segment. Recognizing detailed ingredients is pointless here; the whole thing is too diffuse. So, for anyone looking for an uncomplicated refresher for summer or the office, Ultra Blue is somewhat suitable, but one must have a considerable affinity for the Montblanc brand, as even in the drugstore, one could find cheaper and more interesting options nowadays.

What surprises me is the involvement of three equally prominent perfumers, whose interns during their lunch break or while slacking off could have certainly created the same result or even something more ambitious. Instead of spicing up the DNA of Explorer a bit, they took a super simple route here.

It's a shame for the name Explorer, a shame for the missed opportunity.

This is a shower gel scent as it should be. Fresh maritime notes are paired with citrus accords. Lemon, bergamot, Calone, and a good dose of pepper. Underneath, you can perceive the typical amber note for Explorer. If you like such scents, and I definitely do, then this is a good fragrance. Many would say it is interchangeable. The DNA has been smelled many times before. Yes, I can understand that. But that doesn’t mean that Explorer Blue is a bad EdT.

EB accompanies me around work and sports (they blend for me). It fits really well for that. Longevity and sillage are typical for a fresh, aquatic scent, around the 3-4 hour mark. For that, the price is not high, and thus it balances out. Recommendation for all Freshie fans.

review_title: I smell what you don't smell, and it's blue.
review_content:
"Explorer" - sounds exciting, especially as we are preparing for our active vacation. And "Ultra Blue" should be a revelation, after all, we're heading to an island in the ocean. So, a committed, adventurous, summery-fresh-aquatic scent for vacation everyday life? Let's see!

Upon the first spray, one immediately detects the scent of (drum roll!) Montblanc Legend - and not a variation of Montblanc Explorer, as the name might suggest. Beneath the elegantly subtle surface full of aquatic notes, a hint of incense immediately stands out. And then it's gone. Poof! Gone! Finito! No top note left after just two minutes. A weak, soapy-lemony scent remains, and a little later, one can only perceive a conglomerate of bitterness with a hint of cow grass near Garmisch.

So, the exciting naming does not do justice to Montblanc Explorer Ultra Blue. The brother "Explorer" has significantly better longevity and a more intense sillage, making it the better choice for anyone who can get used to peppery notes and a distinct oriental component. Ultra Blue, on the other hand, disappointed me and is, for me, the weakest perfume from the Montblanc house.

review_title: No matter how blue you are, he is bluer.
review_content: You're in a hurry, just took a quick shower, your Fa shower gel is somehow still lingering in your hair, and you haven't completely gotten rid of the sweat under your arms because you simply didn't have enough time to scrub. But you have to get to your date! You quickly jump into your white shirt, put on your blue jeans and sneakers, and head out the door. Your hair will dry...

Although the mostly negative comments and reviews kept me away for a long time, I always had this scent in mind when it came to finding my Blue Signature. Since it has a very appealing price point, I couldn't resist and got it for myself. What emerged is a fragrance profile that, to be honest, makes me a bit addicted. The Explorer Ultra Blue has nothing to do...

review_title: Not bad, but not a knockout.
review_content:
Mont Blanc Explorer Ultra Blue was my first real perfume. :)
The opening smells beautifully fresh, and you almost feel like you’re by the sea; however, you can also detect a certain spiciness that, in my opinion, fits quite well and makes the perfume not just a summer fragrance.

Unfortunately, the longevity is not great, which means you might need to reapply if you want to last through the whole day. The scent fades quite quickly and is no longer really noticeable.

If you can get the fragrance at a reasonable price, then it’s definitely worth trying out; it’s not bad.

review_title: Solid fresh scent with mediocre longevity!
review_content:
It is fresh, spicy, and pleasant. Unfortunately, like many fresh scents, it doesn't have particularly good longevity.
A pretty good "freshly showered scent" that you should try if you're looking for fresh fragrances!
It is usually quite affordable and its bottle looks quite nice!
It comes across as quite sporty to me.

review_title: Warmer, Sweeter and Spicier than the Original - But Not Bold Enough
review_content:
First impressions.

Montblanc Extreme opens up with a blast of fresh citrus, but then develops into a much darker, warmer fragrance with much more depth than the original. In the drydown it also becomes sweeter and more resinous.

It's very much in the wheelhouse of Sauvage Elixir/Boss Bottled Elixir/Triumph Elixir and even Bottled Absolu, though nowhere near as strong or as bold. It feels like this is where Montblanc took its inspiration from. It also shares the same spiciness as those fragrances and has the same liquorice note found in Sauvage Elixir.

It's by no means a beast mode fragrance, and on me sits very close to the skin. Longevity is better, and I've been able to smell it for most of the day. Personally I would prefer it to be punchier and project better.

It's a 6 out of 10 for me at the moment, as it needs more wear. It's not a bad fragrance, it's just that there are other fragrances out there doing the same kind of thing, only better.

… walking through the forest with the dog. The first blossoms are already daring to come out. The first buds can be seen on the trees. It is moist, spicy, and at the same time fresh. My leather jacket is damp and exudes its aroma. My dog is frolicking on the leash and picks up a stick, or rather a branch. We are just having fun.

When applying this fragrance, the first thing that hits the nose is a scent of dark, not sweet licorice (even though this is not listed in the fragrance pyramid) that reminds one of a well-known perfume from Dior. After about 15 minutes, this is replaced by a citrusy fresh dry dark twist. To give this perfume a truly masculine vibe, resinous and woody accents are mixed in. I assume that the woody note comes from the vetiver. To really become manly with hair on the chest, the leather makes its presence known, which has a slightly moist quality and adds even more depth and darkness to the scent. However, what the fragrance always is in my nose is that it is clean and mature.

The longevity and sillage are very good.

Here, the house of Montblanc has launched a men’s fragrance that turns a gentleman into a lumberjack. Since this scent is strongly masculine, I don’t see it for the ladies. Additionally, it is quite mature, making it suitable for those aged 25 and up. I would say this is an all-rounder that is suitable for the whole year, whether cold or hot. During the day, it feels just as comfortable in a suit as it does in jeans or while exercising. In the evening, it is a charismatic guy who loves to charm the ladies, whether at dinner, in a bar, at a club, or at a ball or party.

Anyone who enjoys a licorice, citrusy fresh, dry dark resinous woody masculine leather scent should definitely check this one out. It is certainly worth it.

The blend of fresh bergamot in the top note and the woody-leathery finish is brilliant. Masculine, confident, not overpowering, slightly oriental but not too sweet or synthetic. In my opinion, it’s a great mix of modern and classic and a good daily driver. Anyone who likes the mentioned fragrance notes can’t go wrong here, in my opinion. Thus, it is also suitable as a blind buy or gift.

Off the top, it's a fairly unique fragrance, it's light, airy and a little floral.
Then after about 2 minutes, the cinnamon makes an appearance and starts being dominant.
After it settles, it smells really similar to Invictus Aqua to my nose, but the cinnamon gives it a little backbone and makes it a bit more mature.

Not a heavy projector, but on my skin it has great longevity at least, about 8-10 hours.
Can be worn year-round, best in Spring and Summer.
Very good choice for work or school, because it's discreet and stays.

Bottom line: I'd only recommend this if you don't have Invictus Aqua yet, but you like how it smells and if you don't mind moderate performance.

This is why you shouldn't buy just for the bottle :)

This was my first fragrance I bought and I used it many years. Personally I believe the scent is unique and it smells good. I like the combination fresh/spicy it gives it a personality and my girlfriend knew when I was around because its not a fragrance many people are wearing. Are there better fragrances out there ? of course but if you consider price/performance I think its a very good choice and the fact that I used this fragrance 5 years or more says a lot. Of course every skin and taste is different so don't blind buy it.

If you have any questions let me know and I will try to help you ^^

Occasionally I'm given men's scents for testing. The most tradional modern scent I do not like. Neither do I like them for my own use, nor do I like them on men. But there are a lot of masculin scents I love and use for myself. Like "Kyoto by CdG" for instance.
So, if I'm testing a scent which I consider as a men's scent only I ask myself:
1. Do I like it at all?
2. Do I like it on men?
3. Would I want to use it myself
4. Would I be intrigued by a man who is smelling with this fragrance?
5. Would I buy it for a man?
In case of "Emblem" I would answere on all questions with a clear: No!
There is nothing much to describe. "Emblem" is a "normal" scent for men which can be smelled on every corner every shop, supermarket, office etc. every day, everywhere.
Cinnamon leaf? I do not know how it could smell, I guess somehow green. Yes, "Emblem" is smelling green too. I cannot perceive tonkabean and I do not pity that.
More explanations are not neccessairy, the pyramide is not lying and maybe on a man I would perceive even tonkabean.
Because the sillage is almost evarage and is withdrawing after about 4 hours I did not suffer since I sprayed it on my skin.
But then, very close to my skin there is appearing a sweaty, sour and cutaneous note I cannot identify which ingredient is causing it. It is not oud, not oakmoss. It is not too heavy. But I know poeple who are smelling like this. I do not like that kind of human smell. And I want to stress: This cutneous note is not caused by unhygienical body-care, it is belonging to some human beings. Also I have to admit: I do not like any fragrances with the slightest hint of cutaneous notes.
Well, if a man would use"Emblem" as perfume I would always stay away in a certain distance of him.
But maybe, if a man is using "Emblem" he would not percolate that cutaneous note I am perceiving now.

I received a sample of this a few months ago, I remember liking the scent but I also remember thinking that there was nothing special about it. The grapefruit was nice on the opening and it dried to a decent tonka bean and wood, but it's got ingredients in it which personally I believe have been used better in other fragrances, for example, Bleu De Chanel with the grapefruit and Armani Code with the tonka dry down.

One thing you have to give to the brand Montblanc: they stay true to their line, at least regarding the aesthetics of their writing instruments as well as their watches. And even some perfume bottles can keep up with the sophisticated design. Emblem definitely belongs in that category.

It's just a shame that, as is often the case in the world of fragrances, the elegance of the bottles does not always match the content. Unfortunately, Emblem falls into this category as well.

Even if one were to consider that Montblanc aims to establish itself more in the segment of understated office fragrances with their men's line and less in the club scene, Emblem unfortunately does not rise above mediocrity.

For higher ambitions, this Eau de Toilette is simply too plain and offers nothing really exciting besides a sweet-synthetic blend of cardamom and tonka bean. With exactly these two ingredients, it reminds me of the colossal Dolce & Gabbana pour Homme in its original version, but despite the violet leaf and clary sage, it drifts too much towards a shower gel aroma - and I find that problematic.

I think anyone who is financially well-off enough to sign their checks with Montblanc pens and check the time on Montblanc watches will surely want and find more qualitatively demanding fragrances for their status. And they don't even have to be more expensive!

review_title: Montblanc, stick to writing instruments! It won't get better....Pseudo-violet synthetic trash
review_content: And again, such a strange product. If one didn't know that the Montblanc brand actually produces stylistically ultra-conservative writing instruments for nobles and literature professors, one would never guess these synthetic nasal crimes that the company has been churning out for a decade and a half. An annoyingly artificial, somewhat leaden opening comes from something...

There is hardly a brand that better illustrates what happens when a well-established and still successful brand name is sold to different licensees across various business fields. And these licensees then position themselves in completely different target segments - high-quality writing instruments for a tradition- and status-conscious clientele on one side and more or less trashy student fragrances on the other - while I am sure that the lovers of 400 Euro and up fountain pens find the scents just as unattractive as the fans of fragrances are drawn to 400 Euro and up fountain pens. The fact that this very fragrance - Emblem - presumes to transport the essence of the Montblanc brand makes the situation no less absurd. Contrary to the reduced (not necessarily retracted) design language of the writing instrument, Emblem is a fragrance of little subtlety, let alone traditional character. On the contrary, it is not shy about driving the full load of olfactory zeitgeist cheerfulness through the ring like an exhausted circus horse with a feather headdress on its head.

Essentially, it is based on two accords: a fruity-spicy intro and a sweetness with the persistence of a Duracell battery. Neither of these accords is particularly original, and neither appeals to me, and the cheap synthetic note in all its fragrance phases is a testament to a lack of craftsmanship and passion that would hardly be accepted in Montblanc fountain pens.

And then there's Tonka.

The Tonka are a warlike mountain people (not to be confused with the Incas) who torture their prisoners with sheets soaked in sugar water and - no, of course not - just kidding. Tonka comes from the Cumaru or Brazilian teak tree, whose wood is highly sought after as a material. The tonka bean is actually not a bean at all, but merely the bean-shaped seed of its stone fruit, similar to almonds or apricot kernels. There are a few fragrances that manage to coax the variety of aromas from the tonka bean and position it away from vanilla, which it has already been used as a substitute for - most settle for a pleasing, interchangeable, often poorly dosed, tooth-pulling carnival sweetness. Montblanc's Emblem is a prime example of this all-encompassing sweetness - it may only be comforting that the top note it overshadows is not beautiful enough to really miss.

Conclusion: a largely inconsequential and loud spice-tonka fragrance. Only the bottle is quite pretty.

I really like both Pieper and Müller - not because of the prices, selection, or niche fragrances, but for one reason: they always have the latest releases in no time. My eyes sparkled when I saw the black, stylish, straightforward, and ultra-heavy bottle of Montblanc's latest: Emblem. Okay, my anticipation was somewhat tempered due to the recent outputs from the writer's company (Legend :/), but still, I spritzed piously and freely on a bare spot on my arm. It was clear within seconds that it wasn’t a stinker and that it was a nice cardamom perfume. Only one thing was even quicker: the disillusionment of having to test another lab-created baby that one has unfortunately already smelled dozens of times. Best exemplified by YSL's masterpiece La Nuit de L'Homme.

I like to be the first to comment, so no one can accuse me of copying from somewhere. And with such a new release, you won’t find any reviews online anyway, so I’m happy to provide the premiere here. Sorry that I can’t generate any advertising or hype - because the unspectacular cream perfume Emblem is simply not suitable for that. An Intense version announced at the same time isn’t needed either.

As for the scent description: super soft, unspectacular, creamy, office-appropriate. It doesn’t harm a fly; it’s as meek as a lamb. MontBlanc will probably never create something as wonderful as Individuel again. It’s really sad what the brand has been delivering in recent years. Emblem is not a gate with seven seals, but deciphered and read faster than the headline of the Bild newspaper. Creamy cardamom, a skin tone, also similar to Chopard's 1000 Miglia. A bit of violet and a lot of tonka - well, one might also like Fahrenheit and Armani Code. However, Fahrenheit is the furthest removed. Anyone who likes or owns one of the mentioned fragrances can test this one, but will then move on unimpressed. Not a very good new release and as cowardly as a horde of cowards.

Bottle: heavy, bulky, and heavy again. One of the brand's strengths.
Sillage: pleasant and office-appropriate. Creamy and soft.
Longevity: a shortened day in the office - 6-7 hours.

Why 100% for La Nuit and only half for the 26th imitator? I hope that was a rhetorical question...

review_title: Emblem: Not an Individualist, but Too Good to Dismiss
review_content:
As this is my first comment on a perfume, I ask for your understanding if it doesn't hit the nail on the head.
------------------
How does one come up with the idea of buying a fragrance from a company known for its beautiful writing instruments?

Exactly for this reason, one becomes aware of the fragrances!
Almost everyone knows the name and automatically associates it with the proud Hamburg luxury brand.
I also discovered the beautiful and high-quality bottle of Montblanc's Emblem rather by chance at Müller. Admittedly, it is precisely the unusual and elegant design that makes you want to test the perfume and you expect a particularly unique scent with the same enthusiasm. To put it bluntly: The scent is not unique. It is not an Antaeus (Chanel), not a Pasha (Cartier), and not a Safari (Ralph Lauren).
However, one must give the fragrance its due: It lives up to the bottle and the name!
‘Why?’
Everyone somehow knows the scent and compares it with other manufacturers and fragrances, but still, it feels very elegant and lasts exceptionally long on the skin (10 hours +).

You can also somehow compare it to the associated writing instruments.
A ballpoint pen is just a ballpoint pen. There are hundreds of manufacturers, and each makes it differently. Montblanc has managed to make the same product feel more premium and market it properly.

The same goes for the fragrance.

There is nothing to add to Leimbacher's fragrance description, which is why I quote it accordingly (I hope that is acceptable). It is “super soft, creamy, office-appropriate, and doesn’t harm a fly.”

Of course, one also recognizes similarities to other fragrances, such as Fahrenheit or Armani Code. However, the biggest difference from the two scents is that Emblem works with my personal body chemistry and doesn’t start to smell bad after half an hour.

The sillage is also very pleasant. Not too strong, not too weak, and lasts throughout the day.
In short: The fragrance is better than one initially thinks.

review_title: Why am I just so strong and you too weak?
review_content:
I was able to test Mont Blanc's Emblem thanks to our dear Parfumo "Zirkeltanz" and I want to express my sincere thanks for that.

The top note starts off fresh, reminiscent of shower gel, nothing wrong with that in my opinion.
It doesn't come across as cheap, but also not expensive; it is in the middle range.

I can clearly recognize grapefruit, as well as cardamom, which I believe is a tad too much, as it makes the grapefruit seem a little "old," but at the same time takes away its bitterness.
The clary sage appears about 3 minutes later and rounds off the top note.

The violet leaf is herbaceous - green, and in combination with the cinnamon leaf, it gains even more depth and a slight floral quality.

"Nanu, where did it go?" I asked myself?

I could smell nothing more, so I opened my Glenfiddich cardboard box, where my coffee beans are stored, took a hearty breath three times, and closed it again.

"Aha, there you are," I noted.

This constellation lasts about 3 hours on my skin until the base note with tonka bean, which has a nutty - marzipan hint and is blended with several wood notes that I can't quite pinpoint, unfolds.

The base note also reminds me of another fragrance, but I just can't figure it out.

Overall, the scent lasts just under 5 hours on my skin, which I unfortunately find too little.

The scent isn't that bad at all, as there are certainly some candidates that would make you want to run away.

In summer, you can apply it generously; an overdose is hardly possible, as the scent is unfortunately really very weak on the skin.
The sillage is moderate in the first 30 minutes, but unfortunately too weak from the start.

After 1.5 hours, the scent is already a skin scent.

If the scent lasted longer and had a better sillage, it would be a candidate for purchase for me for the summer.

...and that is meant positively! Montblanc generally stands for high-priced writing instruments - instruments that I find cumbersome and/or ostentatious across the board. I have never been particularly drawn to the brand; neither the image nor the design appeals to me. The bottle does not exactly exude restraint, standing there as a six-pointed... well, what actually?...

review_title: Which fragrance is preferred by elegant, masculine, confident men who are also good parents? MONTBLANC EMBLEM - Fascinating for more than just women
review_content:
Probably most women want their man to smell expensive and delicious! At least I am one of them. I love it when a man smells like a good perfume.

The inscription on the bottom of the box of the MONTBLANC Emblem Eau de Toilette for men
Packaging: The Eau de Toilette comes in a stylish, minimalist box made of thick cardboard in glossy black. The only inscriptions are the name and information about the fragrance and the manufacturer.

The bottle: Similarly understated, black, hexagonal bottle with the manufacturer's logo (the same white hexagon in the center of the cap), heavy. It distributes very easily. Due to its simplicity, the appearance of the perfume already shows its display potential (businessmen like stylish and not flashy bottles on their shelves).

About the fragrance: MONTBLANC EMBLEM itself belongs to the category of oriental fragrances or perhaps rather to woody scents.

The top notes are cardamom, cinnamon, patchouli, and pepper.

The heart note consists of woody notes and violet leaves.

Base notes are grapefruit and sage

What the manufacturer claims on the official website of the shop:

MONTBLANC Emblem is a classic, a constant play of ice and flame. The icy notes of sage leaves, violet, and cardamom meet the fiery-spicy notes of black and pink pepper and lush cinnamon. The fragrance has a beautiful hint of light wood scent and patchouli. The image of a man who chooses MONTBLANC Emblem is that of a strong and confident leader who knows what he wants in life and has already overcome many peaks on his way to reach ever new and greater heights.

As a renowned Swiss brand with a history of over a hundred years, MONTBLANC knows the fundamental requirements and desires of its target audience, confident and strong men, very well. That is why MONTBLANC Emblem harmoniously combines all the components that make an ideal fragrance for the modern man. The exclusive blend of contrasting facets of this scent is what best describes Emblem by MONTBLANC.
I would like to add for myself that this Eau de Toilette is truly meant for real, confident men who know what they want and achieve their goals. It may seem difficult to you, but it is a matter of personal preference. This is not a fragrance for boys and frivolous guys. The owner of this perfume will never lack taste and will always look flawless! And the trail of the fragrance.... Makes others give compliments (and not just the fairer sex). Men who perceive the scent of MONTBLANC Emblem often wonder about the name and appreciate this extraordinary fragrance. I love this scent very much too!

The advantages of MONTBLANC Emblem Eau de Toilette
The incredible longevity inherent in the entire range of the manufacturer.
Minimal consumption (just one spray and the scent lasts more than 2 days (even after showering, a light trace remains))
Wonderful woody and spicy scent that only real men can aspire to
Elegant and clear packaging
I definitely recommend this product and I think you can make your favorite man happy with such a bottle as a gift!

I hope my review was useful to you! Thank you for your attention!

Advantages
Very persistent.
Stylish bottle
Chic scent
Economical

Disadvantages
Price

First of all: the bottle. What’s that? It looks like a cheap children's toy (and feels like one too).

The scent itself starts off herbaceous-spicy, yet not green, leaving at least an interesting impression. Could this possibly come from the cinnamon and violet leaf? In any case, cardamom and clary sage are involved. A sweetness (tonka) quickly develops, but it does not cross the line of good taste. Emblem now has a grassy note, but still does not smell classically green. For a while, I can still find something in the scent. But then it fades, more and more. It becomes reminiscent of Invictus EAU DE TOILETTE - slightly synthetic, palatable, uncomplicated - and simply boring.
It doesn’t excite me, has nothing special, nothing extraordinary. Everything is okay, everything is well done, but what is the selling point? Why not just go for the original? Or Eros EAU DE TOILETTE? Or 1 Million EAU DE TOILETTE? Or Ultra Mâle? Or, or, or?

And then there's the performance. 1 hour of solid sillage? 5½ hours until you can't smell it at all? Come on.

A star is born? No way, it’s not.

review_title: Nice addition to the Legend collection
review_content:
Out of the Legend collection, I started with Legend EdP which I like very much. Next was Legend Spirit, which didn't do much for me. Didn't know what to expect with Legend Blue but was pleasantly surprised. It's a really nice addition to the Legend Collection. Smooth and clean masculine fragrance.The mint freshens it up but it's subtle, not overpowering. If you don't care for strong mints, or worry about it smelling like toothpaste, you have nothing to fear with Legend Blue. Woody notes are well blended and smooth, not sharp. Also strikes me as very versatile - you can pretty much wear this anytime of the year, day or night. An easy reach fragrance.

To give you an idea on what it smells like, I did a little experiment by comparing it to Legend EDP and Dylan Blue. Legend EDP has stronger woody notes which are subdued and smoother in Legend Blue. In direct comparison, Dylan Blue is sweeter and more floral while Legend Blue is not as sweet and more fruity than floral.

Projection was moderate for me but longevity was quite good - got about 7 hours out of it. Overall, very nice. I'm picking this one up. Prices are reasonable at discounters.

In fact, I approached this fragrance with low expectations.
Montblanc is not my favorite brand.
Aside from "Legend Night | Montblanc," I don't really like any scent from the brand.
However, Legend Blue pleasantly surprised me.
Take the regular Legend EAU DE TOILETTE as a base and add a good dose of freshness and "blue."
It sounds unremarkable, but it makes a noticeable difference.
Nothing here feels cheap.
Somehow, there is just the right balance that I would say: It appeals to every man and every woman.
Maybe it's not the biggest hit, but you will still smell pleasant.
Longevity and projection are also decent, so you can easily get through a workday.
Definitely worth recommending, even as a gift.

review_title: For what it is - one of the best!
review_content:
Montblanc has made its Explorer its Aventus clone and with the Legend line has also made some other popular brands affordable for many.

The Legend Blue now goes fully in the fresh direction and has - at least to my knowledge - no direct 1:1 inspiration.

The Legend Blue is one for the really hot days, for me the definition of a Freshy. A perfume couldn't smell more like typical shower gel.

Completely without typical citrus notes, the cool and synthetic bubble blows directly into your face. It becomes minimally sweet, minimally spicy, but maintains its light core throughout. Absolutely not complex or with a special progression, straightforwardly fresh without fruit.

Since there is no significant base in terms of woods, it doesn't last very long - but that's hardly achievable with this DNA.

You can't overspray this one and you can't go wrong with it at all.

In this price segment and for what it is supposed to deliver: incredibly good.

review_title: The adult brother of Legend Spirit
review_content:
After Legend Spirit was my relaxed all-rounder, I wanted to test the new brother.

Bottle is known, unobtrusive, practical with a usable spray.

Freshly applied, it smells like just showered. For me, it's a bit less biting than Legend Spirit and therefore a bit lighter and more casual.

It is the first and so far the only fragrance that I like to apply directly after showering with a spritz. Whether for the sofa, housework, or just a quick outing, warm or cold, sporty or sophisticated - this scent fits strikingly unobtrusively every time.

It’s not a head-turner, but it won't disturb anyone either.

The longevity for me right after showering is about 6 hours, leaving a pleasant trace on skin and clothing for a good day. Especially on the scarf, I really like it for its warm note.

Anyone who wants to smell rounded and fresh is doing everything right here at any age.

In my eyes, once again a successful everyday classic from the house of Mont Blanc.

review_title: A real Legend in the making.
review_content:
The Montblanc 'Legend' fragrance line is surely one of the most consistently solid lines in the designer scent market. So far my preference has been for Legend spirit (LS) over the Legend original (LO), mainly because I'm a lover of fresh scents, particularly at this time of the year. That said after scoring samples in a store for both LS and LO it wasn't such an easy choice at first but the fantastic white freshie won in the end and I bought a bottle.

So to Legend intense (LI). I tried this in a store in (my old home town) London as it was impossible to find here in France where I live, I just didn't want to blind buy. A couple of sprays on my forearm and it was love or rather 'lust' at first sniff. It just smells so lushly aromatic and classy. Fruity, woody and sweet but not cloying. The notes of red apple, pineapple, bergamot, cardamom and tonka join forces to create something incredibly alluring. In the background are some floral notes (jasmine), ambergris and oak moss on the sturdy woodsy and resinous base. I don't know what pepperwood/hercules' club smells like but perhaps it's this note that gives Legend Intense another little something special too.

A warm spring day, walking along (the typically hectic) Oxford street catching wafts of this captivating scent (I must've looked odd in the rush hour human traffic sniffing my arm every now and then, but in this eccentric city anything goes!). The evening signaled a heavy metal concert and the excellent 'Machine Head' in a packed-out, hot and sweat-inducing venue. After the show, on the train home dripping with sweat and a change of t shirt I was amazed that I could still smell the Legend Intense on my arm. Like a previous reviewer said, it (still) smelled almost good enough to eat.

Upon receiving my bottle I tested the fragrance. Sprayed at 7pm I could still smell it on my arm at 10am the morning after, it would've lasted longer if I hadn't taken a shower, so longevity is very good. Sillage and projection are more moderate but still decent. My sprayer is stiffer than on the LS bottle so it's either a big spray or nothing (maybe I got a dud), great looking bottle though, as usual with the Legend range.
