With LI I have discovered (another) new favourite. I'm really impressed. To my nose this is a magnificent fragrance, class in a bottle. It beats the original as an all round, all seasons scent and is longer lasting too as you would hope for given it's name. It seems more complex and interesting than the original too, there's more going on but it never seems too much. LI is one of those fragrances that could be worn in any situation (except perhaps extreme heat) and will garner nods of approval and turn heads rather than offend. Just bear in mind you'll be continually sniffing yourself! Here's hoping the ladies like this scent as much as I do and if they don't, well they're just going to have to miss out then!

I just hope it doesn't get discontinued (if it isn't already) as it wasn't so easy to find for me. With Legend Spirit I found a gem, with Legend Intense I unearthed a real treasure. My advice-get it now.

review_title: Sweeeeet and creamy tonka, red apple and cedar.
review_content:
I made the mistake one day of wearing this while lifting weights. Strangely enough, as off-putting as the sweetness was, I could never really shake the association. Now, every time I lift, I like to wear a spray of this stuff on my left forearm and have a sniff anytime I need to get angry. Hahaha. And you wouldn't like me when I'm angry...But does this really smell like a ripped guy with his shirt off? Meh. It's too sweet and powdery, really. Fierce references aside, I think it's a very good scent that takes the original Legend and adds some density and character.

The opening blast is fruity - pineapple, apple, a tinge of spiciness and a whole lot of creamy tonka. The similarity to Fierce is obvious, but this just feels more rounded around the edges. There's absolutely no citrus that I can detect, since the overwhelming impression is sugary and casual - almost like a candy apple, without the caramel. The scent remains linear, but becomes very powdery 2 hours in, almost to the point of inducing nausea in extremely hot weather. So save this stuff for the autumn, winter and spring. Longevity is ok, but the projection is weak. Decent for cuddling, but not so much for the outdoors, unless you spray your clothes.

If you're a fan of the original, you'll probably like this even more. According to the reviews online, that's pretty much universal. Personally, I really like it for its general appeal with the youngsters. In fact, 4 out of the 5 (younger) women I asked about it, prefer the smell over La Nuit. I almost crumpled in shock, but there you go. I just wish the projection was better dang it. Plus, the atomizer on my bottle is a squirter. Not sure if that's common...but it gets the job done. Overall, I would still say it's above average, especially as an all-arounder, or whenever you need to grab a little sweeeeeeet....

Legend Intense is an extremely versatile fragrance that can be worn any time of year, for just about any occasion, day or night. It smells incredible and garners more compliments than other fragrances costing 10 times as much. A real winner!

A fragrance that is classified as having a sweet, fruity scent, You will notice a slightly synthetic scent, Consider it the sugarier and sweeter version of its brother, Legend Montblanc.

The scent of the fragrance may last for four to five hours, and it will spread around you quickly, and you will receive compliments for it, but its drawback is the presence of a slight metallic scent that is somewhat repulsive.

The fragrance bottle comes in a slightly dark silver (metallic) color, similar to the famous Montblanc Legend edition bottles.

An autumn fragrance suitable for young men and men under the age of forty.

Conclusion: Not the best Montblanc fragrances.

review_title: New York Spring 2014, Macys, half an hour shopping without my wife...
review_content:
...I had already snagged a fragrance that I actually didn't find that great.

Was it the charming, professionally trained salesperson, my reluctance to buy the fourth American designer jeans, or finally getting THAT New York souvenir that could withstand the test of time and remind me for years to come of the trip of my life in the city that never sleeps? Maybe it was just my latent jet lag fatigue, the sensory overload of Manhattan, and the sticky smell of the New York subway that I wanted to escape. Whatever it was...

"You could treat yourself to a new fragrance!" I thought to myself when my wife suggested we split up to enhance our shopping efficiency given the incredible size of the Macy's shopping temple. Any savvy horror movie fan knows what "We'll split up here, you go that way, I'll keep looking here..." means for the plot's progression! Nothing good.

So I wandered rather bored through the perfume and cosmetics department, being constantly approached at every stand, just like in St. Pauli or the bazaar in Marrakech. Some people like this. I don't. After my first few nerves were spent, I was really just looking for a quiet corner. In a nook near the escalators, I started chatting with an Austrian woman who was overloaded with about 47 shopping bags, and we talked about the sense and nonsense of shopping marathons. At that time, it was still ideologically free and quite amusing. But onward I went; I couldn't appear at the agreed meeting point with my wife empty-handed. I needed a NY souvenir, perfume is always a good choice. We all know that.

After the 2000s, I had finally moved past the Hugo and Boss bottled phase, and some other offshoots of this house that I had picked up in duty-free shops had long since failed to convince me. The fourth or fifth bottle of Versace pH was not going to be it for me anymore, no matter how much I had liked it as a long-time companion through my nights. Similarly, my long-standing preference for D&G had descended into the realm of insignificance, and the original version of Armani Pour Homme that I loved so dearly had vanished when I was busy with more important things in the 90s. And had I ever guessed that Jil Sander Man would stop overshadowing the fragrance heavens, I would have bought a 1000-liter IBC container full to the brim with it! I swear.

So there I stood, somewhat lost in front of a display case with elegant, beautiful, and hopelessly outdated-looking fountain pens from the house with the big white star. These ink pens, resembling unique pieces, had an unexpectedly calming effect on me amidst the noise of this hyperactive metropolis. And 'whoosh,' I was in conversation with the hyper-friendly salesperson (In America, yes, they are like that.), who praised my modest English skills and directed the conversation towards this new fragrance flanker from Montblanc. Another 10 minutes later, I had a heavy, masculine matte metallic bottle and a scent that seemed suspiciously familiar to me. This fresh sweetness didn't feel that new; I had smelled it before. But where? A little later, as the fragrance became softer, cozier, and less synthetically clean, I found it more appealing. Yet it reminded me not at all of my preferences from past years. Why did I buy this?? It was actually too blunt and pushy. No elegance to it at all. So consciously styled. It pretends to be classy but isn't heartfelt. A fraud even?

In the evening at the hotel bar on the 37th or 39th floor with a view of the UN building, I initially cursed the hastily spent dollars from our travel budget and vowed never, ever again to buy any perfume thoughtlessly or hastily. (Yes, I admit, my plan worked out great later on.) "Oh, screw it," I thought after the 7th or 8th Bud Light, "you've got the scent that will remind you of New York, you’ll never buy such soulless synthetic crap again."

The next day, we strolled along Fifth Avenue and passed by this black-clad store, in front of which dozens of teenagers were being pushed by 20-year-old six-pack beauties on the verge of a nervous breakdown (again!). My wife and I, of course, went in because we wanted to be able to join in the next party small talk. 2014 must have been the peak of this completely incomprehensible Abercrombie & Fitch hype for me. Every city back home, from Eckernförde to Füssen, from Görlitz to Castrop-Rauxel, absolutely had to have one of those dark, cramped places with grossly overpriced clothes from the sweatshops of Bangladesh. "Inside, the salespeople run around completely naked and you get doused with perfume to boost your buying urge," I had heard. Well, only the latter rumor turned out to be true. But...

...that was it. I had just bought that fragrance yesterday. "Hey guys, do you also sell fountain pens here?" I called out excitedly. No, they didn't. It must have been that Pierce thing that hit my nostrils. But I had my New York souvenir fragrance. I didn't care if it was Pierce, Fierce, or Legend; it smelled just like a spring afternoon on Fifth Avenue. Of course not, Fifth Avenue stinks of car exhaust. But everything my wife and I experienced together in those unforgettable moments in this crazy, equally fascinating and repulsive city during the first warm rays of sunshine in April 2014 immediately comes to mind when I wear Montblanc Legend Intense. Even though I don't find it that great, I enjoy smelling it. I'm about to get sentimental. And Montblanc Legend Intense really doesn't deserve that, the old fraud!

Actually, MontBlanc doesn't need to copy so coldly. With good to very good perfumes like Individuel or the underrated Presence, they have already proven that they can do it. So much so that even Creed copied with Original Santal and couldn't match Individuel. But it must be said clearly: the Legend series is a Fierce knockoff without any sense of shame. They are certainly...

Legend Intense has been in my collection for a while now. I often smelled the bottle, but never sprayed or wore it. Today was finally the day. Invited to a barbecue, beautiful sun, not quite warm but a pleasant temperature. So I thought today would finally be the big day. I love those days when I spray a fragrance "blind" (it wasn't completely blind, I had sniffed the bottle several times before). And what can I say, wow, what a great experience, fresh, it matched the weather perfectly, what struck me the most was the metallic note. I haven't read much about this, maybe I'm crazy, but I smell metal. But in a positive sense, I might be expressing myself poorly :) And this metallic fresh note lasts forever. I've read often that longevity and sillage leave something to be desired. However, I can't relate to that. I sprayed around noon, not too much, 6 sprays, and I can almost permanently perceive it on myself. I also received positive comments today. As I said, for me, longevity, both on the skin and on clothing, and sillage are truly fantastic. I perceive the scent as masculine, fresh, sporty, casual, and carefree. Good mood, simply wonderful.
In comparison with Fierce, yes, it goes in the same direction, but I find this one a bit better, I justify this with the fresh metallic note that I perceive much stronger here.
Price-wise, it's quite reasonable. Available online for a fair price. I paid around 30.-€/50ml.
Regarding the bottle, I think it fits the scent perfectly. Dark metal, feels cold and cool in the hand, just like the fragrance.
I am definitely convinced and thrilled. Thanks for reading.

review_title: Yawningly boring arrangement of a basket full of syrupy autumn fruits
review_content:
My general displeasure with Montblanc's many failed attempts to push serious quality products into the perfume market is well known.

Not a single scent that I would consider from them. And no, not even "Individuel," which is constantly praised here, but for me represents nothing more than an annoying, unimaginative, unnatural raspberry surrogate.

Okay, I admit, I once had "Starwalker," but I never finished it because the smooth cyber-clean synthetic scent quickly annoyed me.

After the lame, artificial, piercingly fresh "Legend," now comes the "Intense."
And once again, what a letdown!

Similar ingredient list to the base scent, where a rather fresh, artificially summery fruit basket is at the center, but here it’s one that has bundled up for winter.

Pineapple and apple are quite prominent, almost syrupy, with a hint of cardamom spice running through it.

However, it is anything but appetizing or cozily arranged; it comes off too mushy and stirred together.

Tonka bean subtly envelops the autumn fruits in a lightly caramelized shell, while cedar discreetly adds a touch of wood.

It is incredibly boring to smell, uninspired, trivial fruity-syrupy, lacking contours or any "Aha" moment. Weak.... What do the 78% up there even mean?

review_title: A Wannabe Discovers the Fierce Land
review_content: What were the people at Montblanc and perfumer Olivier Pescheux thinking with the Legend series? Probably something like this: Creed has completely outdone us with "Original Santal" and simply copied "Individuel," so now we’ll turn the tables in our favor. In any case, it quickly becomes clear which DNA was to be explored with "Legend": Abercrombie is this time the target of...

About the scent. It really smells fresh and masculine. The fragrance is definitely successful

But here are the instructions for use so that you actually notice the scent:

Please apply 10 sprays to the neck, 5 sprays behind each earlobe, and a few sprays on each arm from top to bottom.

Done :)

The similarities to Fierce are unmistakable in terms of scent.
The progression is nearly identical, except for the first hour, and I wouldn't trust myself to distinguish between these two fragrances after the top note fades away.

Intrigued by the comments suggesting that this scent resembles Fierce, I wished for it blindly for my birthday. After wearing Fierce the day before, I immediately put on Legend Intense the next day.
For about an hour, I couldn't detect any similarity to the long-lasting favorite from A&F, as Legend first hit me with a ripe and juicy pineapple, or rather, wafted it around my nose.
With a tearful eye (since it reminded me nothing of Fierce) and a joyful eye (I really like the scent of pineapple), I was curious about the further development of the fragrance.
And lo and behold ......................, after about an hour, the tropical fruit bid me farewell, leaving behind a Fierce clone.
For me and my amateur nose, I couldn't detect any difference.

Legend Intense has an absolute right to exist for me. On one hand, I like Fierce, and on the other hand, the "original" is not available everywhere and sometimes comes at inflated prices.

The only downside, in my opinion, is the longevity, as it lasts about 5-6 hours on me, clearly falling short of Fierce, while the sillage definitely has the potential to announce someone upon entering.

For anyone who likes Fierce and this direction, I give a clear recommendation to test it. Don't let the top note confuse you.

or rather the development into a skin scent that can't really convince.
That's how I feel about this specimen from Montblanc.

The scent clearly reminds me of Fierce by Abercrombie & Fitch and can be compared to the regular Montblanc Legend.
However, it doesn't come across as fresh, but rather a bit muted.

After the first spray, one thinks this candidate has real power and is certainly comparable to Fierce in terms of longevity and sillage, if not even better.

I should actually revise my previous comment on Fierce, as Legend Intense is certainly not the better Fierce, but just a weak representative of it.

Initially, it made a better impression on me, as it smelled a bit finer and didn't come across as so clumsy and cheap.
But after a very short time, it simply turns into a skin scent without much impact.
It's a shame that I bought this fragrance too hastily; I should have tested it more thoroughly.

Well, with a purchase price of about 35 euros for 100ml, the scent is okay and wearable for everyday use.

Unfortunately, the sillage is too weak for an Intense version; the scent becomes too close to the skin too quickly, and while the longevity is good, it doesn't really convince me.
Conclusion:

The scent is suitable for everyday wear, wearable in the office as well as in leisure time.
Purchase is only recommended online, as it is simply too expensive in the store around the corner, and for that price, you can get something better.
Unfortunately, I cannot recommend buying it, as the scent can't really convince.
No one really needs it, unless you're looking for a toned-down version of Fierce, which is also cheaper and has slightly better longevity than the regular Legend.

This flanker may not become a legend for me, but it is certainly more varied than the Legend.

Legend Intense starts with a crisp, fresh fruitiness that is not too sweet and brings a strong sillage in the first half hour. Really delicious, this citrusy pineapple! However, the tropical getaway doesn’t last too long, as after about three-quarters of an hour, the MLI invites us into a garage, where the mechanic's haze feels a bit too strong in contrast to the pineapple above, which is now increasingly diluted. Although it remains perceptible, it soon becomes one-dimensional and thin in the background. This mix of fruit and lead is handled better by the Legend, as it feels more harmonious and subtly balanced, albeit also more monotonous. After all, it primarily relies on the warmth of the tonka bean. While that does come through in the Intense as well, it only happens hours later, after the garage door opens again and we step out into a pleasantly woody environment, which then establishes itself as a mild base of the fragrance.

Overall, Legend Intense feels both masculine and sweet at the same time, and I can attest to its good sillage and longevity. However, I prefer linear fragrances, so it’s not for me. If you prefer variety [first fruit, then lead, then wood], this Montblanc is certainly the most versatile Legend - alongside the pitstop in the heart note.

The pineapple definitely makes this fresh and masculine scent more exciting than the conventional Legend.
Which isn't really hard, as the conventional one reminds me more of a Dior Sauvage imitation.
A little tip: To really get something out of it, you should spray on more than just twice. The scent loses its power very quickly and doesn't last long.
Have fun with it!

Citrus and ylang make this tropical, but not beachy. A creamy yellow floral with a huge tonka accord in the drydown. I enjoy this combo; it's laid back & easy going. Definitely ticks toward feminine, but that heavy tonka *I think* makes this possibly unisex.

Here I go again with comparisons, but calls to mind frags like Keiko Mecheri Un Jour d'Ete, Kenzo's World Power, and even Bvlgari Goldea. Has this great salted skin feel, like I've spent all day in the sun. Lasts ages. Did I mention the tonka?!

Pear and tuberose are definitely not among my favorite ingredients. I actually downright hate pear.
I don't know exactly what happened here, but I LIKE Signature Absolue. I even have to raise my rating. The more I wear it, the more I like it. I also liked Signature EAU DE PARFUM, but that has nothing to do with this flanker.

Absolue is a tuberose cream underlined by tonka, beautifully fruity, soft with a certain twist; the pear does not stand out, those fine fruity sprinkles that I like so much probably come more from ylang-ylang combined with mandarin. The tuberose here is not the typical sweet gum-like scent but rather very subtle. I don't smell any cucumber (as sometimes mentioned here) at all.

With cedar and amber in the base, it gets a stable foundation from which the fragrance is carried through the many exciting phases of its development. The sweetness decreases over time, it becomes softer and warmer, almost embracingly beautiful and cozy. The fruity sprinkles can still be smelled beautifully much later on.
The scent is continuously creamy-soft like a body butter that gently spreads around you as an aura.
Absolue is a sunny-warm floral-fruity fragrance that conveys a cheerful impression overall.
However, at over 20°, it is too much for me, and you shouldn't overspray Signature Absolue, as it can quickly become annoying, even for those around you; the sillage should not be underestimated. It radiates quite a bit but leaves behind a wonderfully sweet fruity scent in the room. Beautiful enough to make you kneel.
No blind buy - definitely test beforehand!
All in all, a really beautiful fragrance - one should not expect it to smell like Signature EAU DE PARFUM, but those who are not set in their ways and like tuberose will enjoy this scent.

Should I or shouldn't I... I kept asking myself this question while walking back and forth the whole time. The scent constantly changed on my skin, and I was curious to see how it would develop further. After half an hour, only a creamy, powdery fragrance remained from the fruity beginning. And yet, I bought it. Personally, I miss the sweetness afterwards, but with other fragrances, I miss the powdery aspect. So I will combine this scent with another one. Because the longevity of this fragrance is really good.

I was definitely there to try it out 5 times before I bought it. For me, the Signature Original was nothing, as that Solero ice cream note, which is initially so beautiful, also left a sticky sweetness that I didn't like.
Signature Absolue has a non-listed - but detected by many - melon-cucumber note. And that was the argument FOR this fragrance for me. After extensive testing, as I said, I bought it. But now I can also understand the reservations of many Original fans.
A sprayer of Absolue on the arm was fine, however when you apply it seriously - and I am truly not Team-Overspray - my goodness, it is then exhausting.. It indeed has something 90s about it.. Between one spray and 4, there are worlds with this scent. It becomes too much for me and I would feel uncomfortable going to the office with this fragrance - out of concern for disturbing my colleagues.
And at the same time, it is also somehow beautiful... So for those who, like me, hesitated - I would actually advise against it.. If you are into 90s florals, please go for it. There probably won't be many who wear this fragrance...
As for the description: it is indeed fresh, in a melon-floral way. Very dominant florals are present - the flowers are very homogeneously blended. The drydown remains floral. I perceive the sillage as strong. The price-performance ratio is definitely given here. And if you are into this kind of thing, it's a bullseye. I like it too much to sell it - but somehow I also don't like to spray it on.. Therefore, I couldn't think of a good title for this review....

I like sweet perfumes, but this was akin to drenching my body in maraschino cherries while standing next to an incense burner. Those are the only notes I got from beginning to end. Very linear and boring and way too sweet! Not at all elegant or classy like I'd expect from a brand like Montblanc. Actually, it's almost terrible. Any celebrity could bottle this and you wouldn't be surprised about that at all. That bottle is sure gorgeous, though!!!

review_title: Surrounded by raspberry-musk clouds... I think I'm dreaming...
review_content:
Femme de Montblanc is an incredibly feminine, alluring, captivating scent that is melt-in-your-mouth beautiful.
It is fruity-chocolatey sweet. Quite sweet, in fact, when you sniff directly at the scented spot. The sillage, however, is something else entirely and even more captivating than this already delicious fruity sweetness. When I wave my arm, I am enveloped by a wonderfully beautiful raspberry-musk cloud. So incredibly pure and soft, yet so delicately enveloping. For a moment, I close my eyes and float on this fruity cloud. Wrapped in cotton, I let myself drift and be enchanted.
I would say that the musk plays a very important and central role here.
It prevents the scent from drifting into gourmand territory and becoming too sticky.
I don't consciously smell patchouli and vetiver, but I think they are well woven into the fragrance and ground it, so you don't float away on clouds and never come back ; )

Femme de Montblanc is a flattering scent that seductively emphasizes the feminine delicacy of its wearer and captivates the surroundings like an invisible silky thread. You receive many compliments and would even like to shower yourself with compliments because you are so fascinated by the cloud that clouds your mind and envelops you so softly.

I am very, very surprised by the perfume. Convince yourself of this femininely delicate sillage that makes you smell irresistible. It is my current signature scent and a great all-year-round fragrance.
With it, I always feel well-dressed (even without clothing)
Give it a try :)))

Today, my husband held an impressive bottle in front of my nose.

Appropriately for Montblanc, an ink pot - he said with a smile.
Oh - how gallant!

As a school child, I owned a Montblanc fountain pen, a beautiful utensil in green - black with a golden nib.
I wrote every one of my essays with it, feeling like a poet.
The poetry flowed smoothly from the nib.
Letters should only be written this way!
Preferably love letters.

And this slightly nostalgic association is also fulfilled by the fragrance.

It combines style with poetry and awakens tender feelings.

Cardamom and cinnamon start off softly spicy, refreshed by the pineapple.
The rose appears romantic - like the word "back then," which sounds so beautiful in my ears.
The chocolate note is nutty and comforting, like the words of a dear letter that you read with warmth in your heart.

Even though my husband is not a love letter writer - this gift says more than a thousand words.

review_title: There is no snow in the air...
review_content:
I ordered this fragrance blindly as a sample and I am not disappointed.

The first moment is floral-fruity, then a lovely sweetness and delicate spicy nuances come into play.
The jasmine is not too opulent and the other notes do not take center stage either. It creates a very harmonious blend that later shifts slightly towards a powdery scent.
The chocolate can only be sensed, but it is gently present in the aura.
A soft and feminine fragrance that does not overwhelm.
Well, the name is indeed somewhat misleading. With Mont Blanc, I expected snow-covered peaks and an icy winter breeze.
None of that, but that shouldn't stop anyone from giving it a try, as it is a very beautiful fragrance.

review_title: Classy perfume, beautiful bottle, wrong name!!
review_content:
I simply ordered the Femme de Mont Blac!
And I think it’s wonderfully crafted!

This scent is sweet and aromatic, and with the heliotrope
combined with the floral and rose aromas, it unfolds a vanilla
floral oriental fragrance that is perfect for a summer night.
Like an oriental garden at night, you can smell the jasmine with its
sweet heaviness and succumb to this SCENT!!!
I don’t really smell the raspberries! But the musk and a hint of patchouli set the tone.

This Mont Blac is simply classy and has a fascination like this
wonderful Nuit de Ete by Joop that many still remember from the past.

Summer garden at night!

This Femme gives the wearer a fascinating power!

I came across Femme de Mont Blanc quite by chance. I had never heard of her, didn't know her by sight, but suddenly she was there. She came to me with two other pleasantly scented guests, whom I had been eagerly anticipating. When I opened the door, there was a third guest. I was, of course, a bit surprised. With barely concealed curiosity, I observed her. What would she say,...

Opened with an unusual plastic/metallic type of note which quickly morphed into a subtle amber. In final dry down a woody note appeared, blending with the amber. Very generic. Nothing to write home about.

Sillage and projection are practically non-existent. Very tight skin scent. I mean, after the first hour, it's nose to skin to detect any of the scent. No idea what the longevity is like but does it matter? For such an intimate scent, who cares if it lasts 2 hours or 20 hours?

Overall a big disappointment. "Meisterstück" is German for masterpiece. This is definitely no masterpiece. Not available yet at discounters so the retail price of $140 is way too much for what this is - basically weak amber/woody fumes.

If you just read the reviews on here you'd think this was the worst fragrance ever created, an abomination and that montblanc is spitting in the face of every fragrance creator/lover out there with this creation. However at the time of this entry it has a score of 7.6 by 55 users so some people are enjoying it. I am definitely one of those people. To me this is the one of montblancs greatest and I don't care who disagrees. It's a very dark and woody fragrance for sure but there's some amber in there along with some incense that gives it this sort of inky smell, in a good way. Best of all I would classify this as a spicy - oriental - woody/smokey fragrance. Not cough out your lungs smokey but just enough to let you know that it's there. It wasn't a room filler for me but it was enough for passerbys to get a whiff of and get me quite a few compliments every time I've worn it. Lasts all day long too. Really reminds me of something that I can't quite put my finger on, probably something discontinued by Gucci or Tom Ford or something. I dunno but I really like this. for Montblanc on this one.

I firmly believe that the performance is overrated, I very much prefer smelling great for 4 hours rather than smelling meh for 10. With that being said, this one is simply disappointing.

It opens up beautifully, reminds me a bit of Black by CDG, one of my all-time favourite designers. You get a very pleasant and easy-to-like smokiness, maybe even some warm amber and a just a touch of sweetness. For a moment it evokes the scent of high-quality paper, perhaps intentionally, considering what Montblanc is known for. And then, before it even fully develops, the scent disappears completely.

I gave it another chance on a humid and relatively warm, but not hot day, which I thought should have helped its performance. Still nothing.

I’m incredibly disappointed, I had such high hopes.

Don’t get me wrong, it’s worth trying, you should give it a go anyway, it’s really interesting, and who knows, maybe it’ll have more staying power on your skin. From me, unfortunately it’s a no, especially at this price point.

What a tremendous collection this Montblanc has. The four released are very good perfumes, original, purposeful, even bold. The bad thing is that designers charge us almost niche prices so we can enjoy a scent that can be confused with any other. Black Meisterstuck is a tough, solid, direct composition, just three notes that, at the top, display an incense reminiscent of Loewe Anonymous, but it doesn't go that way; this evolves into dark woods, dry, bitter, almost medicinal, and slightly amber. I imagined it would be something warmer, for winter use, but on the contrary, this could work well almost year-round. It's for dressing casually, seriously, with a frown. It is truly a rugged and distinguished perfume. Fair performance, 5 to 6 hours are enough, projected for an hour perhaps. Quite unique, except for the price it is well worth it.

Yesss, it’s a designer, I get it. Still, one should expect more than this watery concoction with no character.

Especially with the "Masterpiece," I had high hopes due to the association with the luxurious writing instrument and the focus on only two fragrance notes! Serge Lutens takes similar paths and does so with great success. So it is possible.

However, the result in this case is not even disappointing, even when you lower your expectations.

In short, there is almost nothing to say (which I will do in great detail shortly):

You have to search for the "scent" with a nasal magnifying glass; I notice absolutely nothing of the incense, neither on the test strip nor on the skin. Ambrofix is listed, but nothing comes through. I have some of these fragrance chemicals at home and trust myself to smell them. Either the concentration is simply too low or it’s something else. Overall, a very light sweetness, a hint of woodiness. That’s it... and you can either like that or not, and it doesn’t have to be bad if only the longevity and sillage were right.

The sillage is almost non-existent: I and the salesperson had to really get about 10 cm close to perceive the scent. Mind you: right after spraying.

There is no scent progression; it remains the same as when sprayed and weakens minute by minute.

The longevity is miserable as well. I was in the perfumery for about an hour and then drove home. Upon arriving home, I could hardly perceive anything close to my skin. It could be due to the interplay of my skin and the fragrance, but the same picture was presented on the test strip.

The best part of the whole thing is the bottle, which looks really nice, though it doesn’t quite hold up in terms of tactile experience. One is used to better from Montblanc... although, if the only positive aspect of a perfume is that the bottle, despite being of average quality, looks quite pretty, that’s already an olfactory confession of failure.

For the price, it’s a real disappointment: a lot of money for a hint of nothing. Maybe a few more complementary fragrance notes and a higher concentration of them would have been better?

Conclusion: Just because you own a Montblanc Meisterstück doesn’t automatically mean you create top notes. The substance must also fit.

review_title: Black Fountain Pen Meets Midnight Mass
review_content: Short and sweet: Black Meisterstück opens with cool incense wafts, melts into creamy amber, and ends in a dry, almost earthy-green vetiver echo. A dark, inky statement - elegant rather than loud, distinguished instead of sweet. Fragrance Journey in Detail 1. Opening (0 - 15 Min.) - “Ink on Hot Parchment” Immediate incense punch: cold, smoky, and slightly metallic, like...

Initially, this fragrance brought to mind familiar aquatic-citrus scents like Tommy Bahama "Maritime" or Armaf "All You Need is Love" – a formula so common, I could probably name dozens of similar concoctions. It's agreeable enough, but undeniably generic.
Like many Montblanc EDTs I've encountered (even their EDPs like Legend and Explorer underwhelm in performance), this one requires liberal application and frequent re-spraying to make an impact.
However, at its affordable price point (around $32), it's a decent everyday option. It's inoffensive and suitable for close quarters like carpools, elevators, and the office. Just don't expect it to be a standout date night choice or to last through a summer day or a night out dancing.

A spicy, oriental fragrance for men, but very soft and not harmful or repulsive to you or the people around you.

The fragrance begins with a mixture of light cardamom until the fragrance settles on a light and pure base of suede and tonka beans.

The fragrance is very masculine and suitable for winter evenings, the scent of the fragrance is very good, lasting for 4 consecutive hours, and the longevity may reach 6 hours.

I have received so many compliments on this fragrance.

Conclusion: One of the best winter fragrances I have used.

But it didn’t live up to the recent YouTube hype it got. It was hyped up to be a “beast mode” monster, and it is quite far from that. It’s got a nice scent, but as far as performance goes, it’s your typical Mont Blanc, 3ft radius, 4-6hr show.

It has a nice scent, sweet with a touch of spice (similar to CK One Shock in my opinion), and it’s not expensive at all, so don’t think I “hate” it, it’s just that I was expecting MORE from it after the vid I watched.

I personally get a decent 3ft of projection radius, with a modest sillage trail, and 4-6 hours of longevity. For $30, I can’t complain. A decent buy at a decent price; no more, no less.

review_title: Presence d'Un Homme, not d'Une Femme
review_content:
This is an incredible woody vanilla, more woody than vanilla to me. Unisex, more masculine than feminine on me, and so so very wearable by a guy. Just a bit of pepper to make it interesting. I don't sense any florals. It has a masculine edge to it that wears like cedar, harboring close to classic aftershave. It smells amazingly clean & uncomplicated, and it wears close to skin on me. I like it but not enough to keep it.

It's great office fragrance for either a man or a woman. For wood-loving fumies like @malegria, this is a must try!

Mar
02
2011

----

Alternative review -

Presence is a very masculine fragrance for a feminine, in my opinion. It seems to me to have cedar in it, which always wears like aftershave on me. Or, perhaps it is the patchouli. Regardless, this is not one for flower-lovers. It's classified as an oriental vanilla, but it seems like a woody to me. Probably best for those who seek out non-floral fragrances.

The fragrance is solid & good, but definitely try this one before you buy this one. It's difficult to wear, and I think more men would wear it off-the-shelf than women. Unique bottle, though.

What a scent! This is a fragrance that has so much to offer; longevity, sillage and note combination. The ratings do not give a true picture of the qualities of the product. I dare say that it is much better than the rating.
It starts out fresh and romantic. The combination of mandarin and pepper works so well. Then comes the heart: flowers and woods - beautifully mixed. It lasts for quite some time. At least five to six hours. In my opinion a great scent that you want to get to know.
The bottle is a beautiful design. It is both interesting and classic. I like the play between the metal and the glass, shaped like a circle. In my opinion it is greatly done.
Do try!
288/365

What can I say, the second I met this scent, I knew we'd be together forever. Over the years I have bought at least 20 bottles. Sadly, it's no longer made, but if and when I find a bottle I always buy it. Even if I'm still half-way through the one I have.
I remember misplacing the only bottle I brought with me on a trip. The entire apartment was turned upside down, looking for it. It just disappeared. My sister-in-law, somehow, managed to find a store that sold it. It was delivered that evening, just to make sure I had it when I leave. Thankfully, we found the original lost bottle! Phew! Exhaling!

Women are just EVERYWHERE!!! Uh, wait, first of all, hello everyone :D
So… women are just EVERYWHERE!!! Well, one must admit that guys are everywhere too… but guys don’t scare you as much when you’re alone (or outnumbered) in a place dominated by you women!!

Oh dear, I could totally get hysterical about all sorts of things just because the name of this fragrance means something like “Presence of a Woman,” and that’s only if I haven’t totally misinterpreted the name… right now in the new year, I should probably annoy you ladies less and… uh… love you more?? Oh, I have no idea :D

But before I say something totally wrong, I’d better get to this fragrance by Montblanc. Still, my text here is surely better than some of the texts from fragrance manufacturers. In this one, it states among other things that the fragrance is suitable for all women who feel “extraordinarily sexy and elegant.” And now try to find fragrance descriptions that say something similar! Well? What did you find? Yes, exactly! That pretty much applies to all sorts of women’s fragrance descriptions, doesn’t it? He he :D
And to be honest, this doesn’t only happen with fragrances but with all sorts of products, because of course a manufacturer has to write things like “The fragrance for the elegant woman of today!” to sell the product, it’s just a shame that all this sounds very clichéd nowadays :D

Anyway, as long as the fragrance (or product) underneath doesn’t suffer, I’m fine with it. After all, you have me here for crazy and silly texts :DD
So, let’s get to the fragrance!

The Fragrance:
I smell a slightly spicy mandarin, of course, because alongside the mandarin (which smells good by the way), there’s also pepper involved, which is neither stuffy nor inappropriate for the mandarin. Both fragrance notes smell quite pleasant, although the scent leaves a slightly diluted impression in the top note. Violets quickly join in and give the fragrance a lightly powdery sweetness.
A little later, I still smell mandarins and pepper, while I also perceive a bit of rose and woody notes. The woody notes are gentle here and not sharply herbaceous like cedar or something, smelling more like sandalwood and similar. All this is still accompanied by a “splash” of vanilla, which becomes a bit stronger later in the base.
In the base, the fragrance is sweet and peppery. It now primarily smells of vanilla with some pepper, while the citrus notes like mandarins have almost completely disappeared. There are still woods and a slight earthy patchouli note.

The Sillage and Longevity:
The sillage is moderate, so you can smell it at a short distance for a little while.
The longevity is quite good at about seven to eight hours, although it is noticeably weaker in the later hours.

The Bottle:
The bottle is round, with the bottle being placed upside down. This way, the actual spray head, which also serves as a cap, is at the bottom, allowing you to see the glassy and clear part and thus the fragrance liquid on the upper side of the bottle. An interesting concept that also looks good.

Conclusion:
So, hmm… the fragrance is not bad, but it doesn’t exactly blow you away. It falls into that category of fragrances that are actually pleasant but just not extraordinary enough that you’d want it immediately, at least not right away. In any case, it’s worth trying out. I think that Présence is an all-rounder that works well for all seasons and can even be worn for many occasions. It is sweet and pleasant for going out, but also not very intensely radiant and overwhelming, so you could wear it at work too.

It smells very feminine, and this, even though the pepper is always noticeable. But the pepper is mild and thus also smells pleasant. Besides, it seems you ladies really like pepper; why else do I constantly hear things from you like “Get lost! Go where the pepper grows!!!”,… *sigh* No wonder I never dare to ask anyone out on a date when you all get so angry :D

Anyway, as I said, the fragrance is worth a test, even though you wouldn’t miss anything if you skipped it. With that, I’ll come to an end, and yes,… I wish you all a lovely evening. And I… I really need to find out where that mysterious place is where the pepper grows… :D

review_title: Light Spicy Oriental with a Touch of Sweetness
review_content:
This is how this beautiful, soft, round fragrance comes across to me.
The floral notes are somewhat underrepresented, which I really like.
There is only a hint of fruit, a bit of pepper, but the woody notes and patchouli are clearly in the foreground. This is the case right after the first spray and remains so.

When I first tested the fragrance years ago, I found the name a bit strange, as it had almost a somewhat harsh, masculine quality to me. But that’s exactly what I like - sometimes.
(I also wore Minotaure by Paloma Picasso for years).

A warm fragrance, perfect for gray autumn days. Moreover, it is a scent that is not overly common, but somewhat underestimated, which in my eyes is another plus point.

The longevity is good, the sillage is also good, but not intrusive, making it absolutely suitable for the office.

review_title: 4ajbukisja. Or: Orient meets Occident. A Hint of Home
review_content: 4ajbukisja was a belly dancer. And she was beautiful, the most beautiful young woman in her home village, it would later be said. Even when she had her hair cut boyishly short at the nape and longer (up to three centimeters) on top, and although she was of slender build, her femininity could be perceived from several meters away. Today, twenty years later, gender boundaries...

Following in the footsteps of one of my favorite perfumers and one of my favorite notes, I found this little gem. The name already says a lot about the character of this fragrance, and it definitely has one, and not a little! Like many compositions from this nose, the perfume is powerful! And it's an Eau de Toilette. The start is very strong, presence is felt, nothing here goes unnoticed (or overlooked)... so the subsequent silence was all the more surprising; the scent briefly became quite quiet only to then surprise with an even more dominant presence. So, it's not for lovers of subtle tones. When I smelled the fragrance, it occurred to me: it seems designed as an accessory for a power lady in a pantsuit who smokes. So, to get rid of it? Well, let's see... sometimes it doesn't hurt to appear stricter than one is. A sheep in wolf's clothing, so to speak... The whole "strict" impression probably comes from the pepper and woods, I assume. The perfumer has indeed managed to create a juicy wood scent with a very subtle sweetness. So, a masterpiece for sure! The quality leaves nothing to be desired. For me, it also has a slight sexy touch. This is, of course, very subjective. By the way, I think a man could also wear this well. I don't know how things were back in 2002 with unisex fragrances. In any case, I'm glad to have gotten to know it.

review_title: sweet and bitter at the same time
review_content:
it initially smells sweet (orchid and vanilla), but also has a bitter note (mahogany, sandalwood) with a splash of orange and a lot of patchouli and a pinch of dark pepper.
It is strong, spicy but not heavily oriental. A few more cyclamen would not have hurt.
Sweet mandarin underneath. The woods disappear very quickly.

review_title: If not for men, then at least unisex
review_content:
Obviously, Mr. Almairac must have relied heavily on pepper, patchouli, and woods when composing this fragrance, making it a clear men's scent for me. Even after 30 minutes, I can only sense the flowers and vanilla faintly and only perceive this harsh masculine character. With the first spray, I immediately thought of "hooker diesel," and I admit that I simply had to have the bottle. That’s also what’s interesting about this scent: The bottle promises class and looks really good as a decoration, but only for looking at.
I’m really surprised that production has been discontinued, as you can still get the 75 ml for as low as € 27.99 at various popular perfume chains, which is certainly worth it for the fragrance.
It will continue to circulate; my dad will be pleased.

I like mandarins for eating, I also like mandarin juice for drinking, but the mandarin in "Présence d'Une Femme" develops an unpleasant sour note on my skin that reminds me of vomit. Mr. Almairac, who is certainly no amateur, surely did not intend it this way, so I attribute this discomfort to my skin chemistry (I had a similar experience with Cassis Douceur by Varens, a fragrance highly praised by other reviewers).

But anyway, I simply cannot like PdUF, even though the description of the fragrance notes sounds quite attractive, with all the wood. In fact, the sour (mandarin?) note remains quite present for a long time, well over an hour. The subsequent sweet floral note no longer smells sour, but still fails to convince me completely; besides, an hour of sour top note is definitely too long. The base comes across as rather sweet and vanilla-like, where is the wood, where is the patchouli? Three different woods are supposed to be there, and also patchouli, but the only thing that is really noticeable is the vanilla and a lingering hint of fruitiness.

By the way, the bottle is a kind of intelligence test. You first have to figure out where the spray button is. It’s at the bottom of the bottle. Well, on the second (or third?) try, I figured it out ;-)

After work, I quickly went into town, straight into Müller.. I actually just wanted to buy a little something, but suddenly I found myself in front of a beautiful woman who was clearly unable to get enough of a fragrance. She smiled briefly, took the scent in her hand, and inhaled the whole mist she had sprayed into the air. She breathed in deeply and finally let out a soft "Aaah." How wonderful it is when someone is truly excited about a fragrance, when they absorb it as if it were a drug. She stood there, intoxicated, closed her eyes, and swayed her head back and forth. Yes, the scent had captivated her. She was enchanted. I love it when I come home stressed from work and see happy, content people. It makes me feel better too. I had to smile, and she smiled back, took the largest dimension of the fragrance, and happily went to the checkout. A wonderful breeze of passion and feminine elegance accompanied her. A very beautiful scent! - It hits you right away when sprayed and leaves you in awe for a brief moment. Yes, she must be in a good mood now, and I became particularly curious. What kind of scent is this? Montblanc. I've heard it somewhere, but I didn't pay attention or it simply passed me by unnoticed.

I slowly approached, briefly sniffed the sprayer. It hit me right from the first spray, and I inhaled the scent just like she did earlier. God, this scent is glorious! A warm spring rain cascades over my senses - The bitter orange falls into a cool mist and brings spring to the forefront. A light scent of an unripe pear spreads and slowly transforms into a warm symphony of woody notes and lily of the valley. Warm, sensual, yet this scent cries out for recognition. A fragrance that is not too loud but still noticeable, as it is very intense in its opening, yet without being overwhelming. It is not sweet, rather a bit unripe, but that is part of its charm. The bitterness becomes apparent after a while, and I sprayed some on my wrist because I found it so wonderful. Because I enjoy being drenched in warm rain and letting it wash over me. The warmth intensifies, and I leave Müller. Packed with 2 test strips, which I kept sniffing. I must say, it had really lodged itself in my memory. At home, I took a long shower, and when I briefly thought of the scent, the warm breeze shot up my nose. Yes, it blew me away. I retrieved the test strips again and took a deep breath to make sure I didn't miss anything. The scent is still warm, but a slight touch of orange can be detected, surrounded by vanilla candles. Like warm wax, the ingredient flows into the fragrance, making it even more feminine and, above all, more intense. It only became quiet after a few minutes. The vanilla has burned off. Only the woodiness remained, refined with the lovely lily of the valley and a hint of musk. The musk is quite shy but holds on firmly until the end and fades away in a flame. It started with a bang and ended with a rush.

My daughter asked me what was wrong with me, as I was so lost while walking back and forth through the apartment, constantly exclaiming "wonderful." I silently handed her the test strips. She looked at me with wide eyes and without really smelling them, said, "Women's perfume!" She raised an eyebrow and looked at me with questioning eyes. She took a sniff, and I waited for her reaction. "Mhm.. Dad, WHAT IS THIS?" I smiled and said I had stumbled upon it today. She took a few more sniffs, holding the strips tightly in her hand as if someone might take them away. Her reaction was the same as mine. She was practically glowing and raving about the scent that truly elevates the ecstasy of spring. She wouldn't let go, and now she was the one wandering through the apartment like a confused person, sniffing the strips as if it were the last drug of the century. It made a strong impression on my daughter's mind. She couldn't stop raving, and I was still lost in my warm rain..

This scent is for women who love to show themselves without wearing too much makeup or clothing. A hint of nothing and this scent! A divine connection. Women who skillfully express their personality, who enter a room and remain silent yet draw all eyes and noses to themselves - that's what Legend p.F. does too. It projects its character outward. It intoxicates the senses, never comes off as arrogant or cheap. It sneaks in like a parasite and devises plans to shape the senses with its fingers.. Gently but skillfully.
Tomorrow I will buy the fragrance..

This scent is unique. It rushes through my veins when I think of it. It definitely deserves much more recognition. Many fragrances go in that direction, but they are mostly all the same or pompously over-sweetened with vanilla or some violets..

It is simply wonderful and really good. I can't say more than that. It has delighted and intoxicated me. It would be something deadly for me if I smelled this fragrance on a woman I desire..

A downfall of my senses..

A toast to Montblanc!

review_title: A fragrance that isn't meant to be worn every day.
review_content:
What a delight this scent is! How pleasantly soft, friendly, and mild it is - after all my tests of demanding, albeit impressive niche fragrances. I spray myself with Legend and breathe a sigh of relief: Citrusy freshness envelops me with a slightly bitter hint of fruit and peel, the well-composed interplay of the mildness and sharpness of neroli, bitter orange, and orange blossoms gives the fragrance balance and allows it to float in the perfect and thus elegantly appealing middle between boring cozy scent and prickly bristle. I don't explicitly perceive pear, but rather a somewhat indistinct fruitiness that adds a restrained sweetness and calms the citrus notes.

After less than three minutes, something floral and slightly creamy joins in. I don't perceive the floral note as lily of the valley; rather, I feel that both a hint of tuberose and a touch of daffodil are woven in, taming the jasmine so that it can show itself from its finest and mildest side. The slight creaminess must come from the musk. Here, I must give high praise: The musk substitute used here is one of the few that I find tolerable, even pleasant, and that does not tend to give me feelings of suffocation. However, I must say that I don't necessarily smell musk here. As mentioned, it is more of a soft creaminess that connects the citrusy, floral, and fruity notes, now also sweetish, in the background.

One might think that fruits, primarily citrus fruits with flowers and peels, a bit of jasmine, dampened by tuberose and daffodil, underlaid with creamy musk would be ubiquitous and nothing special, just another ordinary scent that has been smelled many times before. But that is not the case. Once again, it shows that the whole is more than the sum of its parts.

I like Legend exceptionally well. It is a fragrance that always works when everything else is too demanding or conspicuous. Legend is feminine, but not vampy. Legend is warm, but not cloying. Legend is fresh, but by no means aquatic. Legend is bright, but not lightweight. Legend is sweetish, but not sticky. Legend is in the middle, but not mediocre. Legend is natural, but not naive. Legend is noble, without being elitist.

In my opinion, Legend rightly bears its name: Universally known, legendary components of perfumes that have been cherished by equally legendary divas for centuries are harmoniously honored here and presented anew with a more fruity focus.
In a certain way, this is very conservative. But doesn't the time-tested deserve active attention, a new perspective, and a modern yet preserving way of being showcased and brought to the forefront?
I think so.

From my side, there is only one single point of criticism, which probably has more to do with my particular nose: I adapt to the scent incredibly quickly. After about three hours, I could reapply. This impulse must be resisted, as the fragrance does not have such a short longevity or low sillage. Even two days later, I can still clearly perceive it on my clothing - however, only if I haven't worn it in the meantime.

And so I must hold back: I shouldn't wear it daily, no matter how much I want to.

Having read quite a bit of good things about Montblanc here, I was motivated to test this fragrance.

Right from the start, it smells wonderfully fruity and refreshing. The bitter orange is immediately present and gives Legend something extraordinary and herb-fruity. As the fragrance develops, it feels like all the notes are arranged around the fruit. The note seems to support the entire scent. The pear also comes through very clearly for me, just as refreshing and juicy. However, the fruits do not remind me of an overripe fruit basket that has been dumped with kilos of sugar. Rather, they evoke the image of fruit that has just been freshly cut. The top note hits me like a sparkling, crisp-fresh bomb. Legend gains warmth from unobtrusive jasmine and orange blossom. Both make the fragrance feminine and sensual. The lily of the valley adds a pleasant sweetness. The base is pleasantly woody and cozy. However, the vanilla does not make it a boring uniform blend, but gives that pleasant feeling of security. The base, so to speak, embraces the heart note. Even here, the bitter orange is still perceptible.

The perfume is very balanced for me and makes me long for spring. It is never synthetic or shrill. The bottle immediately appealed to me. It fits well in the hand and is beautifully designed otherwise. The color matches the scent well.
I think the perfume can be worn for all occasions. I find the longevity to be enormous. Throughout the day, my nose keeps catching a delightful whiff of it. Unfortunately, I can't give the overall package a hundred percent, as the sillage could be stronger.

Nevertheless, I place this fragrance at the very top of my wish list, as I can imagine it as the perfect companion through all seasons and I simply feel wonderful with it.

For the report card, there were always a few heartfelt words from my parents and a small gift.
The math grade of five was standard, softened by ones and twos in languages - including Latin.
This comforted my parents about my number dyslexia.

However, they found my handwriting to be in need of improvement, and so one day there was a long package on my report card, containing an incredibly beautiful black-green fountain pen with a real gold nib.
Montblanc.
My heart raced at the sight of the beautiful, stylish writing instrument.
Even the process of drawing ink from the classic ink bottle brought me joy.
It was a completely different experience than the mundane task of changing plastic cartridges.

And the nib glided smoothly and effortlessly across the paper, like a sailboat over a still lake - giving my immature teenage handwriting grace and elegance.
I decided that love letters and poems would flow from my pen this way.

And the scent that reminds me of this beautiful gift is graceful and elegant - with a captivating dose of simple elegance.
The opening of full pear and cool neroli is extraordinarily successful and alluring.
Indian jasmine is exquisitely exotic, and the lily of the valley is delightfully cozy.
The woody notes appear noble and classic, warmed by gentle vanilla.

I see myself again in my old classroom, lost in thought as I dip my Montblanc into the ink bottle, and then energetically transfer Fried's "It is what it is" into my German notebook.

The name Legend is well chosen - both for the classic among fountain pens and for this special fragrance.

review_title: "The ladies must surely like this sweet floral stuff"
review_content:
said the plump fountain pen manufacturer to his marketing department as he puffed on his cigar. In the lab, they quickly mixed something together so that the lady accompanying her husband, who was buying a fountain pen, would not leave the Montblanc house without making a small purchase.

LpF shows a bit of fruit at the beginning "oh, that was pear?!", immediately followed and dominated by an extremely sweet flower "very reminiscent of the overly sweet artificial Tiare from the unspeakable YR-Monoi" and then stays like that for a very long time. In the end, the obligatory vanilla naturally appears and manages to maintain this dull, heavy sweetness for many hours until the end. I do not recognize any of the individual flowers or woods mentioned in the pyramid. The musk was obviously only used for longevity, as it cannot be distinguished further.

Conclusion for me: Fountain pen yes - Legend pour Femme no!

According to the calendar, it was a spring month in 2013, but the weather still felt like winter. My mood was bad, as I was, like many other people, annoyed by the dark, cold, never-ending winter weather. To improve my mood, my husband took me to our Müller store ("You still have your birthday card, and maybe that will lift your spirits!") and there I saw Legend pour Femme! I...

Well, my first thought about this perfume was - does Montblanc really need to try its hand at perfume as well? The bottle doesn’t immediately catch the eye, but it is very handy and has a simple elegance. Without high expectations, I sprayed a bit on a test strip and sniffed. What can I say, I was thrilled. First, I strongly perceive pear, which probably also gives the...

Thanks to my lovely beauty consultant, I got a miniature. Tested it right on the way home :)

Simple, elegant, harmonious.

It will surely accompany me more and more often.
A legend like the women who inspired this fragrance.

A Kelly Bag, so to speak ;)

What has motivated the luxury brand Montblanc to suddenly start producing perfumes is something only God knows. I received 2 bottles of Legend pour Femme and one bottle of Legend (for men) as a gift during an event, and unfortunately, I find them only mediocre.
The men's fragrance smells exactly how one would imagine an average men's perfume to smell: sporty, nothing special.
The women's fragrance smells incredibly artificial and overpowering, to the point that it almost gives me a headache. But what can you do? The longevity is quite good, and I do use it occasionally during the day on weekdays, although not very happily.
Conclusion: Montblanc, I love your fountain pens and leather goods, but when it comes to fragrances, it's better to leave it be...!

I can't believe it! Love at first Glow has risen again!
Legend pour Femme makes no secret of any developing fragrance notes, but reveals everything it has at the "first sniff." For me, that's peach, neroli (which makes it a bit more mature than Love at first Glow), and a musk-bitter orange combo like in Chopard Happy Spirit. However, the juicy fruits (pear,...) are primarily in focus.
When you take a closer sniff, Legend pour Femme turns out to be nothing more than a "regular" women's fragrance that exists by the hundreds. Floral, sweet, fruity, a bit artificial.
Well, at least the sillage keeps me thinking of my favorite from JLo :D

I received a sample and tested it for the second time. It’s just nothing special for me. Nothing stands out and it smells like nothing. Besides lily of the valley, I can't find anything in the scent that the fragrance pyramid suggests. I wouldn't buy it or recommend it. The longevity is also low.

A very unisex patchouli and vanilla fragrance that is on the woody side of patchouli. It’s a patchouli that’s very rounded and isn’t overly earthy or damp smelling. The vanilla is present but never overbearing to where it goes into gourmand territory. It’s an almost vanilla extract type of vanilla. The ink note is noticeable but it isn’t at all off putting or unwearable. It sits under the patchouli and vanilla and gives this fragrance a bit of “Oh…that’s different. But I like it!” kind of thing.

When I first smelled this, it immediately reminded me of a more formal and better behaved Lush - Lord of Misrule.

It doesn’t have the sharp pepper of LOM and the patchouli is more rounded. The vanilla is also not quite as sweet, but the framework is there.

It’s the perfect corporate goth fragrance. A ride to work blasting Bella Lugosi’s Dead in a black tailored suit that conceals your copious amount of tattoos. Working your normie job and all your co-workers know you’re kind of weird. They just don’t know the full extent of it.

The bottle is absolutely gorgeous but I do have some complaints about the cap. It’s a rubbery plastic cap that just feels so out of place for such an elegant bottle. Plus the rubber or plastic they used on the cap STINKS. This fragrance really could have used a magnetic cap to really set it off. But for a sub $100 fragrance, I can’t complain too much.

An intriguing scent that certainly not everyone will want or can wear. It is definitely not a youthful profile, but it can definitely be worn on many occasions. The fragrance is not necessarily edgy, but in my opinion, it is not a mass-pleaser. Strong projection and good longevity.

The scent reminds me of the smell of pecans. Woody, dry, with a very light nutty sweetness. A strong patchouli note. It feels mature and serious. Perfect for gentlemen and suitable for the office with fewer sprays.

The bottle is solid and the cap is magnetic. The price/quality ratio is good.

Since I really like Legend by Montblanc, I was excited about the Lady Emblem sample.

I expected an elegant, confident scent.
But the title is misleading, as I am enveloped by a very playful, extremely youthful aroma.

Its distinct sweetness is appealing - but it probably suits a dapper girlie, without piercings and tattoos, more than a mature lady.
My charming nieces would likely look great in it.

Blackcurrant jam and raspberry are delicious - but not exactly ladylike.
The peach is beautifully delicate and juicy, and the rose is subtle and budding.
I can't detect the woods behind the floral and fruity curtain.

A sweet, delightful scent - whose age group and message I have already outgrown.
Still, I like it because it is so sweet and uncomplicated.

Nevertheless, the more mature Legend is a better fit for me.

Usually, leather is not a note that I enjoy. It reminds me of cars and it gives me a nauseous feeling. Which is why I was very surprised when this leather forward scent caught my attention. The leather/saffron mix gives way to a powdery, soft, iris musky heart until dying back down to a muted musky/leather combo which goes pretty well with me. As others said below, nothing extreme about it. It is pretty mild and enjoyable if you can get past the punchy opening. It has intrigued me quite a bit and it is worthy of trying if these notes appeal to you, but don't expect a saddle.

Dior Homme 2011 and Ombré Leather fusion:

This one has grown on me. The name is not appropriate. In no way is this fragrance harsh or extreme. This is a very soft, elegant, powdery leather. Velvet Leather is more appropriate name.

The Iris in this is not lipsticky or cloying. It’s rather earthy and vegetal, very comforting nevertheless.

Sits close to the skin but lasts decently long as get whiffs of it all day.

I also love wearing it to bed, it’s so comforting, like a second skin.

Have a feeling it will become a hit

Just like the bottle, so is Lady Emblem L'Eau.

I probably would have never picked it up in my life if it hadn't been shown to me in the perfume store, as it was available in a set with body lotion just before Christmas. So off I went to the tester strip. It was love at the second sniff; at first whiff, I found it okay, but not outstanding. However, on the skin, it developed so beautifully that I "had to" go back to that perfume store while strolling through the pedestrian zone to buy the Montblanc set.

Fragrances with peach are often way too sweet and artificial for me, but this one is different. You get what you see - the bottle beautifully reflects the scent. The blue color signals clarity and purity, which the fragrance certainly possesses. However, it is not a classic clean scent either, as the shape and faceting of the bottle are too playful.

For me, Lady Emblem is a lovely fresh fragrance that can be worn at any time of the year and day, and for all occasions. It doesn't annoy anyone, yet it can be sensed well - and for a long time too. I can still smell it quite distinctly on my sweater in the evening after I sprayed it on in the morning before work.

The perfume should be perfect for those who like it fresh but not too aquatic, who enjoy being surrounded by subtle flowers and are not averse to sweetness. Mind you, not caramel or cotton candy, but rather a light and fruity sweetness. Certainly, Lady Emblem L'Eau is not the greatest hit that perfume history has ever written - but it doesn't have to be! Sometimes it is not so easy to discover a calm, feminine gem among all the La Vie Est Belles.

Spring is here - and on the tables in the department store, white, pink, yellow, and light green little boxes are crowding together.

This reminds me of a pastel-colored spring meadow.

I reach for the light green Montblanc Bloom - and I am pleasantly surprised by the sprayer.
I like it better than the pink EdT, which I found too girly for myself.
But L'eau is delicate yet expressive, and it skillfully reflects its spring green.
The mandarin leaf may be responsible for that.
A light sweetness is conveyed by the peach - nestled in white magnolia and pink roses.
Emblem L'eau remains pastel-colored, yet still quite noticeable.
A soft resinous note supports the fragrance from within.

For me, L'eau is more mature than the EdT - even though it is lively and conveys cheerfulness.
Subtle elegance is paired with a charming "carefreeness".

For me, it is the ultimate spring fragrance.

In search of more spring fragrances for my collection, I came across this scent from Montblanc. Well, actually, I was pointed to it by the lady in the perfume shop ;-)
This fragrance is a successful blend of very light citrus notes and floral scents. Clearly, the fruity part stands out at the beginning, smelling of mandarin and peach, and it simply whets the appetite for summer. What remains is mandarin, rose, and musk making their way through.
I’m sitting in the car with the top down and a decadent pair of sunglasses, driving through the Alps to Italy. Passing through vineyards and fruit orchards. I stop at a tiny inn and sit in the rose garden under a little mandarin tree, ordering an Aperol Spritz - or maybe a Limoncello instead?
This scent is fantastic on me. I've already received the first compliments, and my mood is lifting. The sillage is stronger than you think, so be careful! The longevity is great; after 6 hours, it’s still fully present, despite eating at an Indian restaurant and the corresponding food smells in my hair and clothes.
It's going straight onto my wish list!

review_title: Does not deserve the current rating
review_content:
Written when rating was 6.4

This is good! Why do people clown on it? Yes, the price is not worth it, but you can get it for $70 on discounters. It is what it claims to be. Cold vetiver. The opening is undeniably vetiver, but it remains like that all along. Something in the mix, whether it is the juniper or sandalwood (both of which are not that prominent to my nose) gives it a more lofty vibe. More of a tundra than a glacier. It is classy, masculine, and timeless. Out of the 5 of this collection, this one is my favorite.

Vetiver Glacier is definitely a men's fragrance for me, and it is a scent that puts me in a real dilemma as a woman. On one hand, I find it very piercing and almost aggressive with its sharp freshness and spiciness - so present that it keeps me at a distance at first. On the other hand, this freshness and spiciness, along with the woody notes, are so special that they make me pause. It is different. It is a statement. Not a typical everyday scent, not a pleasing mainstream fragrance, but a composition with edge and character. This sharpness remains present for a long time, and that is what fascinates and repels me at the same time. I believe this fragrance only works when worn by the right person, as it demands a certain presence, perhaps even some rough edges in character; otherwise, it can come across as too loud too quickly. For me personally, it is a kind of olfactory tension: I stop, perceive it, am impressed, and at the same time, I wouldn’t want it in my nose for the long term. A scent that polarizes and definitely has a character... for me as a woman, however, it is too demanding. ...

The pink juice made me expect a watered down floral, heavy on rose or freesia or something. What I got instead was something quite unique. The femme who wears this is an individuelle indeed!

The top note of bay is very strong to me and I'm not a huge fan when it's still wet. It's so herby and medicinal, it makes me think of Vick's Vapo Rub. Thankfully it tones down as it dries and begins to blend with the currant. The bay never leaves completely but it takes it's place in the background as a support structure for all the other notes.

This has a slight "plastic doll head" quality and I happen to be one of those people who loves that doll head smell. I actually seek it out and have bought "doll smell" sampler packs! The notes I voted as strongest are: Pink pepper, bay, red currant and vanilla. The florals exist but I can't pick out individual flowers. This isn't for a girly girl, it's for a sassy girl in charge.

Femme Individuelle is the ideal scent for every day. No one feels offended by this fragrance, it does not cause sexual harassment in the workplace, is resistant to all kinds of complainers, does not intrude on allergy sufferers, and gives the whole environment the impression: I am freshly washed!
Without much effort, one (or woman) can leave a "good impression" with this scent. If you want to be pleasantly present without necessarily standing out: Femme Individuelle is the best choice.
~
IN THE OFFICE: Femme Individuelle
JOB INTERVIEW: Femme Individuelle
VISITING A GOVERNMENT OFFICE: definitely Femme Individuelle
HANDLING A COMPLAINT: of course Femme Individuelle
PRETENDING to be innocent: Femme Individuelle
NO DESIRE FOR S*X: this can be supported by Femme Individuelle
DATE: for heaven's sake - absolutely not Femme Individuelle!
PROMOTION: do not even think about wearing Femme Individuelle!
NEED TO STAND OUT: best to keep Femme Individuelle closed!
~
I don't need to describe the fragrance notes themselves; anyone can see them in the pyramid, so I will limit myself to the effect and expression of this delicate companion.
Upon spraying, Femme Individuelle envelops the wearer in a powdery-fresh veil that accompanies her for several hours. One should not expect a spectacular scent evolution, as the fragrance only vaguely changes from floral-fresh-powdery to soapy-powdery.
~
Conclusion:
Femme Individuelle does not really live up to its name, or maybe it does? Is its classically elegant restraint perhaps ultimately what is meant to give us back our individuality? Should this scent subtly underline our personality without being loud and conspicuous?
I don't know. If I were to give this fragrance a name, it would be more like "Femme Incognito"!
~
Why did I give it 70%???
Quite simply: it’s not that I don’t like it; I know few scents that fit into everyday life as well as this one. It is unobtrusively elegant and adapts well to the situations of daily madness where an egocentric sillage is simply not welcome. But personally, I find it too expressionless, or should I say too "quiet" for a "loud" girl like me?
As a companion for hot dance nights and as an aphrodisiac, it completely fails; it is far too inconspicuous and well-behaved.....

... and dirty!, my grandma always added sharply. Logically speaking, she may be right. A bubbling mountain stream is certainly cleaner than a stagnant puddle. But I don't want to know where she got her insight from. Femme individuelle is definitely not dirty. I was hoping for a nice office scent, pleasantly unobtrusive and quiet. And surprisingly, I was taught better.

According to the comments, the fragrance is supposed to be very delicate and being an EDT, one can be generous with the spraying. Four spritzes on the neck and one on the wrist, and I’m enveloped in a substantial cloud of pepper. That’s it for delicate, as it tickles quite a bit in the nose and seems almost to laugh at me. The blackcurrant doesn’t take long to show up. It unfolds rather sour and a bit tart, hitting my taste perfectly. There is certainly enough sugary fruit. The bay leaf provides a fine aromatic and pleasant spiciness. Here, the scent is spicy, tart-fruity, and fresh. Definitely more interesting than I thought and even brings a room-filling sillage at this point.

In the heart note, the sharpness of the pepper subsides and the spiciness recedes more into the background, though it never completely disappears. The fragrance becomes sweeter and softer. The rose presents itself quite strongly without being transparent, but it lacks the velvety and soft touch to give the scent sensuality. Lotus adds fresh accents and lifts the fragrance; without it, the scent would probably be too boring. The heart is floral, fresh, spicy, and sweet, without being sticky. A gentle femininity that does not entice, but simply "is".

After that, the fragrance fades a bit. It becomes quieter until only a sweet, warm, and spicy whisper can be perceived.
The vanilla is very soft, smooth, and occasionally, musk peeks through stealthily.

The bottle is very beautiful, thick glass, curved shape, and well-crafted. The spray mist is very fine. The light pink color fits well with the scent. Femme individuelle can be used in many ways, suits every season, and impresses with long-lasting wear. Fortunately, it is not as quiet and inconspicuous as I initially thought. Initially quite robust, the fragrance soon merges with the wearer and emphasizes femininity in a more modest than overtly feminine way. I still give it 80%, as the spicy and fruity freshness lifts the mood and prepares well for the upcoming workday. Additionally, I am convinced by its good longevity.

Many thanks to Springflower for sending it.

My chronic curiosity is directed towards quiet scents. Underestimated fragrances. Disparaged perfumes. Well, Femme Individuelle is certainly not disparaged, although it might be somewhat smiled at for its quiet presence that is said to characterize it here. The wonderful comment from Michelangela piqued my curiosity; it was clear: quiet, discreet, fine, hardly anyone owns this scent, I see no advertising, zero hype, affordable price -- this has to be tried!

The opening is already a surprise. Strong-fruity, slightly sweet, and definitely a bit fiery, the scent bursts onto my skin. Wow! Well, that's not so quiet and discreet after all. And another surprise: the wicked, wicked currants, which always stick their sour tongues out at my skin, are here flattering and warm-fruity. Goodness!

The transition to the heart is incredibly smooth and flowing, the change so discreet and gradual that I am equally amazed. The rose -- even rose is not necessarily my close friend -- is juicy, warm, non-musty, and almost sensual. The lotus holds it back a bit and brings a touch of freshness, otherwise, Ms. Rose would be unstoppable and would fully display the feminine sensuality attributed to her. The impression lasts a long time. A very long time. How can a scent that is said to have a certain inconspicuousness last so long and well? I'm amazed once again.

After many hours, the scent impression shifts just as skillfully as in the transition from top to heart towards a warm, sensual base. I can clearly smell the patchouli, fine and non-musty as well, and it holds the scent on the skin with its tried-and-true base companions like Pattex.
